So the novels of Patrick O'Brian are seemingly destined to remain an untapped resource in cinema, but there is still plenty to enjoy here as a stand-alone film.During the Napoleonic wars, captain of the HMS Surprise, 'Lucky' Jack Aubrey (Russell Crowe), has been given the task of pursuing French privateer Ancheron, and to 'sink, burn, or take her as a prize'. When one of the crew hears the distant sound of bells one night, the Surprise is taken unawares by the immense power of Ancheron, which is near twice the size of Surprise, and wields much more firepower. Almost fatefully damaged, Aubrey takes the Surprise and retreats into the fog to repair the damage, only to be attacked and pursued again. They reach the Galapagos Islands, where Aubrey predicts Ancheron will head to in order to attack Britain's whaling fleet, and will allow time for the ships doctor Stephen Maturin (Paul Bettany) to walk the islands to gather specimens and notes on the wildlife.After the exciting opening that shows the almost complete destruction of the HMS Surprise, Weir takes us in close quarters with the various levels of the ship's hierarchy from the mates who lie packed like sardines inside the ship being fed on gruel and rum, to the spacious quarters of the captain and his lieutenants. Drinking wine and eating steaks in what looks like a grand dining room of aristocracy, Aubrey and his immediate underlings are certainly privileged. This is mirrored in the scenes of Jack and Stephen playing violin together, and while these moments are key to understanding the close friendship between the two despite them clearly being men of differing values, it also shows their upper-class backgrounds. The shipmates are less so. They are happy being rewarded for good work with double-helpings of gruel, but have an almost necessary brutish nature that becomes apparent when they begin to bully Midshipman Hollom (Lee Ingleby).As well as portraying the societal structure of Britain within the confines of a ship, the film is also about the trappings of power. Jack and Stephen's philosophical discussions about this subject when Jack's hand is forced for the survival of the ship, causes Stephen to compare Jack's behaviour to Nero. Jack argues that the men require discipline and a strong hand to follow while Stephen advises that such an attitude can lead a man to be seduced by the trappings of power. There is also the matter of Jack's pride. At what point does duty end and ego begin? The pursuit of Ancheron will surely lead to the Surprise's demise and the death of its crew, but the men will follow 'Lucky' Jack no matter what.Don't be fooled though, Master and Commander offers scenes of relentless action, with the Academy Award-winning cinematography and sound editing coming together to form scenes that are as beautiful as they are breathless. The hand-held camera gets deep into the action, as cannonball's smash through the ship, sending razor-sharp splinters into the air and taking men's limbs with them. 14-year old midshipman Blakeney (Max Pirkis) loses an arm in the opening battle, and his idolising of Jack and Stephen forms the heart of the film. Jack is strength and leadership, Stephen is calm and thoughtful, characteristics on opposite sides of the spectrum, but Blakeney wants to be both. Sometimes it can feel crammed with too many ideas, but Master and Commander is a terrific film, and, like a lot of Weir's back catalogue, manages to be as thoughtful as it is gripping.www.the-wrath-of-blog.blogspot.com
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: Holding up beautifully over 15 years since it was first released, Master and Commander: The Far Side of the World remains a joy to watch to this day and stands up as what could just be the best work of its esteemed director Peter Weir and his star Russell Crowe.Adapting Patrick O'Brian's famous naval novels that spanned numerous books (Commander collates roughly 4 books into one story), Weir and his leading man capture the high-sea life of determined British captain Jack Aubrey, his friendship with Paul Bettany's long-term friend and doctor Stephen Maturin and his quest to track down a dangerous French vessel in the heat of the Napoleonic wars to magnificent effect.Doing things as practically as possible, Commander was a labour for love for Weir and his crew, as they built a real-life replicas and worked largely on a water-filled stage, giving Commander a lived-in and realistic foundation that visual effects could never conjure up, making it a deserving recipient of 10 Oscar Nominations and 2 wins in a year that was dominated by Return of the King.It's what makes the film stand-up so well to this day, an experience that has lost none of its original charms and magic, as Aubrey and his crew face a myriad collection of problems on their adventures to beat the trials of the deep blue, the tension that builds between crewman and the dangerous battle that is waging between their ship the H.M.S Surprise and the much bigger and more well-equipped French vessel The Acheron.Barely getting a respite from the day to day life of the ship, bar a thoroughly enjoyable stop over at the Galapagos Islands, Commander never once wavers in holding on tight to your attention as you begin to feel like a member of this crew both young and old, thanks to Weir and his cast members perfectly attuned delivery of the material.As Aubrey, Crowe is as charismatic and well-cast as his ever been and while at the time he was riding a wave of public love following Gladiator and A Beautiful Mind, there's a strong case for his turn here being his finest hour.Getting the most out of his fellow Australian, Weir and Crowe make for quite the team and together combine to make this thoroughly enjoyable, moving and thrilling cinematic yarn, that's an amazing feat of technical brilliance, that's just as at home waging a battle on the high-seas as it is focussing on intimate character moments such as Aubrey and Maturin's shared love of classical music, that sees the two jamming on the boat, much to the other crew members disdain.Final Say -Sadly a series that never was, we can still be thankful for this singular Master and Commander adventure, a stunning and memorable outing that stands the test of time as one of cinema's best examples of a largely forgotten about and under-loved event.5 flightless cormorants out of 5
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: Master and Commander: The Far Side of the World (2003), directed by Peter Weir, is based on the popular novels of Patrick O'Brian.  The star of the movie is Russell Crowe as Captain "Lucky" Jack Aubrey.  Crowe does an outstanding job in the role of a competent, capable commander, who is also clearly a flawed human being.   Paul Bettany is adequate in the difficult role of Dr. Stephen Maturin, the ship's surgeon.  I found the dialog hard to follow, and some of the sub-plots hard to understand.  It was difficult to differentiate among the younger officers, and follow the plot threads that involved them.  Much of their dialog was lost in the wind's howl and the cannons' roar.This film is worth seeing for its battle scenes and the glorious views of the sea.  If you expect subtle performances and profound plot, you'll be disappointed.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: The day-to-day life of a seamen in the golden age of sailing navy.
Review_body: Inspired by a novel, this film tells of the adventure of the frigate "HMS Surprise" and its captain, Jack Aubrey, in the South Seas, in pursuit of a powerful French warship during the Napoleonic Wars. To understand the film, however, its necessary to forget the book, set in a different conflict between British and Americans. The creative freedom of cinema has these things. The best of the film, however, is not the action or war scenes, but the way it accurately portrays the "modus vivendi" of a navy crew during this time. The historical portrait made is absolutely strict and this is something that a historian, like me, knows how to value and thank. Superstitions, war tactics, uniforms, hygiene and eating habits, relationship between military hierarchies, scientific research... all have been portrayed in a trustworthy way.Russel Crowe is the main actor and manages to perfectly embody the spirit of stubbornness and determination of an old sea lion. Beside him, the detailed and meticulous spirit of the naval surgeon Dr. Maturin is personified by Paul Bettany in a grandiose way, especially when both are together on the scene. There are other good actors, I especially liked a young man who plays a boy who, at the beginning of the film, loses an arm in combat (I didn't memorize actor's name but he did a great job). Another detail that delighted me was the soundtrack and the use of music during the film. Cinematography is excellent, particularly in combat and storm scenes. The biggest problem of the movie is it's nearly three-hour length. That will discourage some people, although this has not happened to me.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: A very new classic and great feast and pleasure for every (wanna-be) pirate on this planet. I want more.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: I don't know much about sailing
Review_body: I don't know how accurate the movie represents sailing or the strategy of sea battles during this period, but I found the movie entertaining.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: Slow and Boring. If It Weren't For Bettany, This Wouldn't Be Worth Watching At All.
Review_body: I'd like to give this a higher rating, if for no other reason than Paul Bettany's performance. He is exemplary here, and contributes a top notch performance. HIS Performance rates a 9.8/10. Billy Boyd was also a delight.This movie doesn't rate a rating. This was dull, boring, uneventful dreck, made as a vehicle whereby Russell Crowe could show off his talents. I have to admit that this movie does just that. It is lackluster, flaccid detritus, as is, in this reviewer's opinion, Crowe's acting talent. This was a prime example of perfect casting.This film would have suffered, regardless of who was in the lead, but Crowe's presence herein is a SERIOUS detractor of any and all enjoyment one could derive from said work. The pacing is dead, and the dialog delivery was like those horrible Dudley Do-Wright cartoons! I'll save you, Nell! (Dudley voice) That's how stiff and unoriginal Crowe was throughout.Frankly, I hated this. I had no expectations, so there were none to beat, and it STILL failed miserably.As usual, I'm in the minority, but I thought this was an entire waste of film, except for Bettany and Billy Boyd.Sorry, but this rates a 0.7/10 from...the Fiend :.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: What you have here is Crowe still thinking that he's the greatest actor that ever lived.That all takes away the fun of a movie that had the potential to be a high seas epic like, say, Captain Blood.Peter Weir lets Crowe go crazy and you can almost taste the ego dripping out of the pours of every seen, so much so that he doesn't allow Paul Bettany to shine and he's a good actor in his own right, as is James D'Arcy and again, Crowe seems to want to hog all the acting glory there too.Honestly, its hard to sit down and watch a man try to upstage everyone in every scene, especially when they are actors that could hold their own against Crowe...if Crowe allowed that to happen.So, you get to sit back and watch ego and that gets boring.It's a shame, the script and directing were there, it could have been a great film if we didn't just see ego shine.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: Patrick O'Brian is the John le Carre of the sea story.Where the earlier acknowledged masters of the genre(C.S.Forrester always excepted)often gave life in King George's Navy a gloss of glamour it never possessed,Mr O'Brian detailed it with a cold eye for the squalor of the Lower Deck.He also invested his adventure stories with the trappings of literacy - involved plotting,character development,historical research that,combined,made him virtually sui generis. Certainly "Lucky Jack" Aubrey and Dr Stephen Maturin are 20th century men nearly 200 years before their time. The good doctor is brave and cool - headed enough to operate on himself to remove a lead ball form his chest,passionate enough to play a Bach gigue on his cello,percipient enough to grasp the significance of the Galapagos Islands to Naturalists and stubborn enough to gainsay his Captain who,after all,has power of life and death over his crew. He is the mirror - image of Aubrey himself,who,if a slightly less complex character,shares many of his friend's qualities. Life for the crew - many of whom would have been press - ganged - was generally recognised to centre round "Rum,bum and concertina" and two of the three are well represented in "Master and Commander".The third may be read in the glances given to some of the many very young boys scampering round the gundecks. Aubrey (Mr Russell Crowe) is respected and feared by his crew.Whilst by no means a tyrant,he knows that sometimes discipline can only be maintained by taking hard action and does not hesitate to do so when faced with a potentially explosive incident caused by inaction by a weak officer. This is a long movie,but the strength of the plot and the quality of the performances and,above all,the realistic scenes aboard ship in heavy seas and in battle,the creaking ropes,the decks slippery with blood,the deafening roar of the guns and their devastating effect on wood and flesh,keep it sharp and riveting. For all his acuity,Captain Aubrey is not omnipotent,and this frailty - if it be one - makes him even more sympathetic,as the end of the movie proves. An exceptionally well - made movie that makes one hope for a sequel - and I don't write that often.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: Not masterfully done, but at times commanding
Review_body: `Master & Commander: The Far Side of the World' is a modest thrilling high-seas adventure film. Russell Crowe stars as Captain Jack Aubrey, the Commander-In-Chief of a British sea vessel navigating & battling in the high seas during the 19th century Napoleon wars. The film also co-stars Paul Bettany as the supportive, but yet, conflicted ship doctor whom is also Captain Aubrey's confidant. Crowe & Bettany, as they both did in `A Beautiful Mind', deliver potent performances that were beautifully executed. Auteur Peter Weir's astonishing direction of high-seas battle sequences was the work of a skilled craftsman. However, I must admit that i was drowned with boredom with the film's screenplay, which was as long-winded as some of the sea storms shown in the film. `Master & Commander: The Far Side of the World' is unnecessary lengthy but it does not deserve for you to `wave' bye-bye in midway through its cinematic voyage. *** Average
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: A wonderful film and wonderful adaptation technique.
Review_body:
The popular reception of this film-a lukewarm box office in which the film either lost money or barely broke even despite the critical love-forms one of the great disappointments in my life. I don't normally care about this but this is one of the very few films I longed for a sequel upon seeing it the very first time. The film was intended to launch a franchise as the book series it is based on runs 20 complete volumes, and a 21st unfinished work. I wanted at least 1 more film in this series because I enjoy the film so much and so much of the books was left to tell. The film's technical aspects are impressive-and I will say more about them in a moment-but it is really the screenplay that makes this movie.Aubrey-Maturin series is wonderfully layered, detailed and mosaic of the British Navy c. 1800-1815. O'Brian's books are not plot driven and much of their joy is the period detail, a day in the life aspects. Aubrey and Maturin are *exceptionally* well realized characters; this portrayal of male friendship is one of the best in all of English literature. I think the any *single* novel would be hard to adapt outright-none of them fit neatly into a traditional 3 act screenplay. Weir and Collee hit upon a brilliant technique to address this. The actual story of the film is largely new and not found in any of the novels-the plot most resembles The Far Side of the World but it is the mere skeleton of that novel. Instead certain scenes or notions are stitched together from *several* of the novels-Master and Commander, HMS Surprise, The Fortune of War, The Letter of Marque, The Far Side of the World etc. to tell a new story involving these characters. Lines of dialog are lifted from about a dozen of the novels. if you know the novels well-and I do-the film plays a bit like the greatest hit of the series. (Through I wish Maturin's intelligence work and opium addiction were worked in more overtly. If you know what you are looking for it is there. Only "problem" with the film) But despite that the film feels complete and it forms a perfectly enjoyable introduction to this world.
The decision to keep the film almost exclusive on the Surprise solidifies the traditionalism of the film. There is a purity in the storytelling that feels like O'Brian was merely copied into cinema. This brings me to my other major point of discussion. This is one of the very films I really like that is conservative in political meaning of that term. While Maturin is often allowed to voice (forms of) liberalism this film, like the novels, is Burkean toryism defined. The respect for ordered society and hierarchy, the foolishness-weakness of individuals, God and Country being the height of identity, British practicality and empiricism is all here. I admire the purity of the expressions of these values and I enjoy the dialectic that Maturin forms with them. The characters feel caught in an endless tradition in this film and I can't help but think Burke would approval of this.Returning the film proper, the technical aspects transport the viewer into this world. The cinematography is especially painterly and some shots reminds me of Turner's naval compositions. The special effects are perfectly realized and a classic blend of models, CGI, splicing footage etc. There is a romanticism of this time period for me and the film captures it. I can't tell you how much I love to get lost in the details of the canons, sails, the grape shot, the creak of wood, the changing of the watch, the naturalist's expedition and the witticisms.
But above all it is the complex and authentic friendship between Jack and Stephen that makes me love this film. Intense, intimate relationships between men are rare to find in cinema-especially if they are intimate without being erotic. It is even rarer to have the give and take, vulnerability and acts of sacrifice depicted with ease as it is done here. Crowe and Bettany are tailored made for these characters and I simply love both of their performances. (Fun sidenote: Weir was petrified that people would think Stephen was imaginary because of A Beautiful Mind to the point that he made sure that several characters interacted with him *prior* to Jack.)
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: Plot; A British ship and a French Privateer play a game of cat and mouse on the high seas during the Napoleonic wars.Managing to be both taut, but unrushed, this utterly immersive sea faring tale makes you feel like your right in the thick of it w/the crew of the HMS Surprise. Star Russell Crowe brings an authenticity to these kinds of roles, and the cast around him all look as if they were pulled off of an actual 19th century Corvette. Well acted, sharply written and expertly directed, Master and Commander is a rare exception to the rule that "They don't make 'em like that anymore.".
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: Excellent movie, crowe is phenomenal as usual!! You'll love it!!
Review_body: Love movies that take place at sea, especially ones that are from the 1800s early 1900s they have so many facets that are interesting. ie costumes, guns, swords, dialect, manners, chain of command, the whole package is like being there!! This movie has a little of everything, fighting, canons, ship attacks, desperation of being at sea,leadership, incredible acting and direction, cinematography, a beautiful movie and a must see film!! Solid 8.5!!!
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: Good movie, if your in the right kind of mindset...
Review_body: Now, this is in one aspect, a great movie, and in another one just an average one. Let me explain my last viewpoint first. As a matter of intriguing plot this movie does not have much to offer. Crowe commands an english warship, and are under order to seek out and destroy his enemies, which in turn are trying to destroy him. End of story. There are little help from subplots in interaction between the crew. But then again, this movie's strength is not the plot. It's strength is the scenery, acting and details. This movie should not be watched as a ordinary movie, this movie should be felt. Because the makers of this movie have put in an effort for details. If you let it the movie may transport you onto the ship were you can feel the waves, smell the salty ocean and hear the roar of the storms. Thats the strength of this movie. 7/10
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: 'Master and Commander: The Far Side of the World' is not as impressive as its title. Russll Crowe is Capt. Jack Aubrey from the British Navy, also known as Lucky Jack. His friend and surgeon on his ship is Stephen (Paul Bettany). They encounter a French ship and although that one is much bigger and their own ship is damaged Jack wants to follow and attack the French ship. Stephen and of course others are not really sure of this mission.That is basically the story although there are some more interesting human stories. For example there are teenagers on board who have higher ranks than some older adults. A sequence on the Galapagos Islands is a nice little part on land. But the story is not what makes this movie interesting. Well, not for me. I liked the way the characters developed, especially the differences between Jack and Stephen, but I wanted to see an epic tale on the ocean.Partially I got what I wanted. Unfortunately there are only two main battles and with 140 minutes running time it seems to take a lot of time before they arrive. A good thing is that when the battles come they are terrific. Sometimes a little hard to follow may be, but overall it looks great. Not only the battles for that matter; the costumes, the art direction and set decoration and the cinematography are all flawless. For the looks this movie would be a masterpiece. The movie as a whole is not a masterpiece but it is still good. I just think it could have been better in some ways.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body:
Overall Master and Commander is truly one of the greatest, if not the greatest story of ships at sea. The battles are big and satisfying, and ultimately rewarding, and the quiet moments are often intimate, with mystery and also exciting and humorous as we watch the crew deal with this long quest of hunting down the enemy. I really don't have enough good things to say about this instant classic, other than if you haven't seen it, watch it right away, and the same can be said if you have already seen it, watch it again.
For our full review of Master and Commander and hundreds of other reviews, articles, and podcast episodes visit us at True Myth Media!
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: A great victory for the art of film making.
Review_body: Peter Weir is surely a very accomplished director, who just loves to get every detail correct and proper. From building ships to selecting a capable cast that could act and learn the ropes on board a British Napoleonic Warship. The action, realism and pace is spot on, whilst the intrinsic relationships make it pretty much stand out from anything previous. This film was hard work for real but paid off a treat. As far as I understand the story was based on a fight between an American and a British ship but the former was changed to French (naturally), as it was an American backed film. Hollywood has done this many a time but it's only a small glitch. Russell Crowe on his own is enough to guarantee the quality, in both action and his unique period style acting.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: Master And Commander is an extremely specific movie. It's really well-made and never boring.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: 2003 was a pretty competitive year for big-budgeted action epics. The third and final instalment of the "Lord of the Rings" ate up all the Oscars, the first "Kill Bill" had that Tarantino magic, "The Last Samurai" was too much like other acclaimed films, and the first "Pirates of the Caribbean" sat perfectly with Disney. Where does that leave the first adaptation of Patrick O'Brian's work. The film from 2003 that this is the most like is "Pirates" but this is is more serious. This being more serious doesn't make it better, but it certainly is the better film.Russell Crowe was on a roll in the late 90s and early 2000s. LA Confidential, The Insider, Gladiator (his crowning work), A Beautiful Mind (what should have been his crowning work), then this. He plays the charismatic captain of the HMS Surprise, Jack Aubrey. I have never read the series of books that this is based upon, but I guarantee Crowe's portrayal was on. If not, then I am just a big sucker for deep, alive characters.Aboard the Surprise is a wide array of fleshed out and memorable characters. Other than the Captain, the main guy is Stephen Maturin who is the doctor on the ship, played with grace by Paul Bettany. He also educates those aboard. Some more characters include a boy who must get his arm amputated, but that never stops him from learning. One major strength this flick has is its sense of friendship and comradely. They are all for one and one for all (what this is alluding to is inferior to this majestic film).Master & Commander takes place during the Napoleonic Wars in the sea. The Surprise represents England and their mission is to destroy the French Acheron. Jack's mission eats away at everyone as he grows more obsessed with winning the fight. He is like Captain Ahab, but more nuanced. This shows the depth and complexity in the Jack Aubrey character and brings us deep into his mind. Although this doesn't dive quite as deep as an Ingmar Bergman film, the way the characters are developed in this are still fascinating and the way it should be for all films.The battle scenes are astonishing as can be. We get man versus man, man versus nature, and man versus self. The man versus man battle scenes with the cannons and guns are usually the first thing that people notice with this, and they are definitely as good as people say.Master & Commander is an entertaining and poignant film that is one of the year's best. How only one novel in the series of twenty got adapted to the big screen is beyond me. I say they reboot this as a series for Netflix or Crave.4/4
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: This ranks right up there with all the great sea adventures ever filmed and I think you can make a case that this is one of the best. The script is based on the novels of Patrick O'Brian and it carefully balances the magnificent battle scenes with character development so we can understand the way these men behave during war. The story is about the men on board an English ship called the HMS Surprise and Jack Aubrey (Russell Crowe) is the Captain in charge. Also on board is Ship Surgeon Stephen Maturin (Paul Bettany) who is greatly interested in biology and a good friend of Aubrey. The Surprise gets involved in a sea battle with the French warship Acheron and they are forced to flee and repair damages. Its 1805 and they're mission is to keep the French from controlling the waters off of Brazil. Aubrey heads to the Galapagos Islands and figures out where the Acheron will be going so they can try and find it. Aubrey wants to continue the chase but Maturin questions his logic and suggests that they go to the nearest port for the ships repairs but Aubrey rejects that idea. During the voyage we see the Surprise get caught in a terrible storm where Aubrey has to give the order to cut the line and leave a seaman floundering in the water. One of the Midshipman is Lord Blakeney (Max Pirkis) who is only 13 years old and after the first battle with the Acheron his arm is broken and has to be amputated. During the stay at Galapagos Aubrey gets an idea of disguising his ship as a whaler and getting close enough to initiate a battle. This exciting film is directed by the great Peter Weir and while his talents as a director are more towards character development I think thats why this film works so splendidly. The film consists of two battles with another ship and sandwiched in between is the peril of a fierce storm that endangers the ship to a point where it could sink. Weir does a great job of allowing the viewer to get to know each character intimately and in certain scenes we see that some of the seamen have been shanghaied. It reminds us how different things were during war and young boys were put in charge. Its hard to shake the indelible image of a 13 year old with one arm leading grown men into battle! The core of this film is the performance by Crowe. He's perfectly cast and its because of his incredible charisma on screen. The role of Captain Aubrey had to be cast for an actor that you would believe could lead men into battle and Crowe is that actor. Like Mel Gibson in "Braveheart" and Kenneth Branagh in "Henry V" we can envision Crowe inspiring men to go to war. Once again Crowe proves to be one of the best actors of our time. Aubrey plays the violin and we get a sense of how well rounded a person he is. Bettany is also excellent as Maturin and his friendship with Aubrey is evident. He seems to be the only one capable of matching wits with him and we sense that is one of the reasons Aubrey admires him. The battle scenes are both brutal and exhilarating. We watch as cannon balls rip into and through the sides of ships and its the type of warfare that we haven't seen very much in films, at least not filmed this great. This is a truly rousing adventure film on epic scales and its extremely exciting to watch.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: Great Film But A Bit Light On the Storytelling
Review_body: Set during the Napoleonic Wars in 1805, "Master and Commander: The Far Side of the World", is a on the sea story about a British ship the HMS Surprise led by Captain "Lucky" Jack Aubrey (Russell Crowe) as they are assigned to take down the French ship Acheron that's causing problems aross the coasts of Brazil. Under the direction of Peter Weir based loosely on the Aubrey-Maturin novels by author Patrick O'Brian, we are offered a visual masterpiece with an atmosphere that's second to none. The shots are truly a first-class A-level thing of beauty. Sadly however there are many scenes that are mundane in spite the fact that they are in the middle of a serious battle making everything abou it way too light in its premise. The execution is really good, however its concept is highly questionable.This movie is difficult to critique being that the positive things are way out in the open to fully appreciate and that the good does outweigh the bad. The failings in this movie are ubiquitous but subtle. To put it mildly though the movie is a work of fiction, the settings, props and costumes all seem to have the makings of a film based on real events and may have been inspired by real events this movie is very high in its authenticity. And though there were battle scenes that were brutal and bloody, they were few but far between. What's problematic about "Master and Commander: The Far Side of the World" is that at times the direction where this movie is heading feels more like this movie seems for kids rather than adults.It tries to play it big and intelligent, but then as I sit through it, I don't find the necessity in its intentions. Sure the history and the knowledge is well researched and provocative, I just wish the story was given the same level as its historical accuracy. With its intentions and details given proper treatment, the lightness in its storytelling doesn't get the equal treatment it deserves, which is why this movie can't be regarded as a classic.The opening scenes are handled quite well, with a nice background of the Surprise floating along the tranquil seas, on a quiet morning. The tranquility of the open seas my look relaxing from an eye's view. However, the isolation and insufferable conditions is a sign nothing is settling about this voyage. When the battle scenes take charge, there's a sign that the ship itself isn't the only thing taking charge, but the crew behind it. When the cannon fire targets at them, the men on board prepare for heavy duty battle, not for the sake of being tough, but mostly for survival and that they can't turn away at any point.The film itself is not just based on ship battles, costume drama and what's happening behind the scenes involving the crew, but the interactions based on the friendship between the two most important authority figues on the ship. Led by Capt. Jack Aubrey (Crowe) we see a dedicated, determined leader destined to take down this rival, more advanced French ship and will take all risks necessary for his British pride. And the crew's doctor Stephen Maturin (Paul Bettany), an intelligent, loyal, man of science and more critical thinker. He's also the only one in the crew who tell off Aubrey when he's wrong.Captain Aubrey's mission is to stop a French ship from entering Asia, only problem is, this rival ship is more powerful and advanced than the one he's commanding. The other crew thinks it's best to surrender and go back, but being stubborn and head-strong, he won't rest until he fulfills his mission regardless of putting himself or his crew's life in danger. The Acheron leads the Surprise all the way across the South Atlantic and into Cape Horn.Relying less on quotes and dialogue, Weir's direction truly demonstrates the isolation of being out to sea. The battle scenes are violent, but the serve a purpose and isn't just dependent on body counts and bloodshed. We feel the effects of what it's like to be on board a battleship back in the early 19th century. When we see a young boy get his arm amputated, the delivery will sadden and shock you, but will also intrigue you like the way Weir had intended. We don't get to see the amputation because the camera doesn't focus on it, which is just as well because we can still the kid's reaction when it's done. There is some fun scenes that don't take place on the ship like when Dr. Maturin and few associates explore the Galapagos Islands to explore the wildlife that inhabit the island.When it came to the script, Weir along with co-writer John Collee didn't put very thought into the story due to him never reading the Patrick O'Brian series of books. It just seems off-putting that the relationship between Captain Aubrey and Dr. Matruin seem to shift from great bond of mutual respect they have for one another to having a different perspective of this mission. It just feels schematic that director Weir saw this as an excuse for them to argue with each other. It starts to feel like the "Star Trek" movies where opinions clash and verbal war ensues and only stops when cooler heads prevail. It feels like a cliche that every movie has to have these kind of conflicts placed into the narrative just for the audience to choose who you root for.This conflict starts to lose concentration on the French ship and the deadly battle that comes with it. It's a great film but the script needed. More teeth to have kept us intrigued.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: The major difficulty in selling an adventure film to an audience is that it is not an action film. A good adventure film usually has two action set-pieces, one at the beginning, one at the end, but most of the rest of the film is given over to questing, suspense, drama, humor. Occasionally an adventure film does wander close to the boundary of the action film - The Wild Bunch is so violent, the fact that its structure is that of an adventure film (rather similar to that of Stevens' Gunga Din) usually gets overlooked. On the other hand, some adventure films lack a violent set-piece - The Wizard of Oz is an adventure film as well as a musical, and nobody slugs it out in a fist-fest, although of course the Cowardly Lion offers to.Master and Commander is a first-rate adventure film. Those who complain of the long chase with its complicated back-story plot-twists miss the whole point - the adventure film is all about those back-story plot-twists. The reason is clear: the adventure itself is usually a very simple problem about how to get from one point on the map to another (where some great deed is to be accomplished, etc.); all the excitements and meanings of the experience are in the complications - Gunga Din can't become the hero of his film if the British soldiers don't stumble about making mistakes. Although essentially brave, good-natured men, the soldiers oft give in to temptations to be greedy, lazy, dishonest - never Gunga Din.Although Captain Aubrey is certainly at the center of his story, we only really learn why he is 'master of the ship and commander of the men' from the events that occur around him, and from his relationships with his friend, his sailors, and, though they meet only briefly, the French captain. He knows not only how to make the hard decisions but also how to live with them, and still maintain a relative calm and generosity.The film is magnificently photographed. The historical detail is very convincing. The acting is first-rate. And after it is over, you feel as though you have experienced something new and wondrously strange - you have lived an adventure.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: The buckles were not particularly swashing.
Review_body: The beginning of this movie looked promising. Watches made their way through the different decks of their vessel during the night. We saw an attempt to authentically recreate the gloomy stuffiness of life below during the great age of sail (it was almost too authentic, being little more than a series of lantern-lit tableaux).Individuals were introduced to us with very little preamble, apparently on the basis that we'd get to know them as the story unfolded. Well; I'm afraid I didn't. The story that did unfold was a cat-and-mouse chase caper that has been done more times than I've had ships biscuits and a tot of rum. For the most part it has also been done better, as in 'The Enemy Below'. Russell Crowe is competent as a hardcase with a vulnerable side, but that's a pretty easy pose, being the stock-in-trade of any number of one-dimensioners like Bruce Willis, Sly Stallone and so on. I found very little to empathise with, and so when the cannon-balls flew, I didn't much care who was in the firing-line.The battle scenes were very feisty, after the fashion of 'Saving Private Ryan'. I suppose we must take their realism on trust, nobody now being alive with first-hand experience.And then there was the sea. Sometimes it was rough, other times it was calm. Always it was big, but never magnificent. I am told that a camera was fixed to the prow of a tall-ship that was fortuitously heading for the cape at time of filming, in order to get some genuine high-seas footage. They needn't have bothered. A force-5 in The Solent would have delivered the goods.The French vessel had a mysterious way of ambushing them and laying chase - shades of 'Duel' there. And Cap'n Crowe pursued it with dogged zeal, even over-reaching his orders - shades of 'Moby Dick', now.Most of the personal conflicts and discoveries were formulaic and predictable (You just KNEW the doctor would find the French vessel on the other side of the island after good Cap'n Crowe had sacrificed the chase for his welfare). At other times it dragged like a kedge anchor, particularly during the 'musical' interludes.One interesting anomaly was the complete absence of rats. Remember; these vessels put to see for years. When rats got aboard - as they always did - they bred and bred, and having nowhere else to go: ran riot. There was no warfarin in those days. Furthermore, the crew were often in the habit of crapping in the ballast holds, giving their furry tenants an ongoing supply of offal to munch. And the stink? Well, what do you think? Likewise the cockroaches; They bred even faster. You shared your hammock with them. Perhaps Mr Crowe's starring sensibilities would not admit of such intimacy.I would like to say something positive about this movie. But apart from a profound relief when it ended, I can think of very little. If you're going to be authentic then do it right - or stick with Errol Flynn. Recently I watched an old 1950's movie called 'The Cruel Sea'. That was about hunting German subs rather than French Frigates. But in every aspect of presentation, from character to story to hardships, it was incomparably superior, and on a far more modest budget. Doubters should see them both back to back. And everyone who likes nautical movies should see the latter.As to 'Master & Commander'; for me it sank with all hands.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: If you have ever wondered what it would be like to be on board a British Frigate circa 1805, I doubt if you will ever come any closer to that experience than by seeing this movie. Getting all the details right was clearly a labor of love - a real ship was actually constructed for the movie. The realism effected is astounding, with minimal use of GGI.James Aubrey (Russell Crowe) captains the HMS Surprise as it plays a cat and mouse game with the larger French warship Acheron. The two ships first encounter each other in battle off the coast of Brazil and continue their chase around Cape Horn to the Galapagos Islands and beyond. The scenes filmed on the Galapagos were an unexpected treat for me - I had never seen footage filmed there.Aubrey is accompanied by Stephen Maturin (Paul Bettany), a medical doctor, surgeon, naturalist, philosopher, and friend. Aubrey and Maturin have contrasting temperaments and I found Crowe and Bettany to be perfectly cast - Crowe the decisive man of action, very much in command of his crew, and Maturin the reflective scholar and medic. The battle scenes are great, but what makes this more than simply an action entertainment are the discussions and interactions between Aubrey and Maturin that are at the heart of the film. As much as they are in conflict each has an abiding respect for the other and each has something to teach the other - Maturin is ultimately forced into action and Aubrey learns a lesson in warfare from one of Maturin's insects. Aubrey and Maturin are bound together by music and are never in more accord than when they are playing cello and violin together. Music plays an essential role here; I know some people who remember this movie mostly for its music.Breathes there a man with soul so dead, yea even a landlubber, who is not stirred when the drums start beating and the Surprise heads out in pursuit of the Acheron?This was a staggering undertaking and fortunately all the effort paid off in producing a wonderful film.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: There is a scene in "Master and Commander" that encapsulates the spirit of this movie. It is not one of the spectacular action sequences or a scene of tension between the characters. Rather, it is when the officers of 'HMS Surprise' dine with their captain, Lucky Jack Albury, Russell Crowe's character.The men around the table range from senior officers to young midshipmen. The dinner is formal and the men are respectful of the captain's position; it is also obvious that they hold him in high regard. One of the officers asks the Captain if he would tell an anecdote about Lord Nelson. Aubrey obliges and holds his audience in the palm of his hand; the scene not only reveals the awe seamen had for Nelson during his lifetime, but it also captures a feeling for the language, the humour, and the temper of the times.Like everything else in the film it is the details, lovingly observed, that make it an exceptional experience.Cinema has produced some memorable films about life in the age of sail, but "Master and Commander" can stand with the best of them. In fact, the film's production team had compiled clips from about 50 of the best sailing and period movies ever made. This was done to learn what worked on the screen and what didn't.Directed by Peter Weir, the film is based on a series of books by Patrick O'Brian. These feature Captain Jack Aubrey and Doctor Stephen Maturin, played by Russell Crowe and Paul Bettany in the movie.Weir's script captures the fabric of the times and the characters involved. This is true to the philosophy of Patrick O'Brian, who felt that fabric was far more important than plot.While on patrol off Brazil, 'HMS Surprise' is ambushed by a much larger French battleship, 'Alcheron'. With his ship damaged, the captain of 'Surprise', Jack Aubrey, decides to pursue the unscathed French ship. The ship's surgeon, Dr Maturin, feels the captain is doing this out of sense of wounded pride and this places a strain on their relationship. A violent storm and tension amongst the crew adds to the drama, especially when one of the officers is thought to bring bad luck – a Jonah.Another strand of the story involves Blakeny, a young midshipman who loses his arm in the first battle. Played by Max Pirkis. Maturin recognises his thirst for knowledge and encourages his interest in botany, especially when the ship arrives in the Galapagos.Eventually, 'Surprise' finds 'Alcheron' and the scene is set for the final showdown. Sometimes, a powerful opening sequence can overwhelm subsequent events, but not here. The final battle, after the pursuit around South America, caps a movie that rarely puts a foot wrong.Russell Crowe finds just the right tone for Lucky Jack. Balancing devotion to duty, a sense of humour and a dash of obsession he emerges as a leader of men not unlike his Maximus from "Gladiator", but far less gloomy. The actors sound authentic – there are expressions and snatches of dialogue that transport the ear as effectively as the camera transports the eye to another time."Master and Commander" is one film that almost demands a sequel, but so far Peter Weir doesn't seem interested. A pity, but at least we still have this one.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: 'Lucky' Jack Aubrey's (Russell Crowe) ship is attacked by a superior foe, almost sinking it, along with the crew. In the face of defeat he sets sail again in pursuit of the enemy; stupidity, or could it be brilliance will decide the fate of a nation or destroy the brave captain and his young crew.The production of the film is top-notch, everything fits seamlessly into the period, and the talents of Crowe and Bettany are plain to see. Not to forget that massive credit has to go to the young actors that make up the crew, there is plenty of talent on show here.The movie is full of intrigue and action, and it will stir the emotions of everyone. It's a great adventure with substance.8/10
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: Crowe/Bettany partnership is undoubtedly the highlight of the film for me. Everything else: "Eh"...
Review_body: I found "A Beautiful Mind" far less interesting whenever these two weren't onscreen together, and "Master and Commander... " suffers from the same problem to an even greater extent.  The rapport that these two guys obviously have is a joy to watch, and no amount of epic battles can compete with such cracking chemistry.  Well-staged though they are, I found the 'confrontational' scenes rather tiresome.  I much preferred Russell getting stroppy with the good Doctor and his other crew!Crowe seems to have cornered the market in playing iconoclasts, and Aubrey is a scarcely different addition to his canon.  It was fun to see the 'driven' aspects of his method again, and to draw parallels with Moby Dick! All the rest I found a little listless, to be honest; but I will freely admit to not being cut out for the high-seas, and I knew that going in. Certified land-lubber, me!  If this sort of thing has the potential to get your blood pumping, though, I suspect you could do far worse.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: Just what I expected only better - and yet somehow still the same.
Review_body: You'd think the Master & Commander part would be enough title but nope they thought more, more, more.Whether that pushed audiences away or not isn't important, I personally never bothered with this because I assumed it was merely another "we're all in the navy let's have some ship to ship battles" thing. And it is, it's a good one, but that's nonetheless what it is.We join the action in the second quarter of the battle between Napoleon and the Rest of the World, represented in this case by England ship the HMS Surprise. The Surprise is captained by one Jack Aubrey played by Rusty Crowe and has a crew of 200 give or take, some of them only kids. (And I mean kids, as in 12/13ish!) The year is 1805 and things haven't been going that well for the ROW team, Napoleon has basically been giving them a little bit of a flogging, and it is Rusty and co's job to track a French warship that is in the area and engage if possible.Course it's possible, this is a naval battle film! Can I just cut some corners here and say that tactically the French captain and Rusty seem to be on a par, each coming up with whiz bang ways of getting into or out of range, and each pulling some nifty tricks that are totally unexpected? (That saves me from having the explain each one, there are a lot.) The French ship is bigger, better defended and faster however, otherwise it wouldn't be that much of a movie, what with the big boy bullying the little boys around.After an early battle that doesn't go their way the men want to call it quits and head home to their toothless loved ones that eat terrible food, Rusty sez "No", perhaps remembering he has a bunch of kids and that scurvy is probably more tolerable, and besides sailors get regular sex... with each other. So FORWARD we go.The constant voice of reason and doubt is Paul Bettany's as the ship's doctor, he wants to rest up and take a trip to the local Galapagos Islands where he can indulge his love of animals, in the scientific sense that is, (I've already cracked the standard navy = gay jokes, seems a bit think to add beastiality). Eventually it seems that the odds are against them and some key personell are injured so Rusty calls the whole thing off.But it's never that easy.This might come off (and is) an extremely simplistic and glib review of a vast and ambitious film. In reality there is much to like about M&C etc, the ships look splendid and amazing when in full sail fanging along the open ocean, the storm scenes and sea battles are incredible, I'm not sure if they used CGI or not but in any case... incredible and there is more than enough tough decision for Rusty to make to either escape or succeed, and of course they usually have negative implications too such as the death of crew.Rusty's captain is a fierce tactician and soldier, but obviously a loyal shipmate and great leader, and Paul Bettany's ship's Doc is at once a confidante and counterpoint to the captain when he fears he is a little ahead of himself.This is very much an exercise in substance over flash and meaningless FX and as such is a triumph. I myself have seen enough examples of substance though, and maybe I might change as I get older but in my eyes even a film of terrific realism and vision is still only just worth watching as far as I am concerned right now.Final Rating - 7 / 10. Just what I thought it would be, only better. And yet still the same, (somehow). Worth a look but not a crowd pleaser.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: Master and Commander: The far side of the zzzzzzzzzz.
Review_body: Everyone must know, this is the most visually breath taking films out there. Alot of work went into this and that kept my attention more than anything else in the film.So why did I snooze? The length? No way, I sat through very awake and with great interest JFK and Fanny and Alexander (uncut) in the theaters. The acting? Well, it was nice but in the words of a fellow poster, "..and the point is?". I just didn't care about these folks. And besides, there are going to be more "visually breath taking films" to see. Here's the rub: can you provide a story that keeps one's interest along with this? This one, for me, errr--didn't. Ya gotta surround yourself with the characters, story and situations and beyond the style, this one didn't.Yeah, its my fault. I didn't read the books, nor did I care about the characters before I walked in allowing me to develop an interest as I sat there -- but the ships and the waves and the battle were wonderful...but the lack of the men "HEAVING"....it was a man-ly movie made for man-ly men! Sorry, I'm just not a man-ly gal.But...I cannot WAIT for this film to come out on DVD. I hope its box screen, and will look just fabulous on my Plasma TV! But a $10 movie going experience? Not for me.Honestly, it could be due to my attention span because as I watched the film I expected Fabio to come out (remember him from those covers of books like this gals?!?!)....he just seemed to have a place that was deleted from this film..on purpose I think...he didn't need to say anything but just to be there with all that style..and the wind blowing through his hair...wearing the same stuff Russell Crowe does...yes...just to add to the style of the film...and to keep me... awake.Master and Commander is one of the best of the stylish films done this year, But that's about it. I could have waited to see this on A&E or PBS. Without Crowe as the lead, a big budget and Mr. Weir, this film would have gone the way of "Art House" releases, make no mistake.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: Very technical and fun to watch.
Review_body: (spoilers)Okay, the story is fictional.  Was a bit easier to figure that out than The Last Samurai.  I was stuck with a choice.  Watch this movie at the theater or Samurai.  I watched Samurai.  I'm glad I did too.  That one is emotionally charged.  And perhaps not entirely cool to watch.Master & Commander was simply a delight though.  One of the best sea faring films I've since since The Bounty.  (mind you I only saw The Bounty -the gibson version- a few months ago)  Hopefully we'll see more of these.  And I'm not talking Pirates of the Caribbean.  That one is pure entertainment, without much in way of seriousness.The action begins right off the bat , and with the occational breaks. doesn't stop.  If LOTR wasn't on the clock, either this movie or last samurai woulda made a decent showing.  (though I think I still would have been pulling for Whale Rider)I do have 3 known complaints.Camera work.  Some of the camera work is lousy.  Probably from the cramped quarters in which some of the scenes were shot.  My favourite error is as they are going around the table during a dinner meeting, the camera obviously bumps someone and you can actually hear the mistake. o_OThe ending.  It gives the possibility of a sequel.  Or does it.  I know that this is part of a book series.  (note the word series.... more than one)Finally.  Marketing.  Someone in the marketing department should be tortured, hung from the side arm and whipped.  They released this bare bones edition, without a shred  of special features in it.  I'd seen ads of a 2 disc set with that picture on the front.  So I bought it from Blockbuster. Where I found the bad news back home.  1 disc.  Having seen the other cover at dvdempire I informed Blockbuster they sold me the wrong one and I wanted the 2 disc.  They told me it doesn't exist.  After much persistence.  They said Best Buy has a 2 disc set and to buy it there.  I'd say the manager was probably so confused he didn't know his limb from limb.  Since the 2 disc is on the blockbuster webpage.  I ended up with a 3 disc set.So imagine this.Now we have the bare bones edition in widescreen and pan/scan.And now we also have the Collectors Edition in 2 disc sets and 3 disc sets.We've got 4 different versions to watch out for.  So bloody annoying.9/10Quality: 7/10 Entertainment: 15/10  (that is not a typo) Replayable: 10/10
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: You get Russell Crowe so we are off to a good start in this movie that depicts life at sea most excellently. Real absorbing drama with a good story to tell awaits the viewer so look forward to this movie treat. In the movie Mutiny on the Bounty, it points out that while England and her Navy is run on laws its the Captain that gives it heart and justice. Captain Bly did not Master and command this but Captain Aubrey (Crowe) in this movie does a masterful job of encouraging, edifying and leading his crew making their hearts one and that is why the story works on the screen and in real life. It is better to get love and devotion willingly and with a gladness than to take it. There is a difference. The crew even sing songs about the Captain and nick-name him Lucky jack. That's stuff you have to earn. Ahoy then, starboard bow and ....
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: Master and Commander Is both Masterful and Commanding: A Near-Perfect Combination of Action and Drama in a Period Piece
Review_body: There is something about a well-done film that is often taken for granted. You sit in your seat and allow the film to take you away and for approximately 2 hours, you are taken to another world, to a group of people you don't know, to places you have never been, and into situations you could scarcely imagine. And for these two hours, you are enveloped in this world, forgetting for a moment that you are not really there, only experiencing illusory images on a screen. Good movies do this to you. But it all depends upon an outstanding script, convincing actors, realistic sets, and superb direction. If any of these pieces are weak, the cinematic experience is compromised. Luckily, Master and Commander has all of the elements in spades. Instead of watching a movie, you feel you have boarded a military naval vessel at the very beginning of the 19th century. Your ship is loyal to England. And your commander is Jack Aubrey, played with stunning realism by Russell Crowe.Based on the novel by Patrick O'Brian, Master and Commander begins right in the middle of the action. It is as if the viewer suddenly woke up on a late 18th-century naval vessel amidst the conflict between Britain and Napoleon Bonaparte. You see the workings of the crew, their tasks, and their relationships. You see the hierarchical structure, from lowly ship hand to the officers and the captain. And, most stunningly of all, you experience being out on the wide open seas just south of the Caribbean islands along the eastern coast of South America.You mostly get to know the HMS Surprise's captain, Jack Aubrey (Crowe), and his struggles between his duty to and orders from the Crown of England and his love and responsibility for his crew. He must manage these interests while trying to capture the fastest ship known to the world in service to Napoleon Bonaparte. And of course, he can't allow the French to defeat him in combat, and he can't lose his ship at the hands of the French, other foes, or the destructive power of the sea. Aubrey is like the juggler at the circus, his hands juggling his men and orders, while his ship is balanced on his nose.The film begins in 1805 with the HMS Surprise and its crew sprinting down the coast of South America. They are in hot pursuit of the French's prize possession, the Acheron, which can out-gun and outrun the English ship. Fighting erupts, momentarily crippling the Surprise. The officers suggest finding a port, but Aubrey does not want to lose sight of his prey. The story becomes episodic as it chronicles the conflict between these two titan vessels. Softening the stern objective sensibility of Aubrey is a naturalist-doctor, Stephen Maturin, who serves as both the ship's surgeon and an enlightenment-style scientist who wants to study biology off the coast of the Galapagos Islands. But not even science can stand in the way of war and military conflict. Or might it be his ally?As usual, Crowe's performance is outstanding as he finds that subtle area where he is a compassionate and yet hard-nosed commander with a touch of wit and humor. Maybe slightly ideal, but we tend to run with it. Peter Weir's direction is masterful in the sense that he purposefully avoids drawing attention to itself. His goal is to give you this story without breaking new ground in cinematic technique which could distract from the unfolding of the epic drama. He wants to tell you a story on the high seas, not comment on the skill of "directing". And that is the mark of a truly great director.The relationship between the script, the actors, the setting and the director appears seamless. The action and the drama both coincide in such a way as to be believable without it getting too sentimental. Everything is seen from point of view of the ship mates, which keeps the viewer honed in on a particular point of view which appears to be by design. The story wants the viewer to take on the hopes and dreams, the prejudices, the hates and the fears of the crew. Whether or not it is moral or immoral to play war with the French is not the point. Rather, the filmmakers want you to understand the conflict from the English perspective. This is the kind of film-making that succeeds upon just about every conceivable level. I think Crowe makes an excellent Captain Aubrey, and would like him to recapitulate the role and make further O'Brian stories. A high-mark of pure cinematic entertainment.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: A good tale, if not perfect
Review_body:
I always feel embarrassed when I review a film that was based on a popular novel or series of books.  I hate to read. Even when I am at my loneliest like sitting on a stalled subway or up at a cabin that doesn't have electricity, I would rather sit back and rehash a movie I have seen in my head than pick up anything off the coffee room table.So when theatres were hit with the new Russell Crowe film, Master and Commander: The Far Side of the World, I knew that better more refined critics would be able to compare the film adaptation to the on-screen version.  I cannot.Not that that's a bad thing mind you. One of the bigger advantages of not caring to pick up the written word is that you accept the movie as a whole and are not constantly sitting in a theatre saying to yourself, 'It wasn't like that!' or 'He would never do such a thing!'  It's a small advantage, but it's all I got.Master and Commander is based on a series of novels by Partick O'Brian all surrounding (I suppose) Capt. Jack Aubrey (Crowe), head of the British ship the HMS Surprise during the Napoleonic Wars.  Aubrey has a daunting task in front of him and his mates as they follow and try to engage the behemoth French vessel the Acheron.  Their foe has twice the men and firepower than the Surprise, but hell, this is a story of heroes and bravery, so bring it on.  In this case, size does not matter.The movie shifts seamlessly from scene to scene with crewmembers yelling out orders while playing a cat and mouse game with the Acheron that has them twice the cat and twice the mouse.  This all leads to a final showdown where a brilliant idea inspired by an insect found on the Galapagos Islands, has the HMS Surprise trying to live up to its name and attack the unprepared Acheron.Released in the summer of 2003, Master and Commander went on to grab 10 Academy Award nominations including best picture and director.  Whether or not these awards were founded is an argument not to be had here.  However, there is no mistaking that with 10 nods (and none in the acting categories), the production values must have been top rate, and on that level it did not disappoint.There are so many elements and avenues one can take a review of M&C that it is hard to know where to start.  First and foremost, there is the direction of Peter Weir.  A four time Best Director Oscar wannabe, he has been behind the camera and calling the shots for nine critical hits in a row.  Even Speilberg can't lay claim to that feat (Hook, anyone?).  From 1981's Galipolli through Witness and The Truman Show, Weir has become one of those directors where actors cancel weddings to appear in.And, with M&C, Weir does not disappoint.  The characters are brisk and rugged and the it doesn't take him long before he has you feeling as if you are an actual crew member on the HMS Surprise awaiting your next command. Films set on the high seas have been hit and miss over the years.  For every Pirates of the Caribbean, there has been a White Squall, so the fact that Weir pulled it off so effortlessly is a testament to his abilities.Russell Crowe too, puts in another well received performance.  But what is different from his roles in Gladiator and A Beautiful Mind is that the supporting cast in M&C seem to steal scenes from him with regularity. Specifically, Paul Bettany, as the ships doctor and Max Pirkis as a young Midshipman who loses an arm in their first encounter with the Acheron, are both stellar in their portrayals as the ying to Crowes' yang and the young to Aubrey's old.But for all the hootin' and hollerin' fun this ship to ship battle ready movie embodies, it really took the DVD before I was able to understand everything that was going on.  During the opening sequence and later during a severe storm, the ships mates are yelling to each other things that I could not conclude.  Only by flipping the subtitle button did I finally understand what they were communicating.Also, in the final battle aboard the French vessel, it was cut so fast and furious, that it was hard for me to tell the two sides apart.  I couldn't tell who was winning 'cept for the rousing musical score which lead me to believe the good guys were kicking ass.  I am not suggesting that we should forgo history and have one side orange and one side blue, but maybe a steady cut of the sequence would have helped me with my bearings.
Despite these few observations, the movie as a whole was a satisfying experience.  The scenes on the Galapagos Islands (the first ever film to shoot ashore), were of great interest even though it kept us from the battle scenes we so craved.  And the two ideas of Aubrey to dupe the French were inspired.  In all, I have to give a thumbs up to Master and Commander: The Far Side of the World.  It may have had the longest title of any movie this year (move over Terminator 3: Rise of the Machines), but it didn't feel like a long sit once it got started.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: Peter Weir Directed and wrote from a novel.
Review_body: Russell Crowe, Paul Bettany, and Billy Boyd head up the cast of this exciting tale on the high seas. They are trying to prevent a French ship from reaching the Pacific Ocean. The main takeaways are the stunts that were performed on the ship. I bet there were injuries. These men had to climb a mast in all kinds of weather. Some men were at the top of the mast in the lookout box when storms arose with waves and winds that could break the mast and sink the ship. There were young boys on the ship too. What fresh food with vitamin C did they eat? It is so hard to imagine such a trip with all those men fighting to survive not only the voyage but the brutal others on the ship. The battle was deadly, and the burial of the corpses all sewn up is eyeopening. Russell Crowe is the perfect choice for ship's captain. He is robust but somewhat royal. Great film.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: Not my favorite Russell Crowe film, but I certainly enjoyed it. I wished I had seen it sooner and sad that it took me 17 years to actually seen it.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: MASTER AND COMMANDER: THE FAR SIDE OF THE WORLD Aspect ratio: 2.39:1Sound formats: Dolby Digital Surround EX / DTS-ES1805: At the height of the Napoleonic Wars, a British frigate commanded by a charismatic captain (Russell Crowe) engages in cat-and-mouse battle manoeuvres with a French warship.A surprisingly hollow work from director Peter Weir (GALLIPOLI, DEAD POETS SOCIETY), this good-looking epic - based on the novels by Patrick O'Brian - is bookended by a couple of stirring action scenes and features a truly ferocious storm sequence which places viewers at the very heart of the action. But everything else about this high-falutin' epic - nominated for countless awards - is thoroughly pedestrian, with few redeeming features. Crowe adds little to the heroic screen persona he cultivated in GLADIATOR (2000) and is upstaged by co-star Paul Bettany (DOGVILLE) as the ship's doctor and Voice of Conscience, while everyone else simply melts into the background. This is one of the few films in recent memory to feature virtually seamless CGI effects, and the entire production represents Quality writ large, but there's nothing remotely special about either the plot or its execution.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: 'Master and Commander' takes you on a voyage where you can virtually smell the sea and feel the storms. This film is about a captain, and the film focuses on the relationship that he has with the surgeon on the ship. The two come to understand each other through their differences; at one point, they stop at an island for the surgeon to collect specimens from that island. Meanwhile, the Napoleonic wars are raging on, and there are many storms and sea battles. Although a long film, the visual effects are well worth seeing this film for, and they make this film as strong as it is. A lot of detail was put into this and put into the film in this area. The acting is also very good, and this is a film about characters more than about battles.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: A fine piece of Ocean movie
Review_body: Russell Crowe had done LA CONFIDENTIAL before he did GLADIATOR that really kicked his career onto the top notch of Hollywood. GLADIATOR was a huge movie that captured Oscars and was simply a way too convisning, big, dramatic and epic movie to not draw itself attention, so when Russell Crowe headed for his next big movie it was a adaptation, this time; set at sea. MASTER AND COMMANDER: THE FAR SIDE OF THE WORLD is a highly exciting drama about a Captain and a crew that's having a hard time handling a aggressive ship that keeps attacking them. Director has done a fine job but I must say that the movie's finest details is; mood, music and general scenes going threw it. The movie is very fine watching, photo is beautiful and everything is very in place, although the movie did draw it's running time a bit too long at the middle of the movie, the end is so good that it is very worthy waiting on. Russell Crowe does a fine performance after he had to live up to his Maximus character. MASTER AND COMMANDER rules a lot of the time, with big ships firing canons, swords being drawn, genially made viola / bass music, fine photo, good dialog...very much of it goes very well on, another problem is; there's not much of originality or pure entertainment, so it gets a bit "dry" as the movie goes threw minute after minute. The end is fine and maybe the movie's best scene. As Crowe and his crew is done nailing the French boat Crowe starts looking for the Captain, but sadly enough he finds the Captain dead with a depressed doctor claiming the fact. Crowe tells his assistant to take the French boat and that they shall meet later. It all seems finished and Crowe and the doctor is playing music together when they get on the topic of the Captain and the doctor tells Crowe that the French doctor was already dead, so Crowe understands that he has been tricked...and that the "doctor" was the real captain. So, they turn around and heads for another fight...although this one we don't get to see... STARS: 4/5
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: This is a fabulous film in all respects. The actors are all and I mean ALL absolutely spot on with their performances. Russell Crowe, in particular, plays the part of the Captain perfectly, with just the right mix of the stern mixed with a good sense of humor. Paul Bettany, one of the worlds' most underrated actors, interplays perfectly as the ships' surgeon with Crowes' Captain. I'm not much of a sailor (especially when dealing with a huge ship), but all the seamanship type work was all done very realistically. Action? You want action? PLENTY! They're chasing a French privateer during the Napoleonic wars and they end up slugging it out very realistically, with splintered wood flying everywhere. There's close quarters fighting as well after boarding the enemy ship. Men were men back then! A very enjoyable action thriller!
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body:
Being a fan of Naval history, I rarely miss a sea epic.  Most of them suck. They're usually very romanticized, full of inaccuracies with a thin story line that a serious sea fan and former Naval officer leaves with a feeling of disgust and disappointment.   Not here, gang.  This one is a keeper.  I recall seeing the teasers and thinking how very accurate were the little bits and pieces I was seeing.  Then, we get Crowe on the bargain.  Crowe's hamming fits well with the role of a British Naval captain who manages to hold his crew together with his charisma and Bettany is superb as the cerebral ship's surgeon.  There are some very wonderful points of this film, the point of view never strays from the ship, the distinctions of rank and differences among officers and crew are clear, and the representations of the ship and battle scenes are remarkably researched and reproduced.  The only other sea epic I can recall that even comes close is Damn the Defiant. 
If you haven't seen this film yet, do so immediately.  It's a keeper!
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: Great film-not necessarily Oscar material though
Review_body: Relatives of mine who saw this said it wasn't very good because it had only twenty minutes of action and two hours of contemplating strategies of war. Yes, the movie does have some action, (mainly made up of a skirmish in the start and a large fight at the end), however the real goodness in this movie comes from how the characters interact with one another. This makes the movie, at least to me, very enjoyable to watch. "Master and Commander: The far Side of the World" is about friendship and how a captain keeps his men together as one over a rough sea voyage and defeat their French attackers. I liked many of the technical aspects to the film such as; the sound editing, photography, and visual effects. The work of the costume designers and set-decorators brings an 18th century to life. And the performances are flawless, particularly on Crowe's and Bettany's part. This is one of 2003's best films; however, I think it did not deserve 10 academy award nominations (winning two). Yes, it is a great movie, but in my opinion, not necessarily Oscar material.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: Yo-Ho-Ho! And, a bevy of Oscar nominations!
Review_body: *Spoilers, dead ahead!* I'm stuck for lavish praises, so I'll try to make this five sentences long, at least. It's very faithful to mainstream Euro-history, especially 19th-century sailing jargon and techniques. Not to mention, the costuming. It's also very humorous, what with Aubrey's pun concerning weevils. Not to also mention, Fate's conspiracy against Dr. Maturin being the first naturalist to report on the fauna of the Galapagos! *Can you say, "Charles Darwin?"* But, of course, being a guy, the best part for me was the climactic showdown with the captain and crew of the French privateer "Acheron." Man! Did midshipmen (a.k.a. work-study naval cadets) have to grow up fast, back then! Otherwise, they literally wouldn't live to grow up, at all. I guess what I'm trying to say is: it's a good thing "the Black Pearl" never went up against "the HMS Surprise." Lucky Jack would've blown Mad Jack out of the water! Two thumbs up!!
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: This review contains spoilers.Master and Commander: The Far Side of the World is a period war movie that premiered in 2003. The movie is directed by Peter Weir and is based on the book Master and Commander by Patrick O'Brian. The movie stars Russell Crowe as Captain Jack Aubrey of the HMS Surprise. The movie centers around the Napoleonic Wars conflict as the HMS Surprise must engage the Acheron a superior French vessel.Master and Commander: The Far Side of the World is an excellent movie. This movie has many great qualities to it. It is both a great movie, a great historical movie, a great drama, and a great action movie. This movie has so many great components that the movie comes together in an excellent way. The movie starts with an ambush by the Acheron on the HMS Surprise from that moment, the audience knows about the strength of the Acheron compared to the HMS Surprise.The movie is an excellent historical movie. Anyone that wanted a Napoleonic Wars movie will be entertained with this movie. This movie has great attention to detail across its sets, costumes, and props. The movie is able to grab the audience and present them the Napoleonic Era. It made for an excellent experience as the movie immersed everyone in this era. The drastic change that this movie had made was changing the enemy from the United States to French. The book originally had the enemy ship be crewed by Americans. The change did not bother me but for book purists, this can be a deterrent.The action in this movie is well framed and directed by Peter Weir. The movie has a sparse amount of action scenes but this does not detract from how well the action scenes are done. The action scenes are one of the best that feature the Napoleonic Era.
