Everything from the cinematography to the choreography is done to a grand detail. This movie feels incredibly epic across the 138 minutes of running time.The acting by the cast is great. Every actor does an awesome job. The highlight is obviously Russell Crowe's performance as Captain Jack Aubrey. Captain Jack Aubrey is an excellent protagonist that is great for this kind of movie. The rest of the cast fill their roles magnificently. Dr. Stephen Maturin played by Paul Bettany is one of the best characters in this movie. He had great interplay with Captain Jack Aubrey as they both seek to defeat the Acheron and fulfill Stephen Maturin's desire to learn about the indigenous creatures around the Galapagos. The side plot fills a good niche in much of the movie. The rest of the cast have great scenes and it all comes together in a nice way.I highly recommend 'Master and Commander: The Far Side of the World'.Grade: A
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: That's a very clean ship's floor...
Review_body:
Put some pants on when you're fetching eggs!In this situation ALWAYS better to be safe than sorry.Even in an emergency they add "if you please"... polite all the way to hell.Well, you both dropped everything.What a horrendous job. I'll stay land-side and churn butter.Swinging axes on rough floors strewn with blood in bare feet. No wonder 35 was elderly.Back to work you gawkers! Let me gawk!Slade always getting in trouble the rambunctious rapscallion :)All the gems of araby! Amber grease! A fortune!That's a horrible smelling under-deck.That sucks.Tropics to frozen wastes... Was that an elder man with his pants down on the bow?The men have their minds set on a target.Mr. Holland JonesUgh! Naught good comes from bird gaming.
The good doctor has reached a level of pale I thought not attainable by any man, even with his natural head start.Cactus stew!An underwater picture box... Ingenious!Violin marathon.Then a stick we shall be...
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: Exciting-Definitely; Historically Accurate-Mixed; Oscar Worthy-Not Really
Review_body: [Grievous and humiliating error in first submission corrected here. :)]Winston Churchill, wherever he is today, must recoil with horror at a quotation falsely ascribed to him about his beloved Royal Navy. Supposedly responding to an admiral's recitation of the Senior Service's history, the portly First Lord of the Admiralty purportedly responded that the navy's traditions encompassed "rum, sodomy and the lash." In "Master and Commander," etc., director Peter Weir serves up two of the service's traditions, rum and the lash but inaccurately leaves the sweating, groping, between decks sex life out.Weir with Russell Crowe as Captain Jack Aubrey of HMS Surprise, ably both abetted and challenged by his ship's surgeon, Stephen Maturin, played by Paul Brettany, draws the viewer into a powerful, gripping but somewhat sanitized world of the wooden warship at the height of its power before steam drove the old ships to wrecking yards.Based on the late Patrick O'Brian's very well received series of novels, "Master and Commander" places HMS Surprise in harm's way as Aubrey searches for a powerful French privateer during the Napoleonic Wars. The fate of England is at stake we are told (several times, actually). The search takes place in the deep reaches where the oceans collide at Cape Horn, in reality not where naval engagements took place during the long war.The time is half past Lord Nelson's splendid victory at the Battle of the Nile and before his crushing extinguishment of the French fleet at Trafalgar where he paid with his own life.Aubrey was a junior officer under Nelson and he regales his wardroom with stories about the one-armed, seasick-prone, philandering naval genius. Well, he leaves those details out. But no blowzy bimbo like Lady Emma Hamilton is in this captain's life. In fact there are no women in the film except for a few seconds when an undoubtedly randy captain gazes briefly at a native woman.HMS Surprise is, unfortunately, surprised at the very beginning of the film when its quarry hits the frigate with powerful broadsides, reducing the escaping-into-the-fog vessel to near helplessness. Aubrey resolves to make repairs and hunt down the French vessel, a decision that sets the pace for the rest of the film. Is he acting out of duty or from ego? A familiar war film issue.Weir cleverly never lets the viewer see much of the French enemy and attention is unremittingly focused on Aubrey, Maturin and a crew ranging from old salts to barely pubescent midshipmen carrying the weight of officers' duties. It's highly effective.And there are few scenes on land although one is vital to the story. This is a true shipboard movie. From the quarterdeck to the swinging hammocks in an impossibly crammed forecastle, with the almost palpable sweat and smell of sailors jammed in quarters so close as to deny any privacy or dignity, this is a film about men at war. Aubrey, of course, is based on Nelson in reality and Horatio Hornblower in fiction. The C.S. Forester novels about Hornblower, tracing his career from junior rank to admiral and lord, are classics and Gregory Peck did a fine job portraying the character in a much earlier film.What Crowe brings to the screen is a complex character who blends an almost gushing love for his crew with the duty to push them to extremes of endurance and towards the god of battle. Crowe could have totally dominated the film but for Paul Brettany's sensitive portrayal as a doctor and would-be naturalist serving as the skipper's only friend and confidant. His acting makes the story far more engrossing than it otherwise would have been. Aubrey, a violinist, and Maturin, a cellist, make some nice music together too.Historical accuracy? The ship's accouterments, the uniforms, the dreadful quarters for the men, the lingo: a lot of research went into "Master and Commander." Jack Tar was legally entitled (until not very many years ago) to a daily tot of grog, a rum-based beverage that actually served to keep him somewhat servile. Aubrey makes sure that good work is rewarded by extra tots. Great, just what a warship needs-crew members inebriated.Impressment was the main "recruiting" device of the Georgian navy and the men were, no pun intended, a rum lot. Speaking of his soldiers, the Duke of Wellington famously commented that he didn't know if they frightened the enemy but they definitely frightened him. That was even more so of the naval seamen of the time but the crew of Surprise are remarkably healthy, happy, compliant and devoted to their commander. Well, it IS a story.The lash: Aubrey is a humane officer in a navy where most commanders resorted to the lash often, sometimes sparking mutinies from a crew that could endure no more brutalization. But when no other alternative is present, he orders all hands aft to witness punishment. Purists will be disappointed, as I was, to see an ordinary whip used instead of the cat o'nine tails that was the inseparable friend of the Master at Arms.The least accurate portrayal is of the companionship of the captain's cabin where all the officers dine together in good fellowship, their captain tipsy if not fully three sheets to the wind. The wardroom with the commanding officer dining became a staple of the steamship navy. During the Napoleonic Wars, a ship's captain generally kept his distance from his officers and dined (dined? Look at what they're eating.) alone in his cabin at the ship's stern. But that's a minor quibble.Viewers interested in understanding what the Royal Navy of the Anglo-French war was like ought to start with an American's view, Herman Melville's "Billy Budd" (the Benjamin Britten opera of the same name is pretty good too).But this is an audience involving, rousing tale that shouldn't be missed. And it's NOT just for male audiences.But an Oscar contender? Not for me. It's a terrific modern depiction of a story line we've seen in many films. Russell Crowe is entertaining but there's no great depth in his character as there was when he played that tormented genius in "A Beautiful Mind."Wanna bet there'll be a sequel. Perhaps Aubrey, older and of higher rank, will command a squadron landing troops to sack Washington in the War of 1812.8/10
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: Exciting-Definitely; Historically Accurate-Mixed; Oscar Worthy-Not Really

Supposedly responding to an admiral's recitation of the Senior Service's history, the portly First Lord of the Admiralty purportedly responded that the navy's traditions encompassed "rum, sodomy and the lash."  In "Master and Commander," etc., director Peter Weir serves up two of the service's traditions, rum and the lash but inaccurately leaves the sweating, groping, between decks sex life out.Weir with Russell Crowe as Captain Jack Aubrey of HMS Surprise, ably both abetted and challenged by his ship's surgeon, Stephen Maturin, played by Paul Brettany, draws the viewer into a powerful, gripping but somewhat sanitized world of the wooden warship at the height of its power before steam drove the old ships to wrecking yards.Based on the late Patrick O'Brian's very well received series of novels, "Master and Commander" places HMS Surprise in harm's way as Aubrey searches for a powerful French privateer during the Napoleonic Wars. In fact there are no women in the film except for a few seconds when an undoubtedly randy captain gazes briefly at a native woman.HMS Surprise is, unfortunately, surprised at the very beginning of the film when its quarry hits the frigate with powerful broadsides, reducing the escaping-into-the-fog vessel to near helplessness.  Aubrey resolves to make repairs and hunt down the French vessel, a decision that sets the pace for the rest of the film.  Is he acting out of duty or from ego?  A familiar war film issue.Weir cleverly never lets the viewer see much of the French enemy and attention is unremittingly focused on Aubrey, Maturin and a crew ranging from old salts to barely pubescent midshipmen carrying the weight of officers' duties.  It's highly effective.And there are few scenes on land although one is vital to the story. This is a true shipboard movie.  From the quarterdeck to the swinging hammocks in an impossibly crammed forecastle, with the almost palpable sweat and smell of sailors jammed in quarters so close as to deny any privacy or dignity, this is a film about men at war.Aubrey, of course, is based on Nelson in reality and Horatio Hornblower in fiction.  The C.S. Forester novels about Hornblower, tracing his career from junior rank to admiral and lord, are classics and Gregory Peck did a fine job portraying the character in a much earlier film.What Crowe brings to the screen is a complex character who blends an almost gushing love for his crew with the duty to push them to extremes of endurance and towards the god of battle.  Crowe could have totally dominated the film but for Paul Brettany's sensitive portrayal as a doctor and would-be naturalist serving as the skipper's only friend and confidant. His acting makes the story far more engrossing than it otherwise would have been.  Aubrey, a violinist, and Maturin, a cellist, make some nice music together too.Historical accuracy?  The ship's accouterments, the uniforms, the dreadful quarters for the men, the lingo:  a lot of research went into "Master and Commander."  Jack Tar was legally entitled (until not very many years ago) to a daily tot of grog, a rum-based beverage that actually served to keep him somewhat servile.  Aubrey makes sure that good work is rewarded by extra tots.  Great, just what a warship needs-crew members inebriated.Impressment was the main "recruiting" device of the Georgian navy and the men were, no pun intended, a rum lot.  Speaking of his soldiers, the Duke of Marlborough famously commented that he didn't know if they frightened the enemy but they definitely  frightened him.  That was even more so of the naval seamen of the time but the crew of Surprise are remarkably healthy, happy, compliant and devoted to their commander.  Well, it IS a story.The lash:  Aubrey is a humane officer in a navy where most commanders resorted to the lash often, sometimes sparking mutinies from a crew that could endure no more brutalization.  But when no other alternative is present, he orders all hands aft to witness punishment.  Purists will be disappointed, as I was, to see an ordinary whip used instead of the cat o'nine tails that was the inseparable friend of the Master at Arms.The least accurate portrayal is of the companionship of the captain's cabin where all the officers dine together in good fellowship, their captain tipsy if not fully three sheets to the wind.  The wardroom with the commanding officer dining became a staple of the steamship navy.  During the Napoleonic Wars, a ship's captain generally kept his distance from his officers and dined (dined? Look at what they're eating.) alone in his cabin at the ship's stern.  But that's a minor quibble.Viewers interested in understanding what the Royal Navy of the Anglo-French war was like ought to start with an American's view, Herman Melville's "Billy Budd" (the Benjamin Britten opera of the same name is pretty good too).But this is an audience involving, rousing tale that shouldn't be missed. And it's NOT just for male audiences.But an Oscar contender?  Not for me.  It's a terrific modern depiction of a story line we've seen in many films.  Russell Crowe is entertaining but there's no great depth in his character as there was when he played that tormented genius in "A Beautiful Mind."Wanna bet there'll be a sequel.  Perhaps Aubrey, older and of higher rank, will command a squadron landing troops to sack Washington in the War of 1812.8/10.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: Master and Commander: The Far Side of the World: 4/10
Review_body: There is one main reason how you can tell that Master and Commander: The Far Side of the World was originally going to be released in the summer. Not the huge budget or the `special effects', but because of its obscenely long title. Any movie with a colon in its title seems to be big budgeted, mindless movies. Obviously, Fox, Universal, and Miramax didn't think that it was, so instead of releasing it in the summer, they decided to do so in fall, when the Academy would remember it for Oscars. As I was watching it, I was having trouble thinking what Oscars it would hope to win.It wouldn't win best visual effects. It had exactly the effects I have come to expect from Fox and Universal. Universal has always had cheesy effects that weren't believable, which was only added onto by Fox, whose gunshots are just bright yellow lights. I can't believe that Fox needed two major companies to assist with the funding. It certainly didn't show. Some of the shots of the boat on water looked very good, however, but not real in any way.It wouldn't win best cinematography. It seemed like often it was trying to go for something a little different that wouldn't really be noticeable but would have people saying, `Something was different about this movie.' However, for even the easiest of shots to shoot (that were probably even done with second unit), the camera couldn't even stay still. If what they were going for was an amateur feel to the camera work, then they succeeded. Near the end, in the obligatory huge fight scene, the fighting was barely visible. Everything was so quickly cut it was impossible to see what was happening.It wouldn't win best screenplay. Every single character, even the lead, had absolutely no development to them. When Cap'n Jack Aubrey (Russell Crowe) is seen in the beginning, he is writing a letter to his girlfriend to show how lonely he is. However, he neither shows his loneliness nor even references his girlfriend again. People who we don't know anything about suddenly become involved, and it's impossible to tell people apart. And this could be that I'm just not that learned in the history of the British Navy during the Napoleonic era, but why would eight-year-olds be allowed to be in the navy and be allowed to kill various people?It wouldn't win best director. The way Peter Weir directs it is leisurely at some times and haphazardly at others, both at inappropriate times. At the climactic fight scene, Weir is so interested in making sure we know that the British will win, he doesn't bother on the small stuff that is actually important, like being able to tell what is happening! Who is doing what to whom? It's impossible to see. You can't even see who is British and who is French!It wouldn't win best actor. Russell Crowe does his typical shtick, trying to act well to get an Oscar, but he just doesn't work here. The only other semi-large name is Paul Bettany, who starred with Crowe in A Beautiful Mind. See my note for Crowe. All of the other actors were rather invisible; most of their dialogue was just barking orders to and fro. There wasn't really any room for acting.It wouldn't win best actress, mainly because there's only about two in the entire film and are both on screen for a total of five seconds.Lastly, it wouldn't win best picture, mainly because as much as the Academy enjoys long, boring movies, it rarely goes for action movies like Master and Commander tries to be. It had too many subplots, all mainly there for an excuse for the ending `resolution'. Most didn't go anywhere. If they had been taken out, then it could have been a more tolerable length, not this, at an overwhelming two-and-a-quarter hours.If I were to say one redeeming quality of Master and Commander, it would be to say that in the beginning it was quite good, with a good action scene right off of the bat. After that, however, it just seemed like randomly people started to fight and it soon veered off into boredom. The subsequent action scenes aren't good, because I was too bored during the rest to really be entertained by the action, or by the rest of the movie.My rating: 4/10Rated PG-13 for intense battle sequences, related images, and brief language.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: A masterful adventure of a movie
Review_body: Peter Weir's Master and Commander: The Far Side of the World is nothing short of a masterpiece and a wonderful adventure of a movie told with so much detail that people who are watching this movie wouldn't even need to read one of Patrick O'Brian's novel series all because of Weir's and John Collee's great screenplay. The film is one of the best films of it's genre since seeing Raoul Walsh's Captain Horatio Hornblower (1951), the movie is also a detailed character study of British Naval Capt. Jack Aubrey (played by Russell Crowe) and the ship's surgeon Dr. Stephen Maturin (played by Paul Bettany)who also played Crowe's imaginary roommate in A Beautiful Mind (2001), as well as exploring their differences. Aubrey is a great strategist and tactician, and Maturin has a great interest in biology and collecting birds and beetles. Crowe gives one of the best performances of his career, and I was also impressed with Paul Bettany in this movie in a wonderful supporting role in fact to me is also his best performance. This movie has all of the things it needs that an 1800s Naval war movie is supposed to have for example excellent costume design, marvelous fight scenes, wonderful production design. This is one of 2003's best films.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: Best Executed Film I've Ever Seen
Review_body: This is a film I've been waiting for quite sometime since I heard Peter Weir going to make it. And it turns out to be even better than I thought. It is truly is flawless and probably one of the best execute film I have ever seen.Base upon two books of twenty, Master and Commander and The Far Side of the World is about friendship and the history during the Napoleon era. What I like about the movie is projecting the lives of the sailor during that time. The Script is brilliantly written, they definitely have done they homework on researching because it is accurate and very insightful. The directing is too good to describe by words. Plus, the casting and the dedication of each and every actor on the ship can be seen in the movie.Overall it is masterfully done movie, though some of the things in movie might not be up to every body liking. Like the story might be a little predictable and absolutely no female in the movie, which in the way very accurate indeed but very kind of weird cinematically. And the movie is a little slow with and the used of old English might not be easy for some viewer.Recommendation: Brilliantly Done, Look Out For Behind the Scenes  Excellent Work.Rating: 8/10 (Grade: A-) Thanks For Reading
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: I have to say I really like this movie. It has a great story, great acting,great visuals and great directing. It will keep you glued to the screen from the moment it starts. Kick back and pop open a few brewskies and watch a fantastic movie...
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: "Master and Commander" is a movie that feels and looks like a spectacular show. a marvelous play. The art direction and set decoration are what make this movie so fabulous and what make it look like a show. The plot is interesting and the story reminds a "cat and mouse" game. What I felt was completely wasted was the ending. No spoilers but if you watch the ending you realize you've wasted two hours of your life that will never come back. I've watched the movie and felt cheated by the way it ended, a cheap way to end a story, what a disappointment. only for that kind of ending I think the movie was bad. At least the actors were good.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: A well mounted film based on a series of books, this one has Russell Crowe as a British sea captain durring the Napoleon wars dealing with a French ship and various other shipboard problems. Does a good job of capturing the atmosphere of being on one of those ships and the acting performances all keep you involved in the ship and its crew. The battle scenes are also well staged. A fairly impressive movie over all. GRADE: A-
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: GOOD MOVIE - A LITTLE TO LONG
Review_body: Russel Crowe was excellent, in this sea story.  The rest of the cast was more than adequate.  The battle scenes were very good, but the story bogged down in between the battles.  The special effects also were done very well. Go see this 2 1/2 hour spectacle, it is worth the price of admission.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: In the last few months I have been in a phase where good and great movies just came pouring in from countless places and it's been a wonderful experience. But "Master And Commander" tops the chart! Why? Because it was the most enjoyable and powerful of them all. Because it had an impeccable cast that drove the movie all the way through.(Mr. Crowe being his usual self in the best possible way and the incredible Paul Bettany who gives the movie a Darwinistic and humane tone). Because it had an incredible enseble working on its score, cinematography, costumes, editing and especially detailed presentation of that time. Because it had dialogues that had something, no, a lot to say. And because it was just so bloody brilliant. My favorite moment: when Dr. Stephen Maturin stumbles upon his so-seeked out bird and catches the French ship closing in. With the surrounding music, camera and atmosphere it created one of the most perfect movie moments I have ever seen. The only flaw I can remember was the casting of Billy Boyd who should either had more screen time or either been replaced with an unknown actor. I more than understand people who will and have found "Master And Commander" tedious or perhaps arguably uneventful, because the people who will enjoy it the most are people who know a little bit about naval customs and happenings in those days and who will appreciate it especially for that. This movie is more than just a regular revival of a  seaman movie, it is an excellent documentary of days when British fleets fought with the French and it ends in such a manner. Perhaps unfinished to some, to me it was perfect. Peter Weir, kudos to your directing skills, they have proven you to be Hollywood's very own and true Master and Commander.  9/10
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: Deserves more credit, praise and remembrance
Review_body: Master and Commander: The Far Side of the World is one mouthful of a title, but a gloriously entertaining adventure of epic proportions, documenting a ship of the Royal British Navy and its captain during the Napoleonic Wars. Captain Aubrey (Russel Crowe) and his sailors have been ordered to sink or capture the superior French vessel and all of the sea is their battlefield. You feel the weight of such a challenging task at all times and this acts as a device to get us to really sympathize with, and pull for, our British heroes as they struggle at sea. This is a magnificent, beautifully shot and crafted war-drama and best of all, it features no love interests in its plot to distract and detract from the realism of the adventure -- but is a straightforward portrayal of events, as based on the novels by Patrick O'Brien. It is simply genius not to cast some annoying supporting actress running around in a corset and acting as a loved one. Finally, a war-drama that gets it right! In terms of action on-board the ship, this is near-perfection and what Pirates of the Caribbean should have been like; it is gritty, realistic, exciting and sprinkled with a fine dose of humour to balance its dark war themes and the hardships that one may face on a ship.Because Master and Commander is an adventure film, it is also fairly forgettable -- I hate to admit it, but it's true. There is, however, one thing that's stuck with me from the film and that is the visit to the Gallapagos Islands. These few scenes are really gripping and powerful and the bizarre setting of this island creates a strange, almost haunting effect. It acts as a pause in the otherwise fast pace on-board the ship. I truly feel that this film deserves more credit, praise and remembrance.8.5/10
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: Two bases short of a home run
Review_body: MASTER AND COMMANDER is not a bad movie, and sadly it is not a good movie.I was hoping MASTER & COMMANDER would be GLADIATOR on the high seas. Maximus Decimus Meridas, Commanding General of the Army of the North, now becomes the intense, focused leader of 197 souls aboard a heroic fighting ship!But all of this is missing.  The screenplay, direction, and the total lack of dramatic music torpedo this first voyage of the mighty HMS Surprise.General Maximus Decimus Meridas did not have time for fiddle concerts.  The Gladiator did not swap jokes and get drunk with the boys.  Violin playing Captain Aubrey seems overly distracted while drinking his way across the oceans.  Master & Commander lacks steady intensity.  When the subplot about natural science begins, the movie stops dead.  When the subplot about the jinxed officer begins, the movie stops dead.  When the subplot about the ship's busy-body doctor's operation begins, the movie stops dead.  The audience is left with far too much spare time.In MASTER, a swear word not allowed on TV is spoken one time.  Crusty sailors fight battles against the enemy, and fight with each other.  There is a flogging.  The older sailors yearn for pretty girls on the distant shore, etc.  The salty words spoken are clean enough for TV.  Then, the one loan swear word is uttered, and it stands out badly... "Wait folks, here is our required PG-13 moment, @&!$@#, OK, now on with the movie."Take a look at the GLADIATOR -- see the Roman Legions, the Praetoriae, the Felix Regiment, the Centuria -- no kids are seen in military service. Likewise, MASTER & COMMANDER should not be the adventures of Peter Pan. What is believable about the English Navy employing 10 year-olds as officers?  It is difficult to believe that hardened 30 year-old sailors would follow the orders of a little kid who is given command.  What is with all of the kids in MASTER?  Burt Lancaster had no need for little kids aboard his glorious pirate ship.  Captain Kirk was the better for not having to share command with 10 year-olds.  Finally, the most dramatic theme music ever made comes from epic sailing movies and big budget space operas.  Although there is some sparse drumming and some light classical music occasionally, Master & Commander is devoid of true theme music.  MASTER & COMMANDER badly needs a powerful dramatic film score.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: It blew me away. Peter Weir crafts an immensely compelling, superbly acted sea-faring epic that does an impeccable job of making the audience feel as if they are shut up in a ship in the middle of the ocean. This ongoing battle with the mysterious phantom ship is a great device for some of the best action sequences I've ever seen, but the best aspects of the film is when they aren't in battle. It's the relationships between these complex characters that create the most engaging scenes and highlight the absolutely incredible performances from the entire cast, primarily Russell Crowe and the always underrated Paul Bettany. They both deserved Oscar-nods, as far as I'm concerned. The complexity of the ships friendships, leaderships and characters is some of the most well-written work of the decade. Just superb in every single way.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: An authentic tale from the high seas
Review_body: Sense of duty. Love of country. As seen in the epic 'Master and Commander: The Far Side of the World,' these are principles by which the crew of the HMS Surprise lived (and died). The film was a big budget oceanic blockbuster that debuted right around the time of the much more popular 'Pirates of the Caribbean: The Curse of the Black Pearl,' but found a much older crowd due to the subject matter.Russell Crowe was perhaps one of the better options for casting the role of Captain Jack Aubrey, as he authentically seems like someone who would wash up on the shores of the Galapagos Islands. In 'Commander,' Crowe feels right at home, leading a rag-tag British naval crew around the coast of South America. What makes the film work is the narrow focus on a specific mission rather than a long, drawn out series of tales from the high seas that would have been too much to digest. Instead, we get to know the characters fairly well, including Paul Bettany's part-time surgeon, part-time zoologist. This allows us to actually care about what happens to them over the course of their adventures.'Commander' also benefits from great special effects, with plenty of well thought out action sequences that were all the rage in the early 2000s. Films that take place at sea can be hit or miss, but the setting works well in this instance.'Master and Commander: The Far Side of the World' is not the most exciting story ever told, but it's executed flawlessly and should be regarded as a master class in period action-adventure films.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: A great adventurous venture during the Napoleonic times !! A must watch
Review_body: A great screenplay and direction by Peter Weir, Master and commander: The far side of the world is a depiction of a constant endeavour of a captain Jack Aubrey (Russell Crowe) to destroy a French enemy frigate during the time of Napoleonic Wars, thus putting the lives of the entire crew in jeopardy for vengeance as well as for the sake of his country.During his crazy will to take on the Acheron, the enemy Frigate, Jack is often contradicted by his closest friend, the doctor Stephen Maturin (Paul Bettany) and albeit he never gives up the hope of invading the French frigate, he is constantly put in adverse situations wherein he is compelled to feel remorseful for the decisions he made. However he manages to keep the faith of his crew members alive and pursues the Acheron without giving an eye to the doctor's concern and interests. A series of unfortunate events occur and their ship suffers bad luck every now and then but that doesn't stop Jack from taking on the Acheron eventually.Some great acting by Russell Crowe and Paul Bettany makes the whole movie an adventure worth watching. The situations that they were put in certainly demanded pluck and patience which was manifested well by Jack Aubrey.This flick would make you fathom how things were really dealt with earlier. Back then when the technology wasn't advanced enough, how sails were used by the crew and how much work was supposed to be done during a shipwreck.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: Instead of a blood, war film (Troy, Alexander) which get boring after a while, Master and Commander keeps you hooked until the very end. Although not entirely accurate, this may be one of the best Naval films made (although I don't know how many naval films have been made). Taking place during the Napoleonic Wars, Capt. Jack Aubrey (Russel Crowe) is under the service of the British crown and chasing the Royal French Warship Acheron who attacked them off the coast of South America. Capt. Jack sets off on an unbelievable quest to capture the invincible Acheron which is heading for the Pacific Ocean. Along the command of Capt. Jack's men is a crew of laughter, hatred, and interest. The ships doctor, Stephen Maurin (Paul Bettany) is also a moral supervisor and a very good friend of the Captain. Along the way, Jack pushes his men too the limits from enduring a week long dry spell to ordering the death of a crew mate to save the ship. The battles are spread out enough for the drama and plot to unfold and present themselves. The ship is beautiful and was actually built for the film. Russell Crowe is magnificent and Paul Bettany holds his own along with him. The crew is fun to watch, when you don't even know their names you feel for them and feel as if you're a cabin mate with them. The film is a bit long, stretching 2 1/2 hours but is well worth it. The film is not all historically accurate but if I wanted a history lesson, I'd read a history book. The film is visually stunning and about 90% is filmed on the open ocean. The effects are wonderful and the plot above average.Master and Commander: The Far Side Of The World. Starring: Russell Crowe, Paul Bettany, Billy Boyd, James D'Arcy, and Max Pirkis.4 out of 5 Stars.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: This film brings history to life in a way few movies do. Set in 1805, the movie follows a British ship led by Captain Jack Aubry (Russell Crowe) in pursuit of one of Napoleon's fleet. Whether it was the accuracy of Patrick O'Brien's novels or Director Peter Weir's devotion to detail in his recreation of life at sea, I felt as if I were on the ship myself. I might have also felt this way because of the film's unwavering vision to its subjects rather than conventional Hollywood storytelling. For example, in a story set at sea, we would naturally be looking forward to seeing exciting naval battles. While we do get our share of exciting naval action, we mostly experience the HMS Surprise, where every minute of the movie takes place, spending their time waiting and trying to maintain their sanity so that when a battle actually does come, you realize the magnitude of it. The human element of the movie, of course, is the multi-layered relationship between Crowe and Bettany, a duo seen before in Beautiful Mind that does not disappoint
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: Master and Commander: The Far Side of the WorldStarring: Russell CroweRated PG-13 for Intense Battle Sequences, War Violence and Brief LanguageGenre: Action/Adventure/Drama/WarStar Rating: ****1/2 out of 5Another great movie where the wonderful Russell Crowe delievers another great performance. During the Napoleonic Wars, a British frigate, HMS Surprise, and a much larger French warship, the Acheron, with greater fire power, stalk each other off of the coast of South America. Russell Crowe brings great intensity to the role of Captain Jack Aubrey. Lucky Jack, as he is referred to by his crew, is well regarded by his men, who trust him implicitly, even after the first devastating battle and an apparent personal vendetta against the French captain. While the naval battle sequences are quite fantastic, the film is successful because director Weir chose to build the story to get to know the men who are locked aboard the tight quarters of a small ship and how they interact everyday. The officers and the mates are well-known by the time the final battle comes. This was a well done movie with great adventure and thrills! This movie won two academy awards for best cinematography and best sound editing and it was also nominated for best picture, makeup, editing, director, costume design, sound and visual effects. I thought that Russell Crowe should have been nominated for best actor in this movie!BOTTOM LINE: GREAT!
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: A delightful, tragic, moving, exciting and daring adventure
Review_body: Not since Gregory Peck in "Captain Horatio Hornblower" in the 1950's have I been taken with a film about the sea, and in particular about the British navy. What is there not to like about this film. There is not a single weak performance in the film, and there are several that stand out. Russell Crowe almost makes you want to join his crew, even under the horrific conditions that prevailed in that time period. Paul Bettany plays the part of the doctor with great sensitivity which contrasts beautifully with his role as Silas in "The Da Vinci Code." Especially captivating is young Max Pirkis as Lord Blakeney, the young midshipman who is obviously admired by all of the crew. And the performances go on and on. It is an adventure story, but also one that tests the boundaries between friendship and devotion to duty. The music that underscores the film is magnificent including a portion of Ralph Vaughn-Williams "Fantasia on the theme of Thomas Tullis" which is a quintessential piece of English composition, and one that I had wondered why had not been used in a film soundtrack before?I only regret that there has been no mention of a sequel, since the film left the door wide open for one.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: Wrong Revolution, Wrong Red White and Blue
Review_body: Master and Commander brings to the screen Pat O'Brien's epic of Captain 'Lucky' Jack Aubrey's (Russel Crowe's) hunt for the privateer Acheron. Russell Crowe renders a bravura performance in the swashbuckling role of Lucky Jack's exploits in the Napoleonic era wars. There's a Captain Kirkish charm and a star-trek tingle in Lucky Jack's adventurism but there's a serious side too. Captain Jack teaches a middling mid - shipman who constantly fails the test for Lieutenant that a leader is neither a martinet nor a friend to the crew.The movie is set against the background of the Napoleonic Wars. But it derives from a book in which the swashbuckling Captain Jack unleashes his furies on a different Red White and Blue flown by a different cast of Revolutionaries. Americans lacking Britannic objectivity might not flock to the cinema to watch their lads blasted out of the water through ruses de guerre worthy of themselves.Yet the script is so well written that there are many hints from which a keen observer can penetrate the stand - in foe.Hollywood made the French, America's ally in 1776 and co-belligerent in 1812,the feared and resourceful enemy. In 1812 the US picked the wrong moment to jump into the Napoleonic Wars on the losing side. The US tried the fast and lose tactics of the privateers, pirates hired by Congress, in the Revolution without much of the former successes. The Regular US Navy under commanders like Perry and Decatur however did make its mark.The US was nearly over-run by the British with the collapse of Napoleon's regime. Fortunately General Andy Jackson humiliated Sir Edward Pakenham at New Orleans ending the war as positively as it could. Too bad Sir Edward didn't have Lucky Jack with him. Civilisation might have been restored to North America.Britons do not live in memory of past glories when the chips are down as much as Americans do. The Hollywoodization of Patrick O'Brien's sea tale of Captain Jack Aubrey's pursuit of the privateer Acheron had to be toned down for US audiences. The movie only alludes to America as Britain's enemy; with a fresh coat of an alternative or variant Red White and Blue (Bleu, Blanche et Rouge) donates the Acheron to the cause of a different Revolution.There is a Captain Kirkish charm to Russell Crowe's performance and his relationship with the ship's surgeon approaches that of the gritting comradeship of Captain Kirk and Dr Spock.There's some swashbuckling adventure, some exploring the universe and some amateur psychology to merit the accolade 'The Star Trek on the high seas.' Otherwise the story is a formula war story played in cockney.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: Fantastic Old Fashioned Style Action Movie
Review_body: The movie is set in the early 1800's during the Napoleonic Wars when Britains Royal Navy really did rule the waves. In essence the story revolves around Russell Crowe as the Commander of a Royal Navy Frigate and his crew in pursuit of a French Frigate across the worlds oceans. Despite the lists of "goofs" mentioned in other reviews. The errors are extremely minor and unless you are the most perfectionist of a maritime historian they will not adveresely impact on your viewing experience. In fact, for a Hollywood movie, it is surprisingly true to life in its portrayal of the Royal Navy at that time. The film is a classic action movie in the truest tradition of Hollywood. The film is grounded in a good story. The action is intense and holds your attention. There is some violence but it is in keeping with the story and the action. The violence is neither gory or portrayed just to shock and awe. Not wishing to sound sexist this movie is fun for men of all ages. Age 5 to 105. Possibly the odd girl or two but I don't think this movie would be liked by women.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: Peter Weir's early-19th century sea drama (based on the work of beloved writer Patrick O'Brien) feels like a movie that has no real beginning or end--it's as if you've been dropped into the middle of an eight hundred page novel and that the story being told is perhaps more of a subplot. Actually, it seems surprising that there's a plot at all--the novelty in this day and age of a project about early-19th century seafaring is certainly odd enough to forego a storyline. Weir himself appears to recognize the novelty and spends a lot of his time doting on the ship's stateliness or detailing the inhabitants' everyday world (much of which seems to have been lost in the cutting room; there's a scattershot feel to the picture, as if there were too many digressions to fit). Russell Crowe plays the hero, Captain Jack Aubrey, as he chases a French vessel around the South American coast during the Napoleonic era. Crowe plays it safe here--he's on the verge of becoming the new Harrison Ford, a colorless hero who's traded his acting chops for audience adulation. This being a Weir film, there has to be some kind of class warfare and the simmering, antagonistic relationship between the ship's crew and their officers (most of whom are adolescent aristocrats) is examined, although only in fits and starts. (In one of the film's more ethereal moments, one of the young officers is actually driven to suicide.) But Weir somewhat confusingly co-opts his normally sympathetic views of the working class by making Crowe's character loved blindly by his men, a champion they pledge undying loyalty for, even though his obsessions put his crew in harm's way more often than not. Though it's difficult to shake the film's slightness and its lack of focus--it's hard to figure out what it's about, really--it's still worthwhile: in spite of its aspiration to epic greatness, it does manage to retain a sense of intimacy that allows for plenty of opportunities to take it all in and simply observe.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: Let's see...ocean based adventure, lone underdogs up against a superior force, all the chips are down and the fate of the world's at stake, hard push for plausibility through exposition of minute detail, elaborate hornswogglings, lead actor guided somewhat by hubris...yes, it's "Waterworld" all over again.The big difference is that with Crowe at least we get a compelling hero. He knows how to place himself in this; for those reasons I rate this in the 6-10 end (for me, that means 'watchable') of the site's rating scale.This is plainly driven by the "Lord of the Rings" effect of the need for a massive, massive structure that contains every bit of period minutiae of which one can conceive. And it's a bit tiresome.It's bested in every way by, for example, "The Name of the Rose", which in addition to period-correct detail, actually uses the visual narrative to play a game with the viewer, as opposed to merely laying out book-based imagery.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: One of the most realistic period movies ever
Review_body: From its outlook you could expect something good, even if a bit strange: Peter Weir running a seafaring movie, which from its trailer promised to be a gripping and exciting adventure through the seas of the early 19th century? But the trailer was lying. The movie is much more than just the adventures of Cpt. Jack Aubrey on board the HMS Suprise. This movie is made from the very same fabric it displays on screen, a fabric of sweat, salt water, heat, cold and storms. A fabric of moral and human fiber, a fabric of people's senses and feelings. The biggest suprise of this crafted and superb movie is that it sticks to the human values, and brings back that feeling of old movies, before the explosion of CGI created new worlds and destroyed many others. In fact, the computer-generated elements in this movie are so rare and detailed that you'll not notice them and even if you do, you'll forget that they are not real. This movie is realistic to every woodchip that flies under the cannon charges and every bit of cloth these characters wear. Add to it a commanding presence by Russel Crowe, decent supporting characters and a superb sound construction and you'll have one of the finest movies of the year, and a sure bet to the oscars (it's produced by Miramax, you know).
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: I have never read the series of books upon which this film is inspired, but hopefully they are infinitely more rousing than what translates to the screen in this endeavor. The film opens well enough and nicely establishes the rigors and hardships of life at sea on a British vessel during the Napoleonic Wars. Unfortunately, it does not go anywhere after that establishment. The remainder of the film is basically a drawn-out cat-and-mouse game in trying to avoid/confront an enemy vessel while navigating around South America. With the exception of three characters, all of the British seamen blend together and have no distinctive personalities. I swore the character played by Billy Boyd was killed at least three times only to pop up later unharmed making this viewer realize that it was just someone similar and equally forgettable who met their tragic end. Max Perkis stands out as young boy who loses his arm in the opening battle. Russell Crowe packed on substantial weight to take on the role of Captain Jack Aubrey, but one wonders at the effort since the role is a relatively straightforward one of a stiff-upper-lip British sea captain essayed as well, if not better, in a least a dozen superior films. Paul Bettany is exceptional as the boat's surgeon and the film really becomes interesting whenever he is on screen. His side trip to explore the indigenous life on the Galapagos Islands is a nice passage. The remainder of the crew are instantly forgettable and at large unsympathetic. A subplot where the superstitious crew hounds a young crewmen to his death because they blame him for the bad luck and weather plaguing them makes them even less appealing. The fact that the captain seems to support their stand is probably believable, but hardly inspires confidence in his abilities. Even worse, the movie seems to halfway buy into the superstitious stance, which is reprehensible. After the initial battle, the few remaining battle sequences become increasingly repetitious and boring. We learn little to nothing about the enemy vessel, and with a horde of unsympathetic seadogs on the British vessel, it is difficult to become emotionally involved in the outcome. Film is entirely too long and flaccidly paced. It actually concludes in the middle of a pursuit, but it seems unlikely anyone will care about the ultimate outcome. It incredibly received a number of Oscar nominations, but no major wins. To its credit, it does convey one major aspect of life at sea to the viewer  unending torpor.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: This movie is a superb recreation of life aboard a warship at the time of the Napoleonic wars, the scurvy crew pressed unwillingly into service, the overcrowed vessel, the dreadful food, the storms, the battles, the tedium - but where was the most necessary crew member, the ship's cat?  This cat had two jobs, keeping down the rats and giving the men a pet. One picky little detail in an otherwise excellent film.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: I'm not a huge fan of Russell Crowe but when it came to 'Master and Commander: The Far Side of the World', I was able to put aside his thuggish behaviour in real-life as I was swept away by the excellence of the film and his brilliant depiction as valiant Captain Jack Aubrey.I haven't read any of the Patrick O'Brien novels, on which this film is based upon, but I imagine most fans of his work will be pleased by this adaptation as it's clear much effort has gone into preserving details, from the close fraternal bond between Aubrey and the ship's physician Marutin to the depiction of the tactics used to win in battle to the child crew who serve aboard the ship. You truly felt as if the grit, harshness and simplicity of the era were captured in this film and it is easy to be swept away in Aubrey's determination to destroy the French ship that dared to attack him and his crew.The cast were all wonderful in their roles. Crowe was able to shrug off his brutish behaviour to depict Aubrey as a stubborn, intelligent officer and gentleman who lived for Britain. Paul Bettany was perfect as the quiet, reserved Marutin who cared for his close friend Aubrey and all the men he tended to in his duties as doctor. The supporting cast, a number of whom were newcomer British child actors, also proved themselves and gave this film depth in the way they portray their characters as a tight-knit crew who rely very much on each other and would die for their captain and country.A must-see film, especially for the British as there is never been such a film that will leave you feeling proud to be a Briton. It reminds you that you don't have to be a football hooligan/BNP racist/chav to feel patriotic.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: I think this movie should have at least 10 Academy Award nominations. This is a great movie.  Not only is it exciting in the battle scenes, but the sailors on the ship are seen to be human beings.  They are not just crew taking up space.  I hope this movie gets Russell Crowe another Oscar.  He won for Gladiator, but should've won for A Beautiful Mind.  See this movie as many times as you can.  10/10
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: Review - Master and Commander : The Far Side of the World
Review_body: Master and Commander is a movie that at the perfect time, just at the pinnacle of Russel Crowe's career and in a golden age for adventure films. And, I like that movie as much as I love nautical adventures.For me, the only flaw that justifies my 7/10 is the editing of the action scenes. In most of his films, Nolan was able to camouflage Lee Smith's inability to edit action, but Peter Weir couldn't on Master and Commander.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body:
This film is destined to be regarded as a masterpiece of historical accuracy of British naval life and sailing vessels of its time -- roughly 1803.
It tells a story -- not a particularly compelling one in the sense of, say, "The Sixth Sense."  It's absolutely in the slice of life genre although spiced by the action of some storms and battle scenes.
So those who want a narrative to hook them, to fascinate and rivet them, are not as likely to enjoy this film.  Those who enjoy understanding what people in other times and places experienced, those with an interest in sailing and history, e.g., the British Navy, historical vessels, those familiar with Darwin's later voyage on the "Beagle" in the 1830s, etc., will be far more than amply rewarded. Fifty, or perhaps even one hundred years from now, I suspect this film will be still be used and viewed for its accuracy in historical depiction.I'm a long-time sailor, also interested in Darwin, evolution, the history of naval life and vessels, and a retired therapist.  I thoroughly enjoyed its impeccable accuracy in portraying the life and values of the time.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: Master and Commander is somewhat an enigma in terms of enjoyable films: whilst it is not an inherently interesting plot (a British vessel pursuing a French battleship around the coasts of South America during the Napoleonic Wars), this film is well-acted and visually strong, so is excellent viewing if you don't want to take what you're watching too seriously.Master and Commander plays somewhat on the underdog story of a weaker British crew trying to foil a superior opposition, but there are numerous subplots along the way. The steely Captain Jack Aubrey (Russell Crowe) is single-mindedly focused on destroying the French threat, causing a clashing of heads with his closest friend, naturalist-turned-medic Stephen Maturin (played by Paul Bettany, one of my favourite actors in the earliest role I saw him in). By convincing Maturin to engage in the pursuit (on the pretence that he will be able to conduct pioneering scientific research), the crew begin a voyage across the Earth. These two characters steal the show, and their dynamic relationship provides the drama outside of the conflicts with the French.As a period piece, the set and costume design is meticulous, paying close attention to subtleties of the era, bolstered by the entertaining naval battle scenes featured throughout. Master and Commander is exciting from start to finish, and is a low-investment film to watch whatever your mood.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: I couldn't wait to see this film so I went today.  I found the story a little weak, but everything else was perfect.  Taken from the novel by Patrick O'Brien with screenplay and direction by Peter Weir, it is an enthralling battle-weary story of the French & English NapoleonicWar, and the desires of the captain and ship surgeon to discover new life and adventure in the Galapagos Islands.  Photography is fantastic and music is loud and emphatic to keep you on the edge of your seats.  The acting is very impressive.  9/10
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: Historically accurate, but Weir forgot to sign it
Review_body: For a great technical achievement this is at least worth renting. For the unsurprising story however one may look elsewhere. Russel Crowe turns out much better than feared, actually he fit quite well. The other was all quite characterless, except for the doctor who was OK, but maybe too "reasonable" for this voyage. I can easily understand his motivation for the "Darwin voyage" to the Galapagos, but he didn't go quite well as the warrior. As a pacifist, why would he enroll on a war ship? The ship was cramped and dirty, and it had a realistic atmosphere. So was the chaos during the sieges realistically shown. We get to see things exclusively from the ships viewpoint often impressively photographed. But as this is a Peter Weir I would want more in terms of inventiveness and character.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: After viewing this film I had mixed feelings on it. The effects and sound in this film are incredibly enjoyable. The acting was very well done and everything seemed authentic. I feel like this film could have had a shorter runtime. Some scenes could have been made shorter. As some parts in the film seemed to drag on a bit.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: I had heard wonderful things about this film, yet wasn't sure I'd enjoy it, but I was delighted to find that it was an interesting movie and quite thought provoking.  Russell Crowe and Paul Bettany were a pleasure to watch, but so were the supporting actors...in particular, I thought the children were fantastic actors!  I loved the attention to detail ...it is obvious that the art/set designers, whomever they might be (sorry that I am too lazy to look it up) did a great  amount of research.  The music was superb...I always love to hear that Bach cello suite! Of the 3 oscar nominees I have seen (still need to see LOTR and Mystic River), this was my favorite.  I liked Lost in Translation, but it was a bit depressing...this one was not.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: I thought this was a very good seafaring story; with the right mix of personality, action, humour and drama to make a very well-rounded play.I must admit I haven't read the books, but this film actually reminded me of the Doring-Kindersly CD-rom "Stowaway". Everything was just the way I imagined it, from the marines to the powder monkeys.I can't tell why seafaring stories are doing so well now, but we're certainly rediscovering classic cinema storytelling at its grandest. Russell Crowe even had a keen version of the classic matinée rugged hero about him, much like Clark Gable or Robert Mitchum or someone. He and Paul Bettany do play off each other very well, as demonstrated with the earlier A BEAUTIFUL MIND. And the up-and-coming young turks hold their own in this story as well. Particularly Max Pirkis, Billy Boyd (of LOTR fame), and the doomed midshipman played by Lee Ingleby.Great story, very well told. It made my top 100.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: This movie has a rating of 7,5 at the IMDb ranking. That is just so wrong, believe me. I don't know why it got it, but maybe it's for it's epic story or something like that. Anyway, if you expect lots of good action, then you'll be really disappointed. There aren't much action in the movie, and the action that takes place isn't really exciting. The movie is more about telling a rather boring story of the life on board a British warship in the Napoleonic Wars. There are also a subplot in the movie that should have been cut from the movie, as it wasn't interesting at all. If you would like to see a movie/TV-series about life at sea in the Napoleonic Wars, I would really recommend the Horatio Hornblower-series starring Ioan Gruffudd instead. That is much more exciting, has more action, better actors and a much more interesting storyline than this boring mess.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body:
Even though is quite long, the (over) two hours go in an entertaining way.
The movie shows mostly how the sailors live and fight in the ship, not much more happens there, and there are few scenes on land.
Cast and characters are good, but I didn't feel anything took enough intensity to be great and I didn't feel moved or shocked or impressed at any point of the movie.
Cinematography wasn't anything special neither, and few scenes looked impressive or specially beautiful.
Story is quite simple and doesn't evolve much throughout, it actually ends like it would loop over and over again.
I have to say it's a good movie, it didn't bore me, but I found nothing special on it to stand out.
For a big production like this, it could have been better.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: It is excellent in every way!
Review_body: Scheduled for release on June 6, studio heads at Fox, Miramax and Universal decided to wait on releasing `Master and Commander' in the fall rather than the summer to give it Oscar consideration. I would not call it the best film of 2003. However, it is an instant classic! Why? Peter Weir's direction, of course. The man knows how to take a story and play it out on the screen with excellent characterization, visual effects, acting, music and set design. When it all comes together, `Master and Commander' is made with such perfection and dignity, that it far exceeds anything in its genre. 	`Master and Commander' tells the story of British Naval Captain Jack Aubrey (Russell Crowe) and his voyage during the Napoleonic Wars. Along with a crew of 197 men, including Aubrey's best friend and the ship's surgeon Stephen Maturin (Paul Bettany), the crew set out to discover different species and lands in the Pacific Ocean. But that all changes when a French vessel fires upon their ship. Crippled at sea but under repair, Aubrey's ship sets out on a journey to find and destroy the French ship. Along the way, the men will battle a search for inner courage and will be forced to face odds they never dreamed possible. 	This film is made on such a grand scale, but when analyzed, there is nothing that has not been done before-except for the immense detail that no other film like it has done before. In the opening scene when Aubrey's ship is fired upon, they are floating in dense fog and can not see the enemy. When the ship emerges from the fog and they fire a second time, huge plumes of smoke can be seen emanating from the French ship's cannons. When the cannons strike the British ship, the damage is immense. We see the wood splinter, we see men get injured, we see the sails break down. The camera captures these shots in amazing clarity and furthermore, in real time.	Weir's direction is outstanding! The director of such wonderful films as `Fearless' and `The Truman Show' has gathered a cast that fits the film like a glove. Crowe is superb as the courageous and fearless Captain Aubrey. What better choice than Crowe when you consider his countenance as he appears dignified yet cordial to his men. Bettany's performance proves what an admirable actor he is. He also starred with Crowe in `A Beautiful Mind' as John Nash's imaginary friend Charles Herman. Here, his character Maturin is both a trusted friend of Aubrey's and the voice of reason when the goings get tough on the open sea. 	`Master and Commander: The Far Side of the World' is based on the novel by Patrick O'Brian. Weir, along with John Collee, have created a screenplay that details so much about the ship and the characters on board. We get to know a few of the men on board, from a gallant boy named Blakeney (Max Pirkis) to a cowardly Midshipman named Hollom (Lee Ingleby). Their character development is light enough where Weir does not waste film time on them, but satisfies the audience's interest in the characters. Also, look out for Billy Boyd as one of the ship's Coxswain named Barrett Bonden. It is hard to imagine him playing anything other than the hobbit Pippin in `Lord of the Rings.' 	In the end, one can not help but appreciate this film. It is excellent in every way. Moreover, it is not encumbered with unnecessary action sequences or absurdities. ****
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: Seriously, I am picky and even my favorite films I can think of a few things I'd change here and there, a scene or actor doesn't quite work.This one on the other hand is perhaps perfect in every way. It is hard to go on in more detail without giving equal weight to everything, so it would taken 10,000 words to give it full justice.Perfect script, great acting, and apparently every character had a backstory as they all act appropriately and uniquely - as people do - in every situation, for the entire running time.Photography is flawless without being showy, or distracting. Effects are... impossible. Absolutely convincing at every step. I guess they went back in time to film it and actually fought the French and killed actors. I have even been on the ship they used and I don't know how they did it.And on, and on.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: I couldn't give an objective review of this movie if I tried. I own it, I love it, I watch it at least once a month, and I still want to crawl inside the world it creates and live there. The technical team that created the material environment of this film deserve all the awards that they can carry home. The glimpses of everyday life on board a tallship never cease to be fascinating, and each and every viewing reveals another missed detail. All the cast are exceptional, not least Crowe and Bettany, who create real characters of true warmth, integrity and charisma.If I ever won the lottery I would build myself an IMAX screen just so I could watch this movie on it all day. Brilliant.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: The Best Epic of the Year
Review_body:
My Rating: ***1/2 out of ****. Return of the King may have just won the Golden Globe for Best Picture-Drama but I find Master and Commander to be superior. ROTK may be the more visually stunning film, although Master certainly has some breathtaking visuals. However, Master and Commander is just a little better to me.
I have noticed that some people were disappointed by Master and Commander and its done poor at the box office (Made 84 million with a 150 million dollar budget). Those people were expecting another Pirates of the Carribean. I know they were disappointed because this is undoubtedly the superior film. Pirates is fun because of some of the action, while there is action in Master and Commander it is much more character-oriented. The film moves at a slower place to allow time for character development and interaction. Master and Commander was on a high budget and it shows in every scene. The visual effects are flawless. The films two big battle scenes are crafted with an undeniable skill. The typhoon is flawless looking. The ships are also flawless. Master and Commander is a stunning looking movie but the visual effects are not the film. There is a good deal of costume and make up too. The scenes at the Galapados(Spelling?) Islands are beautifully photographed.  The acting is also strong. Russell Crowe turns in a fantastic performance. Crowe has an undeniable screen presence and its more on display in this film than Gladiator. However, matching Crowe's performance is Paul Bettany. I have always noticed the actor in supporting roles and found him to be scene-stealing. But Bettany does much more acting here. His performance is not as showy as Crowe's but it equals it.  Peter Weir maintains tight control over the film. Once you strip away the visual effects, you will immediate see this is the kind of character-driven film Weir does best. However, Weir never lets the visual effects overwhelm the film. Weir has crafted the best Epic film of the year and one of the overall best films of the year.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: This movie fell flat and for only one reason. There was no element of danger involved in the telling of the story. It was billed as an adventure/drama/thriller of a sea story and it just wasn't there. At all. Crowe, a fantastic actor, is left hanging with a plot that isn't gripping and a movie that doesn't supply enough action to keep its viewers attention. Had they added the necessary suspense into this it would have been a slam dunk. But they didn't. So it doesn't go anywhere but do laps around the ocean like the Flying Dutchman. I hope there isn't a sequel and if there is I won't go to see it. Give this film a pass and leave it on the shelf.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: Visually beautiful though a little tedious
Review_body: Russell Crowe plays the captain of a British ship circa 1750 on the hunt for the formidable french man-a-war Acheron. Unfortunately not much happens during the hunt - a crewman gets flogged - they visit the Galapagos islands and look at the tortoises - the ship hits a weak-long windless spell - the captain plays his violin. All the action occurs near the end and it's very good.To a large extent this movie is a character study of the captain. He is a smart man who employs a number of clever tricks in pursuit of the Acheron. He is an outstanding leader much loved by his crew and a fierce warrior. In fact, the movie lays it on a little too thick for my taste as his only flaw seems to be a fondness for rum. Nevertheless, when the movie is over you say to yourself, now that's how a man should be.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: Peter Weir is a director who has made some of the most interesting movies over the years, for example Witness, Dead Poet's Society, Fearless, Picnic At Hanging Rock. And for me, Master and Commander is not only one of his best, but also one of the best period epics from the last few years.Based on a novel written by Patrick O'Brian, it follows Captain Aburey and his ship HMS Surprise, as it does battle with a French ship in the South Pacific and the South Seas...There are many reasons why this movie works so well.The casting is spot-on. There are probably not many actors who can pull of a part like Aubrey, but Russell Crowe is one of them. Aubrey as Captain has to be a strong leader, but also an almost father figure to the young boy officers on board his ship. He certainly has to look the part when he has to fight. and in all these areas, Crowe easily convinces. I think his performance here is actually better than his Oscar-winning performance in Gladiator.But this is not totally Crowes' movie. There is a fantastic performance from Paul Bettany as the ship's doctor and Aubrey's close friend. The relationship is at the heart of the movie, despite the clashes with the French vessel, and both actors have to convince. It's to Bettany's credit that he more than holds his own against Crowe, making their relationship believable.The supporting cast, are all impressive, but special mention I think has to go to Max Pirkis as Blakely, one of the boy officers on the ship.The script by Weir and John Collee gives the actors plenty to work with. I've not read the Patrick O'Brian series of novels, but the dialogue here is fantastic and makes you really think you are on board a real ship. This of course is helped by the wonderful production design by William Sandell.The cinematography is superb, as is the music through-out the movie.The climax of the movie, a fantastic battle between and on the ships is gripping, well shot and very exciting. I've read that the way the battle is fought is also historically accurate. I can believe that.But this is Weir's movie. He directs the movie well, and despite being a long movie, it never drags or feels padded. He stages the action set-pieces brilliantly, yet also gives time for the actors to act well.Master And Commander won 2 Oscars at that years' event. It was beaten in its other categories by Return Of The King (which won everything else!). I think in any other year, it would have won best film and director.It deserves it.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: One of the best high sea adventure movies ever.
Review_body: I can not decide if this is the most exciting history documentary of life at sea in the mid 18th cent. ever made or a swashbuckling yarn. The props are that authentic,and to a pretty good degree the treatment and duties of the crew portrayed in this movie.Russell Crowe is perfect in this movie in the roll of Captain "lucky" Jack and the stand out in the movie, but every single actor is this movie does a amazing job.Max Pirkis, and Paul Bettany deserves mention as outstanding too.The basic story starts when Captain Jacks boat is surprised and damaged by a French warship. The chase begins for proud Captain Jack , and at any cost it would seem..Jack is torn between friendship, duty and pride when his best Friend is injured and the captain must make some morally tough decisions. Tonnes of high sea adventures ensue.Every detail of this movie is great, you must occasionally remind your self to breath at times while watching it...very very good.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: "Master and Commander" is a film that exemplifies a mastery of deception. It is a lengthy tale of 18th century naval war, and it is a film of 18th century quality.  They hype leading up to this so-called Academy Award Winner was prolific.  Unfortunately, the movie failed to live up to the hype generated by big bucks.  It is filmed in a dark, and hazy set.  It leaves on feeling claustrophobic and cheated out of one's time that could have been spent seeing one of the better current shows.  Not a good picture.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: It feels like this film was made in another planet
Review_body: Great film!But, in 2021, this film released in 2003 seems to have been made in another planet or in a parallel world.I wonder how "Master and Commander" would look like if it were made today.Historical revisionism and woke lies would be rampant, of course.How would Hollywood allow a bunch of white guys have control of a ship and behave with honor and loyalty?Too bad they do not make films like this one anymore....
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: Mr. Russell Crowe is not my favorite actor. But in this film he was impressively good. Also good directing, costumes, make-up, camera and excellent scenes, made me really happy. I must of course, mention all the actors participating, for good to excellent performance. Interesting was also the (historically correct) anti-French attitude.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: Master and Commander: The Far Side of the World
Review_body: "Master and Commander" is an interesting film that tries to combine pure entertainment with philosophy and historical detail. To some extent, one could say, it is successful. This is not so much because of the story (which is pretty thin), but more because of the interest Peter Weir puts on the crew and their internal dynamic. The strongest parts of this movie are in its non-battle sequences, when the interest is almost fully on the captain and his crew. To make it short: What we have here is a character-drama-blockbuster. But: As a blockbuster it may be too slow for a big part of the audience. And as a character drama, it doesn't go deep enough, it stays on the surface. But the result is still better than most of the blockbusters today, you just have to take it for what it is and you will be able to enjoy it very much.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: A Re-Furbished Pirates of the Caribbean
Review_body: Peter Weir's lackluster, semi-bland latter-day Hollywood career (Hollywood sucking the creativity out of someone's work - gasp! Say it ain't so!) doesn't compare to the early days of his more profound Aussie New Wave musings (Picnic at Hanging Rock, Gallipoli) and this standard, common, yet-another swashbuckler monochrome etching is testament to that. It literally comes off as a Pirates of the Caribbean spin-off set in the same extended Universe. Or maybe Pirates itself, but Sparrow's lost his whimsy and gets a slightly modified skin. We get it, it's a British period piece (wow, so uncommon, not like people've been doing this premise for centuries or anything, soooo fresh, way to give 'em something dazzling!), harumph, I say, Harumph, yes, Mr. Crow, we get it, you're not just "the dude from Gladiator", we're all taking you very seriously. This's the kind of video you would put on in a middle school social studies class when learning about the War of 1812. Yawn. An educational re-enactment without the wonder of learning something spectacular. This is the moving-picture version of skimming thru a few dusty Encyclopedia Britannica entries on 19th century Naval history. A tedious chore rather than stimulation. As dry as this review, but at least this review has the decency to be much shorter.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: OK, so the title is terrible  (*Master and Commander:  The Far Side of the World*???), but Peter Weir's big-budget extravaganza about life on the open seas during the Napoleonic Wars is a welcome return to old-fashioned entertainment.  The many negative comments here -- "talky", "boring", "not enough action", etc. -- tells us more about the viewers than it does about the film, which, I assure you, has action to spare.  It's a measure of how vapidly hyperactive today's audiences have become when 5 minutes of dialogue can be described as  "endless".  Grow up, people.The movie is really not as  "intellectual"  as its detractors make out (nor as intellectual as it wants to seem to be of its own accord).  Generous critics will probably make too much of the presentation of the alternately conflicting and cooperating roles that War  (personified by Russell Crowe's Jack Aubrey)  and  Science  (personified by Paul Bettany's Stephen Maturin) play in the progress of civilization.  *Master and Commander*  is not a philosophical piece.  Rather, it's a boy's adventure tale  (even featuring a largish role for a 12-year-old midshipman)  in which derring-do AND smarts win the day for our heroes.  However, the smarts are not accompanied by 21st-century-style, hip, Tarantino-esque wisecracks loaded with F-bombs, and so the movie's appeal will probably be lost on the average idiot at the multiplex.  Our main heroes, Capt.
