Jack Aubrey and naturalist/surgeon Stephen Maturin, are definitely men of the Old School:  Duty before pleasure; an enthusiasm for the Life of the Mind  (even macho Aubrey is not above taking battle-strategy tips from his egghead friend Maturin); a preference for classy things like Bach suites, which they saw together on violin and cello in Aubrey's quarters  (I felt the movie was pushing it a bit here, but whatever).One gets irritated after reading complaints that there's  "no plot", when the plot is abundantly clear:  England and France are at war; Aubrey has been commissioned to bring in a marauding French frigate -- the nicely named "Acheron" -- back to England as a  "prize"; the Acheron turns out to be a Yankee-built monster that is better-gunned and better-manned, or at least more-manned, than Aubrey's ship.  Thus, Aubrey & Crew take the retreating position in the cat-and-mouse game that ensues.  One of the pleasures of the film is watching how Aubrey dodges the French ship with clever ruses like setting adrift a decoy-raft hung with lamps after nightfall:  Acheron pursues the decoy, and Aubrey escapes.  Presumably, these displays of cleverness must be the  "boring"  parts everyone's referring to.  Well never mind.  If you're still able to enjoy the pleasures of classical storytelling in this age of pachincko-like cinema, *Master and Commander*  will be right up your alley.  *Matrix*  fans will want to avoid the movie.  One other note:  no females in the movie, except for a longing glimpse at a South Pacific girl.  I realize this will further limit the appeal of this film -- i.e., no women for the female audiences to identify with -- but, considering the setting and genre, I felt relieved to not have to endure yet another anachronistic, butt-kicking chick wreaking havoc on Napoleon's legions. Ladies, give us guys this one, OK?  We promise we'll go see  *Love Actually* in exchange.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: I think those that do not like this movie were looking for the fluff usually found in Pirates of the Caribbean. This is definitely not that. THIS is a movie about true English sailing. It's long, yes...some say boring...but I say infused with thoughtful meaning. The battle scenes are extraordinary and the acting is excellent. The scenery is stunning. For anyone that loves sailing adventures on page...you'll love this outstanding example on the screen.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: Not exactly master of his domain
Review_body: "Master and Commander" is well crafted. The (very few) action scenes are worth the price of the ticket and the special effects take you to that high-sea adventure effortlessly.The problem I found with this movie is the low entertainment value. Crowes other and better known historical epic, "Gladiator," has a gripping, involving story. "Master" on the other hand looks like something more suitable for the History Channel or Bravo than the multiplex.This story is the second in a series of books made on the same character, and in a way, the movie feels like a sequel without being one. The characters are introduced as if we already know them and some of their intentions or problems are not really explained.Still it is a very good movie, not great, but good. It possibly needed a better balance between the action scenes and the scenes that pushed the plot development, again, like in "Gladiator." The action scenes in this movie are too few and far between. A shame because the climatic battle scene at the end is one, if not the best naval battle scene ever made for a movie.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: A superb understated Russell Crowe and a well-paced movie
Review_body: Some have commented that this movie is dull.  Well, I supposed pace, composition, and a setting appropriate to the high seas aren't everything. Some have commented that Russell Crowe is dull.  Well, perfect control, pitch, and nuance as the Captain of the Surprise doesn't require the overacting prolific in Gladiator.  What's so, er, surprising about Master and Commander is its languid pace, which echoes the kind of life faced by the shipmates.  You got a direct feel for sailing, and kudos to Peter Weir for that cinematographic vision.  One user commented that certainly lots of sodomy would have gone on behind the bulkheads...and frankly, the whole crew seemed rather non-sexual, as though a saltpeter bomb had gone off at the film's start.  Given Russell Crowe's fine performance in The Sum of Us, I'm sure he could have improvised...but perhaps he had more important ship duties to attend to (a la Captain Kirk, who always referred to the Enterprise as "She").
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: I've watched this film probably close to ten times now since I first saw it in the cinema for a double header that included Tom Cruise's dreadful 'The Last Samourai'. I remember the impression it made on me. I also remember feeling embarrassed as a teenager buying a ticket for a movie with such a florid title as 'Master and Commander: Far Side of the World' and Russell Crowe on the poster looking like a butch sailor with an unbuttoned uniform staring wistfully off into the future. I cringed. How wrong I was. Here is a film told with great precision and mastery by one of the great chameleon filmmakers Peter Weir; I say chameleon because he is a director who always puts his story and characters ahead of himself - his craft is efficient, with the goal being to remove all traces of there being a hand behind the wheel. Everything you need is there, in service to the film. I've never had the adventure/buccaneer/sailor fantasy growing up, but this film certainly instilled it in me. It's a tremendous adventure, with sweeping battle sequences but is also unusually smart and literate for such a large scale picture. Despite its swashbuckling pretenses, the film allows all of the characters to breathe and come to life over the course of a strangely moving and evocative narrative. Each viewing of the film brings out more details under the surface. It's a shame it didn't have a chance at a sequel, it deserved one so badly. Meanwhile Pirates of the Caribbean 9: coming to a theater near you. Seek this one out instead.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: A great movie, but not oscar great...
Review_body: I enjoyed the movie, but i don't think it is as great as some people say. To me it is a normal action movie set on a boat. You don't really get too involved with the characters and i think that is too bad. My favorite character in this movie is the ship's doctor. And i you ask me why that is, i can't really give you a good reason. All i can say is that i like that actor. I also like Russel Crowe but my favorite movie with him is still L.A. Confidential. Don't get me wrong, he does a good job in this movie, but i missed getting to know the story behind the characters. Most of the reason i liked this movie is due to the fact that the waves and ocean are real. It looks amazing. You will probably enjoy this movie, but not more than that. I rate this movie 7/10
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: An old dame likes this tale----
Review_body: ---From the opening shot of the beautiful sailing vessel on the lonely sea from high above; through the first sequence of the crewman going though the hammocks of the sleeping crew to wake the next watch and them climbing, in the dark, up the masts among the sails, I was captivated.I have never read the books, nor even heard of them, until reading about this film.  The movie has a great world of the Napoleonic era to detail, and does so in great fashion.  I loved the look of the garb of the era, and the detail of all the many chores and insights into daily living on a great vessel.The cast is uniformly fine.  Russell Crowe is the commander of this vessel and he is most believable.  The young Lord Blakeley played by new-comer, Max Pirkis is a standout.  And for us gals, James D'Arcy, in a small but star-making role, is just gorgeous.This is a world of men, and the time is the early 1800's.  I, for one, am glad the filmmakers did not mess it up with romances and kept it true to the story of men at war at sea.  And that they did not put in action just for the sake of the fanboy crowd that has no attention span for the nuanced tale being told.  Wonderful film.  9/10
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: A Good Movie With One Major Weakness
Review_body: ********    SOME MILD SPOILERS  ******* Master and Commander is an adventure on the high seas.   It gives us the depiction of a cat and mouse game between the captains of two ships.  It's a good movie with one weakness.  The major weakness of this movie is that it ultimately looks at every character in an analytical way.  The result is that I admired the characters but never became attached to them.  This might not be bad news for a character study, but it isn't particularly beneficial to an adventure movie. The perspective of Master and Commander is from the captain and crew of one ship.  The captain is played by Oscar winner Russell Crowe.  There is tremendous attention to detail and the actors give marvelous portrayals of their characters.  Russell Crowe and Paul Bettany (together again from the movie A Beautiful Mind) shine as do several other actors especially the actor who played the young officer who lost his arm.  It is interesting to see what the quality life of the sailors was like in that time period.  Beautiful photography and lavish sets abound.There are numerous men aboard the ship living in tight quarters and the men from different walks of life with some being officers, one a doctor and the rest crew men on the ship.  This naturally leads to some conflict and tension.    For adventure movie lovers, Master and Commander is a good choice.  You'll probably be satisfied although not swept away (no pun intended).There is another difficulty, however, for this movie. I believe it is overshadowed by Pirates of the Caribbean which is a tough movie to compete with.  There will be inevitable comparisons, and Pirates of the Caribbean will come up the winner.I rate this movie a C.   It was better during the second viewing and I think time will be kind to this movie.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: I was far from excited about my trip to the movies this weekend (I didn't get to pick what I wanted to watch...) but...I was going to be a good sport and sit though this mess with minimal complaints. Boy am I glad I did. This turned out to be a fabulous movie. Excellent special effects (the storm scened in this movie make "The Storm" look like a joke), the cast (how many seamen were on that ship?), and the story were all enjoyable. The story was very historically accurate and full of trivia (how did they measure speed in the good ol' days before computers?). I though the acting was good though not spectacular. However, great to watch was Paul Bettany, a talented actor, who, up to this point, had been undercast.8/10 for this great sea epic
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: From a simple plot, an epic film
Review_body: The entire plot of "Master and Commander" can be summed up in a single sentence:  In 1805, HMS Surprise sails from the coast of Brazil to the Galapagos Islands to do battle with the French ship Acheron.  From this thin reed of a plot, Peter Weir constructs a true epic that should thrill fans of old fashioned sea-going adventures.From almost the beginning, we discover that the Acheron is a formidable foe, since it is both larger and faster than the Surprise.  The Acheron is also nearly impervious to the Surprise's ordnance thanks to the modern invention of double-hulling.Also from the beginning, we are shown that the Surprise's captain "Lucky Jack" Aubrey (Russell Crowe filling the shoes of fellow Aussie Errol Flynn) is a wise and courageous commander who loves his men.  He does have doubts at times, however.  This is largely due to his frequent conversations with his best friend and ship's doctor Stephen Maturin (Paul Bettany).  Dr. Maturin believes in the primacy of scientific research over battle and feels that Jack can be something of a tyrant towards his conscripts.  During their free time, the doctor and captain play music together with the captain on violin and the doctor on cello.What impressed me the most about this film is the painstaking attention to detail as far as what the ship is like, how the men are trained and even who served in the Royal Navy two hundred years ago.  The men are mostly conscripted (i.e. kidnapped) by the Navy from off the streets of England. And not all of the men are men at all.  Boys who have not yet reached puberty are conscripted, and are even made officers (there is a subplot involving a young boy played by Max Perkis who loses his arm in an early battle, and who commands a battalion at the end of the movie).  Captain Aubrey treats the boys with fatherly affection, although he still expects no less of them than his adult crew.Another thing I liked was that, rather than relying solely on a through-composed score, bits of classical music from Bach, Handel, Mozart, and Vaughn-Williams are thrown in.  In deference to the Captain's duets with the doctor, the music is nothing but violins and cellos, with no brass or percussion.  And the score is such that it fits seamlessly with the classical music.I also really enjoyed the scenes of natural wonder on the Galapagos.  They are so enchanting, one forgets that they have little to do with the plot.The film truly belongs to Russell Crowe.  In a movie with no women, Crowe is the manliest of all men, and is the only contemporary actor who could have played the part.  Every other male in Hollywood is either too old (i.e. Harrison Ford), too wimpy/sensitive (i.e. Ben Affleck) or not a good enough actor (i.e. Vin Diesel).There are a few flaws.  Much of the dialog is either mumbled or drowned out by the sound effects, so it is sometimes difficult to tell what's being said.  Plus, there are a few scenes too many that have nothing to do with the main plot.  And aside from the captain, the doctor, and the kid who loses his arm, you don't really get to know anyone in the film as a distinct character.Altogether, however, this film is a rousing nautical adventure in the spirit of "Captain Blood", "Treasure Island", or "Mutiny on the Bounty".  I highly recommend it to anyone who has ever daydreamed about going to sea or going to war.  9 out of 10.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: Certainly Peter Weir's most focused film possibly even his finest, Master and Commander is a supremely intelligent action film that puts you in a time machine and takes you back as much as any film as ever done. You find yourself completely engrossed in the story and characters and very grateful that you didn't live in those times.(9/10)
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: One of the finest movies to realistically show what life was like in the days of fighting sail. Totally believable adventure-drama as British warship hunts down a much larger French man of war off the South American coast in 1805.Crowe brings Captain "Lucky Jack" Aubrey to life and fits the role perfectlt. He gets good support from his co-star Paul Bettany as the ships doctor-and naturalist Maturin . They both were good together in "A Beautiful Mind" and these two have a chemistry that works perfectly. Much attention is paid to historical detail and we get a good picture of what it was like to live-and fight on these wooden ships. We get to see all the details, the food, the cramped quarters, the thrill of the battles, the dangers of the sea and the monotony that existed when the ship was stuck in calm weather where not a breeze of wind was to be had. It was a tough life-and a dangerous one too and the film doesn't gloss it over. This one is up there with 1962's"Damn the Defiant" as one of the best sea adventures ever filmed.An intelligent and exciting movie, a rarity in todays age of dumbed down high concept so-called "movies".
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: A movie to rate a 10 if there every was one
Review_body: I can't say enough about this movie. The casting was spot on. It is a perfect part for Russell Crowe.This movie depicts life aboard a ship in early 1800s like no other movie I've ever seen. The crude ship, clothing, medical practice, tools, etc. perfectly fit the era.The story is rich, battles are superb, time spent on the Galapagos was as real as could be. Acting = 10 Driection = 10 Cinematography = 10And the music added so much to the movie. I had no idea where real sets ended and CGI began.It is rare for me to rate a movie a 10. I hold my top ratings for nothing but the best (like Shawshank).
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: There is much to admire about Peter Weir's adaptation of the British sea voyage novels, "Master And Commander: The Far Side of the World". It's absorbing, it's breathtaking, it's intelligent, it's glorious, and it's ingeniously crafted. This is such a sensational marvel of a film production that, if it hadn't been for "The Return of the King" stealing its thunder, "Master and Commander" would have certainly won many more Oscars, and perhaps even the grand prize. My only major complaint with the film is the story: at times tedious, and includes some ingratiating details (e.g. Paul Bettany befriending a junior sailor---entirely irrelevant to the plot). This is an astonishing effort that sails both on style as well as substance. The acting is, as expected, pure dynamite, with Russell Crowe delivering yet another impeccable performance as the virtuous, vivacious "Lucky Jack" Aubrey- and plays this role with such spirit and conviction that he virtually steals the show as far as the cast is concerned. Paul Bettany plays a diffident, subdued role as Stephen Maturin, proving that he can be deftly serious and reflective to Russell Crowe's bombast and vivacity. The visuals, to say the least, are absolutely splendid- from the engaging battles of the ships, to the raging storms, to the flickering lights throughout these turmoils, one is really given a "taste of the perilous and spectacular sea" through some strikingly realistic effects. And speaking of being situated into the action, the sound effects are superb- the gunshots are vociferous and glaring, and it is often scary how terrifying these battles really are. The ship design is exquisite, and perhaps very exorbitant, displaying practically every detail one might expect to find in a British liner circa 1805. The costumes are fancy, genteel, and luxurious, and what else might one expect sailors from the Royal British Navy to be suited with? A far cry from the scrappy suits of "Pirates of the Caribbean" in that respect! I will say that my favorite scene of the film was the showdown between the Brits and the French- you are literally situated right in the center of the bloody action, and you realize that this is the ultimate pinnacle and quest of the story: what an engaging thrill! Featuring some brilliant and laudable technical design, fantastic acting, yet a somewhat slow and stagnant plot, "Master and Commander" is, above anything else, a masterpiece in modern film-making, and truly a wonder to behold. ***1/2 out of ****
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: Very good film, just over long
Review_body: As a fan of Russell's I really enjoyed the film. He did another wonderful performance. HE SHOULD HAVE BEEN NOMINATED FOR AN Oscar. I REMEMBER THE MORNING THE NOMINATION WERE ANNOUNCED, THE CROWD GRASPED WHEN HIS NAME WAS NOT READ. HE DESERVED IT!!Other actors did good jobs with their roles.Great film to look at.Another good job by Peter Weir. Not his best work, that would be in "Witness". Film was a bit over long. DID NOT NEED THE SHORT SCENE, YES EVEN IF IT WAS THIS SHORT, THERE WE HAVE TO HEAR WHAT HAPPENED TO THE SHIPS CREW DURING THE STORM. Also, did not need the scene of the surgery on young Blakeney . Good extras on the DVD package. I have not been able to get the better DVD package. Would like to see that.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: Russell Crowe is a very convincing Jack Aubrey. He projects Aubrey's energy, competence, pugnacity and confidence bordering on self-satisfaction (unlike Hornblower, Aubrey always knew he was good). He also credibly projects Aubrey's belief in the need for custom, tradition and authority, his acceptance of the irrational culture of the lower deck as a fact of life that must be dealt with, and his own irrational streak. Crowe's Aubrey is true to O'Brian's instinctive Tory. He is intelligent but not an intellectual, and he knows that the ignorant, superstitious masses have to be dominated from above rather than uplifted. A.O. Scott of the NY Times got it right when he wrote that this "one of the most thoroughly and proudly conservative movies ever made," for which he expected to see Edmund Burke get screen credit. Scott also got it right when he described Aubrey as "an ideal personification of modern executive authority" and wrote "'Master and Commander,' were it not a movie, could be a Powerpoint seminar advertised in an airline magazine: Leadership Secrets of the Royal Navy." Maturin will be the biggest disappointment to serious O'Brianists. Bettany gives a good performance, but the part is badly written. The Maturin of the books is a scientific rationalist, but of his time and place. Much of the pleasure of the character is to see what he knows, what he doesn't know, and what he thinks he knows that we know isn't so. The Maturin of the books is also, in his peculiar way, devoted to the defeat of Napoleon and the overthrow of all the French Revolution stands for. One might think of this Irish-Catalan outsider as a neo-conservative of his day. A former Irish revolutionary, he has become a devoted supporter of the existing order out of revulsion with his personal experience of radicalism and its consequences, and he puts his considerable intellect at the service of victory.The Maturin of the movie is an anachronism, not merely outside the culture of the Navy but unsympathetic to it. He isn't merely upset that the ship's mission interferes with his naturalizing, as the Maturin of the books often is. He disputes with Aubrey the need for the mission itself and the intensity with which Aubrey pursues it. O'Brian's Maturin is a dedicated, competent and merciless secret agent for the Admiralty. Weir's Maturin isn't an intelligence agent, and I can't see how he could be or would want to be.Weir also wastes Maturin's great narrative potential as an explainee. In his 15th century text on painting, Alberti wrote that a religious or historical scene should always include an "interlocutor" in the foreground; a figure who draws the viewer into the picture. Since few people in Western societies have military experience any more, a good modern war movie needs an interlocutor, both to inform the audience what is going on and to be an emotional intermediary, reacting as one not hardened to war. Leutnant Werner does this job in Das Boot, Corporal Upham in Saving Private Ryan.Maturin was O'Brian's interlocutor. His peculiar inability to learn anything about seamanship gave O'Brian the chance to have members of the gunroom explain things to him repeatedly, as well as some low comedy when Maturin tried passing this knowledge on to those even more ignorant than he. With very minor exceptions, Weir doesn't use Maturin this way. He limits Maturin's interactions pretty much to Aubrey and Blakeny, leaving out the kind of easy social intercourse with the other officers through which O'Brian fed the reader technical information. His Maturin is also too emotionally distant from the struggle in which he is involved; he sulks and almost sneers, but he does not seem moved.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body:
Those who like movies with great battle scenes, authentic sets, and superb characterizations will love this movie as I did.Master and Commander is one of those films you have to watch more than one time.  There is so much "meat" in it that it is easy to miss important tidbits the first time.I almost felt as though I were on an early eighteenth century ship fighting in the Napoleonic Wars.  How apropos that the French are the enemy! 
The movie is based upon two of the novels of Patrick O'Brien.  Having read several of them, I know that Russell Crowe's characterization of the courageous, sometimes blustering "lucky" Jack Aubrey is accurate.Definitely a 4-star film--one of the best of the year.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: A Good Solid Adventure Movie (Possible Spoilers)
Review_body: Russell Crowe and Paul Bettany play the Ship's Captain and the Ship's Doctor, who happen to be best friends.  Moreover, both characters share a responsibility for the survival of the crew, albeit on different planes of authority.  I found that the pairing worked quite well, and wonder if we'll see it again.  Both did solid acting jobs, but neither role was a far stretch from previous roles - Crowe in Gladiator and Bettany in a Knight's Tale.The feel of the movie was phenomenal.  I cannot recall any movie with at sea scenes remotely close to this movie, except The Perfect Storm.  Combine that with the brutal combat details of the Patriot and you'll have a good feel for what war on the high seas was like.  One of the major differences though is the presence of young children and teenagers, usually orphans, on ships that as often as the adults find themselves the casualties of sea warfare - this is a fact most people tend to forget.This visually masterful depiction of life at sea, showed all facets of sea-faring life.  The ship itself is amazing - how it was transformed from a place to live to a place for war in a matter of minutes.  How while some live stock was kept on board, much foraging still needed to occur the longer the journey, or when the ship was stuck dead in the water because their was no wind, or how they ran low on fresh water because it hadn't rained in days.  Based upon what I have read, in and out of school, these were many of the realities of sailing at sea.You will find yourself drawn to all the supporting characters who's names and faces become familiar to you over the course of this movie, and be amazed at the vivid scenery that plays a backdrop to the brutality of life and war at sea.  This is an awesome movie that everyone should see.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: Best movie I've seen in quite a while
Review_body: There was nothing in this film I didn't like. Folks, the naysayers of this movie probably missed the flash and dazzle of special effects (some call it eye-candy). But that was here. The attention to detail was magnificent. Crowe's acting was understated brilliance and I will be lumping him with the likes of Anthony Hopkins for mastery of the subtle nuance. Some have called it a slow film. On the contrary, the time is definitely compressed. Life on a ship at this time was long periods of nothing. In this film something was always going on even if it was just character development. There wasn't a character in the entire movie that you couldn't appreciate. I liked this movie so much I watched 5 times over the course of two days. A fine film worthy of great praise.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: Okay, this movie is right up my alley, but still.. It's intelligently written, incredibly well-acted, exciting (in a slower way than most modern action flicks) thoughtful, and true to the fighting sail genre. The production values are outstanding as is just about everything else. It's obviously a work of love.On the other hand, if you've read the O'Brian novels, you might miss some of the finer points of the Aubrey/Maturin relationship. Personally, I read the books after, so it wasn't an issue. I must have watched this ten times by now, and I still marvel at some of the detail. My only caveat is that it is not your standard Hollywood production which has been written trying to appeal to every demographic. It is what it is, so you'll need to be interested in the subject matter. If you even remotely are, you should find it a very rewarding viewing.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: Good cinematography, but not much else.
Review_body: I was suspicious when the ads and trailers started appearing with great seafaring scenery, yet barely a clue as to what the film would be ABOUT.  I was not familiar with the books, but if I had been, I would probably have been even more disappointed!  Actually, the ads were pretty accurate, Russell Crowe, scenery, and battle sequences, that's all there is.  It is hard to feel sympathy for characters whom are barely defined or even introduced.  The only exception is Paul Bettany as the ships doctor. Otherwise the film barely has a soul and is merely an exercise in filmmaking on the part of the normally excellent Peter Weir.  In other words, the film is boring, but not for lack of action.  I could blame a weak script, but Weir co-wrote that too.  The cinematography had to have been the ONLY reason this film was nominated for Best Picture over several more deserving films.  The good acting almost redeems it, but I still think I'm being generous in giving this a 4/10.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: . . . gives Godfather loyalists the testosterone pop they crave ...
Review_body: Action packed.  Thrilling.  Music, Medicine and Mayhem are the basic ingredients -in reverse order - with 90% mayhem.  This film and its many seaquels will give Godfather fans the testosterone pop they crave - and that's "gender neutral" testosterone so my daughters don't knee-cap me. The Patrick O'Brian books could be retitled `Sea Trek' (1 to 23) or for as many books as Patrick O'Brian has written and cares yet to write.  I've never read one.  I will now.Beyond non-stop action, great moments justifying the ticket price: (1)  The on board surgery theater and gallery for 1805 medical procedure at sea  . fascinating; (2)  The age dispersion of the warriors . . . and of the leaders among them. . . eye-opening; (3)  The practical application of a naturalist's curiosity into a warrior's passion; (4)  Digital sound's persistent reminder that you're on a wooden war ship as the plot unravels; (5)  Guerrilla tactics on the high seas at the dawn of the 19th century; + the sheer quantity of grog consumed. . .   buy some Barcardi Stock next week.It's long on character chemistry, brilliant photography, screenplay pacing, and the birth of screen heroes - making its 160 minutes an excellent investment of your time and money.  It's short on bathroom breaks so empty the bladders before taking your seat; then pound a little grog after the show.   Earns an unwavering 9 on the 10 scale.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: More than most of Weir or Crowe's previous films, this one relies as much on effects and scenery as on the individual performances of the cast.  Make no mistake, many of the performances are excellent, but this is an action/adventure film.  Unlike many Hollywood action films, the action is pretty realistic, rather than simply graphic.  Having seen several films and read several books set during this war, I found the story fairly formulaic, and therefore predictable.  But that did not lessen my enjoyment of the film.  It was a rollicking high-seas adventure that I found very exciting.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: This movie consisted of a few battle scenes and two hours of meaningless mellow drama. Now I know why I've never had an interest to see it.The acting is good but that's expected from veteran actors but the entire movie for the most part just drags. I couldn't wait until it was over so I could put that snoozefest behind me.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: This isn't usually my sort of film, and yet on the other-hand it was so well made i felt i had to watch it to the end.For anyone interested in films about the Royal Navy in the 19th century this is a must see,i couldn't fault it,the film was acted to perfection.Russel Crowe convinces us that his a British captain aboard a ship named the HMS Surprise,all the accents are very well done no one in this cast lets the film down.The scenery was breathtaking the old type ships were beautiful and made you wish you could sail on them.I understand this film took 3 years to make which doesn't surprise me as every detail from the dialogue to the outfits of the sailors has been expertly researched,i wouldn't have thought there were any inaccuracies in this film,well not noticeable ones anyway.The director has took the trouble to make the film as realistic as possible.The battle scenes looked real and bloody,which of coarse they would have been.There is no women or love interests in this film which would have ruined the realism,and also the film didn't need one.In all this is a brilliantly made film and definitely worth a watch,even if your not interested in life at sea in the 19th century.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: A good story with developing characters, nice acting and interesting interactions...  But only of special interest to those who like constant battle content, seafaring talk, weather changes and guts and gore of extreme medical care(and very unrealistic I might add - I worked with surgeons for 7 years and most of the outcomes are ridiculous).  Overall, there is not much in the way of clever turns of plot or much to keep the viewer engaged.  The most suspenseful and interesting parts are (1) when Aubrey decides to disguise the ship as a whaler and (2) how they discovered and studied the Galapagos Islands, famous for the origin of Darwin's "Origin of Species" theory.  The lessons they learned are important and inspiring but not earth-shattering or especially new or deep.  In short, the film is good but mostly as a historical study and not even in the top 10 of the year.  I rate it 6 or 7 out of 10 stars.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: After reading the other User Comments I began to wonder if all these people saw the same movie I did.  I am not sure what people are looking for or expecting in a movie but "Master and Commander", offers great acting, a good solid script, well drawn and interesting characters, good action, outstanding photography and a true depiction of life on a 1800 English ship of war.  That being said, I find this movie one of the best I have ever seen and I do not make that judgment lightly. The ending could have been stronger and I can only assume that the director was leaving a starting place for sequel.  Master and Commander earned and deserves the rare 10 I have chosen for it.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: I read a history book a few years back titled "Birth of the Modern" by Paul Johnson.  It was a narrative of world events and people from the years 1815 to 1830.  I was reminded of that novel when I was watching "Master and Commander".  I appreciated the film maker's decision to set it during a period that's rarely done in film history.  Europe has just begun to extend it's grip around the whole globe with England about to reach pre-eminence. The scientific method was taking hold among European academia.The main plot has a British warship pursuing and being pursued by a French warship.  Among the men, and boys, on the ship is its doctor, who is a naturalist as well.  He clashes with the ship's captain when his pursuit doesn't conform to the captain's.The film is well written, well acted an adventurous.  A good all-around effort.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: Shows how life might have been like at that time and place
Review_body: I love films like this.  Films that take you to a place completely different from the world that you and I live in and allow you to experience life as others might have lived it in the past.  It really makes history come alive for me.Russell Crowe gives another great performance.  With A BEAUTIFUL MIND, THE INSIDER, and LA CONFIDENTIAL, Russell Crowe proves himself to be among the greatest actors working today.  He is completely focused in every shot.  I kept looking into his eyes and I didn't see a movie star.  I saw a sea captain.This is also a triumph for director Peter Weir.  I've been a fan of Weir's work for a long time now, but I never would have predicted that he could pull off a film like this.  This is probably his largest film in scope and he proves that he is more than up to the challenge.My rating:9 out of 10
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: Watched a few times now, but just watched again first time in a few years. This is a superb movie. Great action and historical themes every well told.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: If there is a connecting thread in the work of director Peter Weir it is to be found in his great theme, the clash of cultures. Sometimes the clash of cultures is in the foreground (Witness, Mosquito Coast, The Year of Living Dangerously, Picnic at Hanging Rock); in some of his works it is more subtle (Dead Poets Society, Gallipoli, The Truman Show). In Master and Commander it is revealed in the tension between the values and worldview of the warrior-leader and the healer/man of science.The master and commander is Jack Aubrey, very capably portrayed by Russell Crowe, one of the best actors working today. His good friend, the doctor and naturalist is played by Paul Bettany (who played the imagined roommate opposite Crowe in A Beautiful Mind). It is easy to view this as simply a standard swashbuckler, and to be sure there is plenty of swash to be buckled (whatever that means) but the strength of the film lies in its juxtaposition of the larger conflict and the battle scenes, and the interpersonal conflicts between the two friends.If the film were just about the larger conflicts, the spectacular battle scenes, and the pursuit, it would be too easy to dismiss the film as a remake-Gladiator Goes Sailing-in the same way that I dismissed Waterworld as Mad Max goes sailing. In the macro-story, the quest for the elusive ship, the story is reminiscent of many other sailing films. There are elements of Moby Dick, Mutiny on the Bounty, The Caine Mutiny. The thread that connects these films is obsessive leadership that walks the line between duty and prideful ambition. The most engaging part of the film, as is always the case in Weir's films, is the clash of cultures. In this case, the cultures are represented by the values of the two friends. The tensions created by the conflicting values of the warrior and the healer. These represent conflicting values, dialectical tensions, in all cultures and perhaps in all people. It is this storyline that redeems the film from being just another run-of-the-mill seafaring adventure.Having said that, I should add that the seafaring adventure story is particularly well told, and is wonderfully supported by superior cinematography. Cinematographer Russell Boyd is an Australian (as are Weir and Crowe) and Boyd has worked with Weir on a number of films from the beginning of Weir's career in the mid 70's. The cinematography is superb in this film. In the battle scenes we feel the claustrophobia, in the storm scenes sheer terror. When Boyd shows us the vast oceans or the Galapagos Islands we are awed by the sheer beauty of the scene. When the Academy Awards are announced, the Master and Commander may not be able to defeat the Lord of the Rings but you can count on it to be in the running. This one is definitely worth a look.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: Good movie, but SOMETHING was missing, but what!
Review_body: Having just watched the movie i am kinda confused, i actually thought it was a good movie, but why does it feel like there is something missing, and i can't quite figure out what i feel is missing, lets dig it.First of all what drives this movie is that it is a well directed movie, and it has stunning cinematography, that was one thing i really loved about it, absolutely beautiful scenery and settings.First of all one of the losses in this movie is that all the persons except the doctor and the captain feels kinda distant, it feels like they are there becuase they have to be there, many of them are just faces you recognize but you don't get to know any of them very personally, which is why you later on won't feel much sorrow when some of them dies. More intensity to the personalities of each main character would have made a better movie i think.Also one of the things that struck is that the movie spends most of the time building the background for the initial fight with the french ship, and then after the end fight is over, you're left, wondering why it wasn't a great fight as you had hoped and expected for, that's sad becuase the start out small fights are so well made, and then the end one is just a big dissapointment, that kinda let the movie down.The last thing i felt wrong was the twist made very late in the movie about the doctor about the other ship, someone please tell Peter Weir not to include a twist in the movie if he does not wish to explain the outcome of it, that totally ruined the ending in my book.So overall i thought it was a good movie, but there are some things, some major things, that i thought was either missing or wrongly done, but you can't take away from the movie that it has some fantastic breathtaking scenes at times, and some pretty solid action. And it is entertaining after all, just has a few flaws hehe.7/10
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: In any year without Return of the King this one should be a big winner
Review_body: I went to this movie with my parents and don't expect anything more than a usual light sea adventure movie but I was mistaken. Master and Commander without a doubt is a best sea war/adventure movie in recent years and one of very best of all-time. It's a story of a British war frigate in thousands miles far away from home, a story of duty and courage of people united by one goal, a story of the strong characters who struggle with power of nature. The script is well-written, solid and consistent all the way. The screenwriters one more time proved that such a movie can exist without a usual weak Hollywood's love story in the background. Just unexplored boundless ocean, people on the certain ship and that's it.Peter Weir is a director who has made lots of very good but different from each other movies (worth to mention among them Dead Poets Society, The Witness, and The Truman Show). His directing in Master and Commander is outstanding. He has brought a balance into the movie; he united into one masterpiece excellent acting with magnificent special effects and that's the most important all these visuals are in the right place. Nothing here looks fake, all seems perfectly real, from a squall sea to beautiful Galapagos Islands. But the real glory of the movie is naval battles, the best such scenes I have ever seen. The excellent cinematography with well selected scenery makes this terrific piece of film-making an unforgettable experience for all people who prefer high-quality work to shallow summer blockbusters. Finally the acting. As all previously mentioned it's excellent. Russell Crowe and Paul Bettany created here two Oscar-worthy performances of their well developed characters. Mr. Crowe was incredibly powerful as captain Jack Obrey, the strong leader but at the same time not a heartless person. He definitely deserved the fourth Oscar nomination in last six years for this terrific performance, but for some reason he was robbed of it. Paul Bettany perfectly plays here his best friend and at the same a subordinate under his command. All the supporting casts are good (including an excellent performance of young newcomer Max Pirkis as midshipman Blakeney) in their parts, they have created an amazingly real picture of a war ship and its crew. The movie's soundtrack is in opinion the best original score of this year and very suitable. All the way Master and Commander is an Oscar-worthy work of art that deserves the highest appreciation and praise. I know there is no a perfect movie in our world and with some patience you can find flaws in this Peter Weir's work but when you see such a movie you forget about all that and finally applause to all people involved in making of such a masterpiece.10 out of 10
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: Come for the Action and Popcorn
Review_body: Epic budget, no doubt, but not epic impact. Great time period, plenty of action and characters to care about but I came out just feeling a little flat. The word anti-climatic comes to mind. If ship battles in the early 1800s were like this, it must have been a harsh time. Black powder and big calibres make for a lot of destruction, if not accuracy. Fun, and worth seeing, for this reason alone.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: Excellent, but not to be compared to the book
Review_body: It is hard to say enough good things about this movie -- you just couldn't get a better presentation than Russell Crowe does.  When he growls a line like, "he's done this to me two times, there won't be a third" you can feel the determination and authority that O'Brian's Jack Aubrey is.Of course there is so much that are in the novels that isn't even touched in the movie.  The character Jack Aubrey is certainly a genius when it comes to anything nautical; in almost any other venue he is almost a complete buffoon.  This is very important to the character.  The best the screenplay can do to show this is show him spitting food over his table in a clowning act; it just doesn't work very well.  The Stephen Maturin character is similarly short-changed.  He becomes a backdrop character instead of a second protagonist, even though they wrote in a crucial role for him in the plot.Most of this sacrifice is to give you stunning sea footage and up-close-and-personal battle scenes.  I'll tell you the guys who did that in real life were crazy. So the real star of the show is the ship and the water around it.  That at least is where the movie version has real value over what any book can provide.Enjoy the movie, but don't equate it with the books.  It would be great if they did more of the books' stories with this cast.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: It is the story of the sea.the life of the seamen,the aspects of the battles,the wits and the guts.My personal opinion is that this movie had almost everything a story like this needs..but the ending was too hollywoodian...i can't get into that since there are no spoilers here.Crowe was absolutely great,convincing and charming..Bettany was really different than his other roles but quite good too..and i wonder what's next around this movie? The sound of the movie is very good done,aspects surrounding the battles make you a part of the action,right in the middle of the movie,spectating ...and feeling everything. Enjoy this movie and see behind the morning mist !
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: One person already said that this film is like looking at some seafaring masterpieces in a museum.  Exactly!  This film is as beautiful but as static.  Plot?  Huh?  This film didn't have one as far as I could tell.  And I tried desperately to find one in this LONG LONG LONG LONG epic.  Consider this, though: the French killing the English and the English killing the French on the ocean in BIG ships? That is not a plot.  That's the background in which a story can be told.  The one nice thing about pictures in a museum unlike this film:  you can walk away from them in a couple of minutes.  This one goes on and on and on and on and on and on and on and on and on ..... Oh, yeah, I know I could have turned the DVD player off before the end, but I fell asleep by the time the epic battle scene occurred (good grief, another one?!).  There was absolutely no suspense, drama or drive to this snoorer.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: The attention to detail in this movie is one thing that really impresses me, particularly in the actor's wonderful job of studying and speaking 18th century British Naval lingo and accents flawlessly. You feel immersed in the belly of this tiny British Frigate (at 28 guns, it was indeed a tiny warship for the time and barely worthy of the title Frigate) which brings me to the first of many minor complaints.We are shown a very skillful and apparently distinguished commander, who apparently served with the immortal Nelson himself, yet this man, at the apex of his career, is commanding what might today be called a patrol boat. He should be commanding a massive 74 gunner ship of the line by this time in his career, and we are offered no explanation as to why this is not so.The reason of course is because of production values. No 74 gunner exists any more in the world and would have to have been re-created completely digitally. That they managed to do this with the 'French' Constitution class heavy frigate is proof it could have been done though.Apparently they originally had the British against the Americans. This would have made a far more enjoyable movie for me, since the American Constitution class 44 gun frigate, (armed with 24 inch main guns, btw, not 18 as stated in the movie) was never loaned to the French.Secondly, such a boat would have eaten the lowly British frigate for breakfast on the first engagement, fog bank or no fog bank. The inequality between these two ships is so massive as to nearly beg impossibility of any good outcome for the Brit boat. The passage of such a unique ship would have been known, and the British would have dispatched at least 2 (more like 4 for good measure) 36 gun frigates in pursuit.But technical errors aside, where this movie shines is in the acting, and in the costumes, set and the passion the actors threw into it to get the mood right. Wonderful job, I suspect the director sent them all off on a tall ship sailing adventure cruise to get their heads into it before the movie began.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: Master and Commander grabs you and pulls you in almost immediately. The sheer ferocity of battle at sea is perfectly presented by the team that put this movie together.The vernacular, the living conditions, the hardships and comradery seem to me to be impeccably accurate. The top billed cast deliver great performances, and the rest of the cast give a gritty dimension to the story line.I've watched this movie three or four times over the years and no doubt i'll watch it again down the road, it's that good.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: Stunning visuals, solid acting and rousing story
Review_body: Since Errol Flynn graced the screen in Captain Blood, the genre of swashbuckling, seafaring films have enjoyed great notariety. Master and Commander: The Far Side of the World is a period piece with modern execution. From the standpoint of the story and cast, Russell Crowe as Captain Jack Aubrey is the ultimate star of Master and Commander. He conveys an authenticity and charisma that few actors currently possess, which allows him to pull off the Aubrey role so authoritatively. But there is an even more impressive star of the film--a star you will not see. Richard King was brought on board by director Peter Weir as "sound designer". His passion and technical expertise in audio engineering make the film a powerhouse cinematic experience, transporting viewers from their seats to a place onboard the British Navy ship, Surprise, off the coast of South America almost 200 years ago. More than any other aspect of the film, the realism and immersive quality of the audio puts the audience in the middle of the action. King won the Academy Award of Merit for Best Sound Editing for his work on Master and Commander. It was very well deserved.Based on Patrick O'Brian's novels about Aubrey's adventures, Master and Commander: The Far Side of the World follows the Surprise, as it battles the Acheron, a superior U.S.-made ship in Napoleon's navy. After a surprise attack by the Acheron during the film's opening scene, in which the British ship takes nearly insurmountable damage and barely slips away in the cover of fog, Captain "Lucky" Jack decides to go after the faster, stronger ship instead of returning to England. At first, the decision seems foolhearty, as the Acheron again surprises Aubrey. This time, he escapes under cover of darkness. But the story is more than a series of chase and battle scenes, entertaining as those prove to be. Several aspects of naval and ship service are explored.Part of the story touches on concepts like religion and science in the prism of 19th century thought. The latter part of the film takes place in the Galápagos Islands where the ship's Irish doctor and naturalist, Stephen Maturin (Paul Bettany) convinces Aubrey to let him explore and collect specimens in a pre-Darwinian subplot. Unfortunately for Maturin, he makes an unexpected discovery that leads him to cut short his tour of the Galápagos. One of his specimens, an insect that looks like a twig, gives Aubrey the idea to disguise the Surprise, leading to the film's climax, an intense battle, featuring an extended sequence of intense hand-to-hand combat. It is worth asking if Master and Commander would have received more attention if it arrived in theaters at a different time than the much more successful Pirates of the Caribbean: Curse of the Black Pearl. Both feature "Captain Jack" characters, swashbuckling adventures on the open seas, and impressive battle scenes. Both films were very well executed, and it makes sense that a movie appealing to younger audiences would gross significantly more at the box office. The reality, though, is that audiences chose the equivalent of a theme park ride over an excellent series of books that easily could have spawned even better sequels to Master and Commander: The Far Side of the World. The biggest disappointment of the film is that there would be no follow-up Master and Commander to follow Lucky Jack's exploits in the service of England's navy. Instead, we got two insipid sequels to the Pirates film, neither of which rose to the level of the first. Too bad. I would much prefer a trilogy of Master and Commander films, but it was not to be.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: Not a masterpiece but still another gem from the Ausies
Review_body: I have a question: How come Hollywood still approves ambitious projects for sea-oriented motion pictures? This is a big question, in my view, because there are so many pirate movies and movies with extensive shooting on the ocean that their costs bloated like a highway project. Those films (apart from the shrewdly marketed "Titanic") ended up losing great deal of money (Cut throat island, Water world and list sails on and on). But still, when veteran and an extremely talented director Peter Weir came up with an idea to film the story of Ocean battles (who were shot in a location near Mexico, exactly where "Titanic" was filmed) during the 19th century clashes with Napoleon, the studios handed a carte blanche (French for: 150 million dollars) to turn the didactic story to a very convincing epic film that, unfortunately for all parties involved, sunk.The plot, in essence, is about Jack Aubry a.k.a Lucky Jack (Russel Crowe) who is the captain of a war vessel with contagious zeal and charisma which enable to conceal his impulsive, ego motivated and fickle philosophy (what we refer today as "Politician"). The quest, seemingly after a French super modern  vessel becomes a feast of strength for Jack and his followers who include a young trainee who turns out (naturally) as a brave and resourceful youngster, A first lieutenant that can't garner respect from the ship members and, finally, the Doctor/zoologist/ Voice of reason on the ship. Before I elaborate further, I must stress out that every sea-oriented motion picture has to include its fair share of adventure. This movie, is no exception and it provides with very compelling (although sometimes, to elaborate to be coherent) battle scenes that portray vividly the confrontation of two war vessels back in the days where attackers saw what or who they were attacking.There are two schools regarding Russel Crowe acting, some say he's one of the best working actors today but others claim he's overrated (no man in his right mind will refer to Crowe's acting as bad). I belong to the former and I think that although the cast in this movie (especially D'arcy, the Doctor) is great in general, Crowe's performance as the skilled sailor and secretly sensitive captain, makes the movie a real treat. What denies the movie of the Masterpiece title is the lack of added value of the movie, a trait that many other Weir's films have in abundance (Dead poets society, Fearless, The Truman show and so many others, all of which I strongly recommend).Summing up, the movie is well written, acted, directed, shot and paced and if you're not in an overly pensive mood, this film, although not Weir's finest work, is yet another evidence of its skill in the 7th art. Unfortunately, the fact that the movie didn't do very well at the box office means that future "location is the ocean" pictures will be either a thing of the past or a fluffy adventure flick (like the curse of the Caribbeans).8.5 out of 10 in my FilmOmeter.P.S. Just in case you were wondering, "Ausies" is a nickname for Australians which is where Weir was born and where Crowe lives. Cheers, mates!
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: A rollicking seafaring epic featuring some of the most authentic maritime ship combat ever put to film. Crowe offers one of this finest performances as Captain "lucky Jack" and the supporting characters are all masterfully done as well.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: A cinematic masterclass in realism and acting
Review_body: This is a wonderful film that speaks of a time when ships were wood and men were iron. The Royal Navy truly shaped the modern world we know and understand today. It was a time when our ships, Royal Navy, Merchantmen and indeed, Privateers, ruled the waves with their bravery, discipline and determination. Master and Commander is a true classic that will stand the test of time, because the era it speaks of is timeless. The performances were all magnificent but the real stars were the ships Surprise and Acharon. The detail was amazing and I really felt the Visual Effects team really should have received an Oscar, it was just unfortunate they were up against The Lord of the Rings that year. I rate this film very highly and would recommend it to anyone wishing to see a historically accurate and highly memorable piece of cinema. 10 out of 10
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: Good seafaring movie, probably the best pure seafaring movie of all time as some critics claim but not the best sea movie, the Hunt for Red Octobober and Titanic are a step above it. Stars Russel Crowe and Paul Bettany as they try to take down a french vessel called the Acheron, whose captain seems to get the best of Lucky Jack. The movie mainly focuses on the relationship between Maturin and Aubrey, though screen time is given to the crew and how sea life was back then. The dialogue throughout the movie is laced with nautical terms and slang that adds to the authentic feel of the movie. Action sequences are top notch and the graphical shots hard to spot. Directing is excellent, as is to be expected from Peter Weir. The problem with the movie is that we don;t connect enough with any of the characters to really care about what happens to them. The only two individuals i cared about were midshipmen Blakeney and Hollom, while the rest of the cast seemed caricatured. Another problem is that the hero Aubrey is not as charismatic as a fellow character in the same vein by the name of Hornblower. PErharps this is due to the numerous films in that series compared to only one here but we feel every emotion with Hornblower, while with Aubrey, we relate to his as we would relate to our remote, he is just a label (captain)doing his job (leading). I realize this is a setup movie and it is a fantastic start but not deserving of a best picture nomination, that only shows the relative weakness of movies this year.Summary: Good picture but stick with the Hornblower series
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: Believe me...it is a great movie
Review_body: I saw Master and Commander with average expectations, I thought it would kinda like Gladiator on high seas and a little overweighted...well it wasn't, it was actually a pleasant surprise.The plot although generic, is enough to push a great epic adventure. Russel Crowe plays Captain Jack, an old fashioned, hard boiled British captain who gets obsessed with the idea of bringing a French ship down. In the meantime, dozens of misadventures are lived and blood spilled.Sometimes it might feel the movie tries to append many many subplots within the main plot, but I did not find them distracting at all, and they all added dramatism and depth to the characters in the ship. It is weird to see an all male movie though, I can't remember when was the last time I saw one.After I saw the film, I have been trying to persuade my friends and family to see it, but no one seems to believe me this is a great, fun, and exciting movie with adventures from beginning to end and great acting from all people involved. So take my word, board this ship and live a major adventure.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: Beautiful, lovingly crafted film is a visual and audio treat
Review_body: "Master and Commander" was well worthy of its 10 Academy Award nominations. It is rare these days to come across a film that is this intelligently scripted and directed. It is wonderfully subtle, sensitive and powerfully moving at times, occasionally humorous, and yet tense and gripping at other times. The attention to visual and audio detail is incredibly rich and makes owning on DVD well worthwhile. Every time I have watched this I have discovered new details previously unnoticed.I saw this film before I had read any of the Patrick O'Brian books upon which it is based, and I have to give Peter Weir and his crew even more credit after having become familiar with the novels. While the film borrows snippets from several of the books, and is only loosely based on "The Far Side of the World", I am extremely impressed with and appreciative of the attention that was paid to the characters' personas and relationships to each other. This film was obviously put together by people who greatly admired and respected O'Brian's creations.Some naysayers here have accused this film of lacking plot, and I have to wonder if they understand what the word means. In addition to the main plot involving the tense and fascinating cat-and-mouse chase between the Surprise and the French privateer, there are various sub-plots involving the relationships between Captain Aubrey and Doctor Maturin as well as the other officers, midshipmen, and rest of the crew. There is something gripping going on in almost every scene, providing plenty of pace to the film.The acting is excellent and the always charismatic Russell Crowe makes a perfect Aubrey in my opinion. The Maturin of the novels is a bit darker character than what is presented in the film, but Paul Bettany does such a wonderful job with the role that that is not even worth a criticism.An excellent soundtrack employing lush, classical music adds to the enjoyment of the film.My only regret is that they don't make nearly enough films of this kind any more...one of my top favorites in our DVD library.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: Could have been so much more...
Review_body:
The film had everything epics need... great scenery... brave leaders... some fighting and a big budget. Still somehow the film fails to deliver. Scenes where you should feel suspense and/or tension... are a bit slow and a bit boring. The action scenes are few and far between.
    I liked the movie... but I gave it a 7 in 10. I know a bit about Naval Warfare and History and so my interest was bigger than the average male moviegoer.     Good points ? Beautiful ships. Really nice work there. Crowe seems a bit awkward as a british captain at first... but convinces us as the movie rolls on. Some of the secondary characters are neat too. The story has its good points... the acting is medium mostly. The battle scenes are a treat too.    With a bit better pacing, acting and story this would have been a great movie. All the right ingredients... but a bit overcooked perhaps ?
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: During the Napoleonic wars a British warship commanded by Russel Crowe's character is mysteriously attacked by a French warship. The captain who had no idea that this was coming takes it as a blow to his ego and despite the ship and the morale of his men being damaged, decides to go after his newfound nemesis.Seems fun? Not really. The film moves along at a very slow pace and doesn't really manage to truly grab your attention. The characters, though decently acted, are weak with Crowe definitely not giving one of his better performances. He just doesn't have enough things to work with to make himself interesting. Well maybe I can ignore that but what really got on my nerves is that Peter Weir has simply made the whole 138 minute movie into one long stream. The tension, which could have given a lot to the movie is virtually non existent. It makes it seem like being attacked by the most powerful warship in the French navy is no different than having a cup of tea.As for more technical things, it really annoyed me that there was so little music. That too could have added suspense and more life into this dull picture. The cinematography was pretty good, though somewhat difficult to comprehend at times. The ships and costumes of course were excellent and filled with detail. The battle scenes, or what little there was of them were pretty well done but yet again, as seems to be the case with most Hollywood films, confusing and a bit too shaky at parts for one to understand what is going on.All in all not that bad of a film but if you are looking for something along the lines of excitement like Pirates of the Carribbean then this is not your picture.6/10
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: OK, forget what the film leaves out from the book.  O'Brian wrote a 20 novel long saga and the movie takes bits from a few to make this.  O'Brian was never that interested in the plot, but more the human side and the emotional drama and that is what Weir has given us.  I was worried this movie would dumb down the book and leave us with a meat-headed action-fest, but it captures the flavour of O'Brian's canon so well.  The music of Jack and Stephen, the conflict between the warrior and the scientist, but still with the friendship that underpins it.  What also makes this film excellent is the human side to the HMS Surprise:  it's not the ship or the mission that is important, it's the crew...we see the men bond, whether below decks or in the wardroom with the good natured officers.  So many Hollywood movies portray the British as pompous, tea drinking stuffed shirts obsessed with class.  In M&C, they are not mere national stereotypes but men with feelings who show joy, playfulness, devotion to duty, superstition, bravery and deep sadness and remorse.  When characters are killed, we feel their loss and share it with the survivors.  And that's the wonderful subtext to Weir's movie; the human element of a bygone age.  I feel he truly understands O'Brian's work not as nautical potboilers, but as a character study of the men who fought in the age of fighting sail.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: The idea of life on the sea, living our adventure after adventure, has always fascinated me. This is the first real movie of that nature that I have seen (save "Pirates of the Caribbean"). The story is of a crew during the Napoleonic Wars that are on a mission to take down another ship. Of course, the other ship has the same orders, resulting in several scenes of cannons damaging said ships. The lead stars, Russell Crowe as the captain and Paul Bettany as the doctor, are a great pair whom you may remember from "A Beautiful Mind". The film is well done and realistic. The only downfall is that it is a bit difficult to follow and it is somewhat slow on top of that. It is definitely worth watching, but just be aware.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: This movie is one of my all time favorites. I think it was the tiniest fraction away from becoming one of the greatly regarded movies of our day. It had everything: great cast, superb direction, marvelous action, believable sets, and incredible cinematography. I believe one thing alone held it back, and that was the choice of music.Throughout the movie we have the recurring theme of Crowe's and Bellamy's characters playing stringed duets. Wonderful tho they may be, they are less then stirring, and detract, more then contribute, to the overall atmosphere of the the picture. Had this movie had an original epic musical score to match the epic proportions of the rest of the production, people would still be talking about this movie as one of the greatest of all time.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: Russell Crowe and Paul Bettany deliver spectacular performances inside a well oiled and detailed film that smacks of classical and vintage colonials ship battles.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: wonderful, and unusual as great all ages
Review_body: there is nothing amiss in this victorian sea adventure, but nothing; you could watch it alone, with your kids- and then wonder why no follow on; the characters are personal, precise, interesting, intelligent; there are heroes young and old, a driven plot line that keeps pushing the story forward, very amusing asides, very realistic life on board, danger, music, science- all wrapped up in an unlikely package that is purely and consistently entertaining; of course, reserve 10s for movies that have a lasting message; this one has lasting moments; crowe consistently in character with bravura and subtlety; bettany (if you've seen his one-off performance in gangster no. 1) reversed in a cunningly sensitive role- and aside from that interestingly shot, edited, locales; can't miss with this- and, again, begging for a master and commander 2
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: "Master and Commander" is Patrick O'Brian's first published seafaring novel featuring the early-1800's characters "Lucky Jack" Aubrey, a British Navy careerist, and Stephen Maturin, a true Renaissance Man born four centuries too late. There followed nineteen more novels in the series featuring this odd but endearing pair, until O'Brian died in his 86th year.Patrick O'Brian has been described as one of the truly great story-telling writers of modern times. His books certainly bear out that characterization. Read them and you'll see why!The movie is taken from material of several of the early books, but it stitches all that stuff together into a great story standing on its own merit, which rings true to the spirit of the O'Brian sea novels.And the movie has fine casting and acting, and really top-rate cinematography. View it, and you'll see why!
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: Another Masterpiece from Australian Director Peter Weir
Review_body: I put this DVD into the player simply looking for some light afternoon entertainment, but instead found a really good movie...The scene for this movie is set rather quickly, as a British frigate (HMS Surprise) captained by "Lucky" Jack Aubrey (Russell Crowe) is stalked by a larger and faster French warship, in the treacherous seas off South America. The year is 1805.After setting the scene, director Peter Weir concentrates on character development and we get to know Captain Aubrey and some of his crew, and become aware of the friendship (and at times conflict) between the captain and the ship's doctor (Paul Bettany). The other central character is Blakeney (Max Pirkis), a young and likable Midshipman.The story traces the voyage of the HMS Surprise as it sails down the coast of South America, via the picturesque Galapagos Islands, and tension steadily mounts as the movie reaches a climax with the final sea battle.Other excellent movies directed by Australian Peter Weir include Dead Poets Society and The Truman Show.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: Why is this movie praised so highly???
Review_body: The critics and public seem to LOVE this film. Why?I saw it with great expectations after reading such raving reviews.Yes, the sea battles are very well executed. Yes, the sound is deserving of an Oscar nomination. And yes, there are some cool scenes in with ships in the fog.BUT, the bottom line is this movie was boring! The story was completely unoriginal. The characters were nothing we haven't seen before. And worse is how they crammed so much completely irrelevant "fluff" into the film just to stretch out it's length. (What was the point of the whole Jonah side story?)Russel Crowe is a fine actor, but he was completely wasted in this. The role was absolutely nothing special.I was so bored I almost left the theater!I gave it 4 out of 10, only for some nice visuals and sound.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: the worst movie of the year!
Review_body: There are many things wrong with this movie. First of all, a good story should take into the plot before the first hour rushes by, and there has to be a meaning in a movie that will keep the audience begging for more; not falling asleep in their chairs and snoring louder than the sound of a bullet being shot from a gun. And the bottom line pretty much is that SOMETHING HAS TO HAPPEN IN THE FRICKIN MOVIE!!!!!!!! There is not even 30 seconds of action one minute, and then it's just singing folk songs on the ship and eating slop while celebrating. And worst of all, they make jokes that aren't even funny! I'm sorry to say that to the people that worked 3 years on this movie that it completely sucks and it was a complete waste of their valuable time. I'm not much of a war movie fan, but I know a bad movie when I see one, no matter what genre. I understand that this is a war movie telling a true story about actual people, but it's not worthy of being shown on the big screen.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: This film reminds me an era when Director's and Producers wanted to make an epic, didn't matter what the cost was, they just wanted to make a good film that both excites you and makes you think. Russell Crowe gives his most daring performance in years, fans of the O'Brien books thought he couldn't do a real man's performance, he was known as dreamy Russell before now. Crowe is not only being compared to Tom Hanks , but compared to the greatest actors of our time, like Tom Cruise and Sean Penn, and now he's being placed in the category of Marlon Brando and Peter O' Toole.  He not only brought back the sandle movies, but now he's bringing back the swash bucklers, wow.THE PLOTThe film is about CPT. Jack Aubrey(known as lucky jack), and his sidekick the doctor(Paul Bettany). They embark on a journey to hunt down an enemy ship, but this isn't the test, this is a journey of finding one's self and coming together to conquer their fears."Master And Commander: The Far Side Of The World" is an incredible film that will entrance you into the ocean and put you into the minds of the men and CPT. Jack Aubrey. But something is missing, Paul Bettany, he's great in this film but he doesn't have the same intensity that he had in "A Beautiful Mind", or maybe he's not sopose to. Even with that flaw, this is still an acheivement, and nothing can stop in the way of the new rein of actors, and I hope to see more of this cast including Russell Crowe and Paul Bettany.I give this film ****(out of 4 stars).
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: All the elements are of high standard - the acting, the action, the effects, the costumes, the sets, the characters and the story as a whole.It takes great skill to show so much of life of the time in a two hour movie, and make us care about characters who we've only seen small amounts of at a time. You feel for all these people as they deal with the situation and events they find themselves in.What was really amazing is that the enemy is essentially faceless, not given time to be a character, it's all about the crew we're following and their perspective on the battle.This is one if Russell Crowes best performances, and a real surprise from Peter Weir as a director.Highly recommend!
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: This is a film all about atmosphere, authenticity and emotion.In a film climate where audiences are encouraged to view film that have big twists, turns, action sequences or emotional revelation, it is testament to the quality of Master and Commander that it was a box office sucess, despite being all about the essence of being at sea.I admit that I was a sucker for this movie from the very start: my favourite filmic location is probably a boat at night (and there is quite a bit of that in 'Commander) but that was not to say I expected to love the film - I was sceptical about it, in truth.After viewing I was thoroughly convinced of the atmosphere on board a Napoleonic wars battle ship.
