Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: One of my criteria for great art on film is being able to see spectacle that one would normally not be able to see. I love films that carry me away to another time and another place, to see remarkable things. Master and Commander reminded me of classic adventure films from the last century, done with impeccable modern and seamless special effects and authenticity. Like, you could not obviously see CG in use, or notice scaled down models. I think it is a remarkable film on all counts, acting, cinematography and visuals, story, costumes, music, and detailed authenticity. Even the editing is noticeably superior, because action sequences are fast paced, yet easy to follow (unlike other contemporary actioners using the ultra-close, blurred and jumbled mish-mosh that is in vogue). Acknowledging that there were many other great films in Oscar contention this year (2003), I believe Master and Commander was the BEST PICTURE (but unfortunately released the same year as the conclusion of a great trilogy, which had to finally receive a collective Oscar recognition). I especially loved that the naval strategies made some sense. Both the hero and his adversary were wily, smart fighters and strong leaders, and you could understand why the crew wanted to follow them. The characters were all likable and all of them were superbly acted. My favorites were Captain Aubery, the Doctor/Naturalist (played by Paul Bettany), and the young Midshipman, Mr. Blakeney, whose characters were wonderfully developed. It is somewhat violent, but I highly recommend Master and Commander for everyone. I love this film.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: Absolutely fantastic. The set design, story, cinematography, performances, and overall film is striking from beginning to end. Apparently the historical accuracy is one of the few films that stays true not only to that being said, but also the books story is very on point. This is definitely a film worth investing your time in.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: Master & Commander is flawlessly helmed by Peter Weir, who once again proves he is one of the most important filmmakers working today. His direction is masterful, creating an atmosphere in which the audience becomes fully emerged in the story. The film is aided tremendously by Bettany, who after only seeing previously in a Beautiful Mind (also starring Crowe), gives a surprisingly strong and memorable performance. Crowe is perfectly cast.A wonderfully memorable sea adventure, and one of the year's best films.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: Definately one of the best Warship movies i've ever seen.  Peter Weir captivates us into this Epic 19th Century Sea Battle which includes great action and drama.  Russell Crowe is Captain "Lucky Jack" Aubrey, a profound admirable leader to his shipmates. Together they go through an extraordinary sea adventure. Russell Crowe plays yet another brilliant and indepth character like in all of his movies. He definately captures the ideal leader to his "country" or ship; the kind of commander we all long to have and admire. Hands down this has to be one of the best movies i've seen so far this year.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: I enjoyed this film because I recently read about Darwin and captain FitzRoy on board of the Beagle (some decades later). I found it interesting to see this environment realistically presented in a movie, and the controversies between Darwin and FitzRoy were similar as in the movie.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: A Beginning, A Middle, Well what about
Review_body: To supply more than what has already been stated would be simple repetition. The cinematography and scene direction superb.The battle scenes were really well done. Russell Crowe brought a good sense of what Lucky Jack Aubrey was. He really tried. To Crowe's credit, he really does that well.Albeit after working on the water, Crowe's version would come across as a bit of a milquetoast. Yet at the end of the day, I still feel someone else could have been cast in the role. If one doesn't think so, then compare Jürgen Prochnow's portrayal of Capt.-Lt. Henrich Lehmann-Willenbrock in Das Boot. Then sit back and compare the two movies.Master and Commander also suffered from plot disjointness which made no naval sense. Any good French privateer wanting real prizes, would be heading for Madasgar, or the Seychelles. Even Tahiti made no real sense in naval terms.Knocking off whalers at the Galapagos with your top ship of the line makes absolutely no strategic sense to begin with. Suppose these whalers shipped out of Portsmouth, well it would make more sense to stick the bow on station outside Portsmouth. Further the Galapagos is one fifth of the earth's circumference away from the Horn. Heck of a journey for a ship of that period.There was nothing there for a top ship of the line. A schooner could have done the same thing against whalers more efficiently. And any admiral would have given such orders.And there are tons of places to lay in wait such as the Falklands if your into whaling, Jamaica or Trinidad if your into money. Or off the coast of North America in the Gulf of St. Lawrence.So I didn't buy the premise of the movie. Further at the end, it sucked. I cannot believe for a minute that a Captain, any Captain, would break escort when two ships having undergone pitched battle. So the ending dropped the ball so to speak.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: The star easily says it sucks.
Review_body: There is only one Russle Crowe movie i hae ever liked and that was LA Confidential because of a good plaot, Kim Basinger, and of course the magnificent Kevin Spacey.  Anyway, every Russel Crowe movie sucked.  Erin Brockovich or chocolot or traffic should have beat Gladiator for best picture because i fell asleep-and i even wanted to see it in theaters (i always like movies i want to see).  The story looks dumb.  Only good "over the seas" movie swere Titanic and Pirate sof the Carribean.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: I have seen Master And Commander twice and will make an effort to see it again before it leaves the big screen. Overall the the thing that impressed me most about this movie is how I found myself completely engrossed from beginning to end.  Magnificent acting, directing,sound, and the musical score. There appeared to be a great deal of attention to detail regarding authenticity of costumes, nautical language,props,etc..  Russell Crow was outstanding.  Encouraging to see Hollywood bring to bear its resources of writing, creativity, talent, and technology in producing a great film like this.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: This movie got it right. The perfect blend of realism and storytelling. Really now, who didn't like this movie? If you thought it was boring, go take your Ritalen and watch it again. No, I am not being mean to anyone with ADHD, my point is you need to slow your life down to more than just a few sound bytes from MTV. This is a take your time and smell the roses kind of movie. Watch it with a good bottle of wine and I swear you can almost smell the salt air.This kind of movie only comes along once in a while. You have to appreciate like a fine wine and it will grow on you through subsequent viewings. My only suggestion to those that didn't like it is try it again. Enjoy it, own it.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: Overarching story allows small seafaring episodes to be told.
Review_body: Quite good. Assumes that the audience is paying attention. Can tell that it comes from a [book] series since this movie starts and stops rather than begins and ends. Consists of a series of seafaring scenarios told while the overarching storyline keeps the movie moving towards a stopping point. Different supporting roles rotate into the limelight and are dealt with dramatically. While this might not sound great, it works well here. This movie is directed by Peter Weir, afterall. Lots of seafaring action, some of which actually makes sense! Much of the dialogue is muffled, but it, nevertheless, has its own compass and logical direction. Crowe will get a nomination out of this.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: Mr. Gladiator plays a British captain hunting a better, faster, younger ship.Some interesting things in there. I didn't realize kids so young were in the Navy. It was also fun seeing battles with older, limited technology, where each maneuver might take a day or two, instead of the high-speed heat seeking death-at-the-push-of-a-button we're used to today.Still, the movies was absolutely mediocre. I can't really point out huge flaws, but I can't recall anything that grabbed me either. Actually, the twist at the very end had promise as I worried about the young captain on his own, but that didn't end up going anywhere as the movie immediately ended.Someone had highly recommended this movie to me, while another had spewed bile all over it. My advice is, if you've got nothing else to do, go ahead and watch it, but if you have anything at all to do, you won't miss much skipping it.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: After many of my friends labeled this movie as the "most boring thing they'd ever seen" I felt very uneasy. What's gone wrong? Could Peter Weir be capable of producing a "bad" film? After hiring and watching this film I was astounded. M&C is one of the most compelling pieces of cinema I've ever seen. Absolutely absorbing in every respect it affirms Peter Wier as one of the best story-tellers working in Hollywood today.M&C follows the story of an English Navy vessel as it pursues a far superior French vessel down the South American coast during the Napoleonic wars. But it is not the plot itself that makes this film superb, it's the way in which it is presented.The film's strength comes from it's blending of adventure, setting and character development. Weir doesn't focus on 'goody ship chases baddie ship' but gives great attention to how the characters react when put under such straining circumstances. Also evident is a genuine sense of atmosphere and setting. The production design, screenplay and acting lend themselves to the period in which the film is set. Consequently, the film strips away much of the more sensational aspects of an adventure flick, making the reality on screen appear entirely credible and engaging.Every acting performance is spot on. Each minor character is distinctive and stereotypes are completely absent from the film. Russel Crowe is fantastic as "Lucky Jack", superbly presenting the captain's charisma as well as the internal conflict between his ego and sense of duty. However, it is Paul Bettany who shines as Jack's confidant and intimate friend. The best performance of his career.Praise must also go the cinematography. Russel Boyd's visuals are superb. The film never resorts to extravagant special effects, instead focusing on a realistic and gritty portrayal of life on a navy vessel even during action sequences. The first time a cannonball flies over the bow I felt as though the projectile was about to crash through the screen and into my lounge room. Thank god, the annoying 'hand-held' camera technique is absent. Regardless of this, the sound and visuals are quite evocative.To appreciate any film, you must appreciate it for what it is, not against a set of preconceptions you have about what it 'should' be like. If like my friends you want mindless action steer well clear. If you are after a compelling, atmospheric and dramatic adventure film, Master and Commander shines above any other.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: Not Too Bad Since I Like Both MUTINY ON THE BOUNTY's
Review_body: I noticed in MASTER AND COMMANDER that a lot of camera shots and angles resembled ones from MUTINY ON THE BOUNTY 1935 and 1962.  Consequently, I worked myself right into enjoying the film completely.Russell Crowe keeps convincing me that he can play any role put in front of him.  After LA CONFIDENTIAL, GLADIATOR, and A BEAUTIFUL MIND, I believe that he can even tackle the ultimate macho role: 007 (Move over, Pierce).The most pleasant surpise that I found throughout the film occurred within the reunion between Russell Crowe and Paul Bettany (Dr. Stephen Maturin) as they played the two main characters.  The chemistry that they displayed in A BEAUTIFUL MIND created a genuine friendship between them that spilled over seemlessly into this movie; they really care about each other in it.I can't wait for the next one...and I plan to read a few of Patrick O'Brien's books to see what everyone keeps praising so much within them.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: The best movie that sailed the seven seas
Review_body: Although only winning two out of the ten academy awards nominated for the movie, "Master and Commander: The Far Side of the World" is my absolute favorite. The determination, the battles, the locations, and the entire ship itself is pure perfection. Leading the ship "Surprise" is post-captain Jack Aubrey, a fierce, determined captain set out to follow the French  privateer "Acheron" to either destroy it, or take it as a prize. Aubrey is accompanied by his best friend, Dr. Stephen Maturin, a man who is opposite Jack. He is resourceful and philosophical compared to Jack's need to get the ship. Fondly called Lucky Jack by his crew, he engages the Acheron at the beginning of the movie, which includes the loosing of his rudder and the need to pull his oat into the heavy fog. The rest of the movie is the determination of Jack to get this ship and take it back to England as a prize. Peter Weir masterfully directs the movie on the boat, and on location in the Galapagos. My new favorite movie, as it will be for the next few years. 5 stars from over here!!!
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: For those in peril on the sea
Review_body: I am working my way through the Jack Aubrey/Patrick O'Brian series of historical novels and thought it would b a good idea to see the film of Master and Commander. I was a bit apprehensive about the castings and in some cases they definitely did not work. However, thinking that Russell Crowe was not right for Jack Aubrey, having seen the movie, all I can say is I can't see anyone else doing a better job. In the books, this is a man with a zest for life, courageous and maybe a bit reckless - Russell Crowe captures this very well. Still not sure about the Maturin casting because he is definitely a man who is not what he seems and that does not come across. Boden - also not quite right. However, this is a proper rendition of the period and the spirit of the books. I can only say I wish they had made more - the books do have quite a few love interests in them so this would have been good to see. Of course, it must have been expensive to film but this is what film is made for - beautiful cinematography, great set pieces, a good story and really sound acting - much better than all the action hero stuff that is out there.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: I am taking the plunge, and giving this movie my first "10" rating.In the mid-18th century, Russell Crowe, a Commander of a British Man Of War ship, faithfully discharges his duties to the Royal Navy and the King, pursuing a troublesome French warship which is larger, more heavily armed, and of a higher class than his own. He must use all his skills and leadership abilities to overcome his superior foe.Excellent acting all around in this movie. Life aboard a British warship in the 1700s was quite rough, with most crews being treated by their officers as little more than prisoners. However, Russell Crowe has all the military education of old-school Royal Navy, without any meanness or narcissism. He is a firm leader of his men, who brooks no nonsense, but refuses to be unnecessarily cruel. He displays a high degree of personal integrity, and treats everyone, regardless of rank or station in life, with respect. As a result, his crew has complete faith in his leadership - their loyalty is unswerving, and this plays a very crucial part in what is to come.Encounters with the French warship are unsuccessful at first; Crowe is forced to retreat, to avoid destruction, but does so with a cleverness that amuses his men, and their morale does not suffer from the defeat. In their extensive travels, the Brits enjoy some interesting diversions, including exploration of the Galapagos Islands. There are casualties, including the Captain (Crowe) himself, and an intriguing sequence where the ship's surgeon is accidentally shot through the abdomen, and must operate on himself, with an assistant holding a mirror. The youngest officer on board is gravely wounded in battle, his arm smashed by a musket ball, and must undergo an amputation, without anesthesia. Barely a teenager, he not only endures, but impresses all with his courage and strength, fully recovering (except for the loss of his arm) without complaint. This boy-officer even plays a key role in a pitched battle with the Frensh warship, boarding the enemy ship and fighting hand-to-hand with the enemy. The sailors he commands - all much older men than himself - are literally spellbound by his performance in battle. The crew, impressed by their Captain's leadership and humanity, draws strength from him, as he does from them.It is a story of bravery, intelligence, coolness under adversity, and true leadership ability. The Captain is far above the norm in this regard, and his performance is inspirational - not only for his crew, but for the audience watching this movie. All of us wish that we had leaders like this man in our lives and workplaces.Of course, I will not reveal the ending lol. You must watch this movie, but I highly recommend it. It's a "10". It's a "must see, don't miss".
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: The film captures the essence of the Patrick O'Brien novels as well as being the most authentic piece of 19th century ship warfare action ever seen. The characterisation, storyline and pace are as good as cinema gets. The script explores leadership issues, relationships and duty in subtle ways, fitting in to the main theme of hunting down a French frigate more powerful and with much greater firepower. Zoology, entomology and baroque music are all featured, as well as surgery and philosophy. The scenes of rounding Cape Horn were filmed on a vessel doing just that that and bring home the everyday hazards that all seamen faced in the early 1800s. All rounded off with some memorable music, some of it actually played by Russell Crowe who learned the violin for the part. I can't praise the creativity, skill and special effects that went into this film too highly.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body:
This film defines what it means to be a masterpiece, sets a style to imitate, withstands the passage of time making it even more beautiful ...
It is undoubtedly the best ever made of all those that have a naval theme, and incomprehensibly it had no continuation despite there being more novels to follow the story.
In short, a movie that will become a classic in decades and will always be remembered.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: The movie was pretty nice. Overall i'd give it a 4/5. It's wroth mentioning though that this movie is not a "war" movie! In fact, 70% of the movie is Drama, and a little part (30%) is war. Some scenes were OBVIOUSLY fake (so the production was not "that" rich"), but again, the essence of the movie is worth watching. If you wanna see good water (storm) graphics, "The Perfect Storm" would be a better choice.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: Master and Commander: Awesome and Breath-taking
Review_body: In 'Master and Commander' Russell Crowe delivers a performance equal to his role as Maximus in Gladiator. He brings Captain Jack Aubrey to life, making him perfectly brilliant and courageous. Crowe's supporting cast is priceless. Filled with stars and others that aren't too known in Hollywood, the casting is superb. From Paul Bettany (if you recall, he played Charles, Nash's roommate, in 'A Beautiful Mind') as Dr. Stephen Maturin, to James D'Arcy as 1st Lt. Tom Pullings and new young faces such as Max Benitz and and Max Pirkis ... the cast is perfect.The cinematography is awesome, taking the audience from the middle of the ocean to foreign islands. The different colors bring this movie to life and create a feeling as if you're actually under Captain Jack's command and experiencing right there with the crew.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: I saw an advanced screening of Master and Commander. I was really excited to see it, considering that I loved Peter Weir's past work. Especially Truman Show and Fearless.The movie starts off in the heart of the sea. Weir does a great job of establishing the surroundings. The movie is basically a cat and mouse movie. It goes nowhere and it's very talkative.The huge problem with the movie is that it is incredibly slow paced, the characters aren't interesting, and it never really gets past the first act. The goals seem unimportant and the plot is really uninteresting. The dialogue is bad at times and tries too hard other times.Besides some nice special effects, this has to be one of the slowest movies of the year. I really hope this movie doesn't get any Academy Award nominations besides visual effects.On a scale of 1-4, I would give Master and Commander a 1. I don't know what movie critics saw. I saw a mess of a movie.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: Master and Commander: The Far Side of the World 6/10 stars
Review_body: I saw Master and Commander last night, and it a really well put together film however, the plot is pretty weak, the HMS Suprise (Crow's ship) is attacked at the begining and so the Surpise try's to hunt down the ship that attacked them. The acting was really good. But, the plot and dialouge wasn't that strong. There were lots of parts that had nothing to do with the plot, and useually that is to build character for you to like or dislike the characters but I really didn't care if anybody died or not. But that isn't the acting that was bad, just a weak weak script. There wasn't much meat to this movie, and if this movie is nominated for any Academy Awards for acting (the script made the acting weak), someone is getting robed. Master and Commander 6/10
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: GOOD: Its a great look into Navel life in the 1800's
Review_body: This film was not brillient like it should of been but it was good. It really got me interested into the Navy in the 1800's and mostly Lord Nelson of whom is mensioned once in the film.I wish instead of this film that they would of done a film on Nelson as he was real person and Capt Aubrey is fictional.7/10. a good watch for people who are interested in the napoleonic wars but its not a brillient film.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: This was a great pleasant surprise, as I found the trailer rather mediocre and thus I went to the cinema with low expectations, figuring that this would possibly be another heroic Hollywood drama full of clichés. However, I was overwhelmed with joy. In addition to be an adventurous and thrilling movie, it is full of humour and personality, and it also seems quite authentic historically. The tension and special relationship among the crew mid-sea in wartime in the early 1800s is very charmingly described. I think Crowe and Bettany play excellently together. Crowe has the authority, the sympathy as well as the doubt that one would expect of a convincing captain Aubrey - my only complaint is that he does not seem convincingly British. I am really happy that the project was laid in Peter Weir's hands, he never disappoints. Quite a relief also that this was not made into a simple, superficial Hollywood drama by adding unnecessary love stories or such, which is always my worst fear about "masculine" movies. Oh no, this movie is full of manhood and in my opinion it does not at all suffer from not including any female characters. I can't say much about the degree of being true to the original story as I haven't read Peter O'Brian books yet, but at least this movie has surely made me want to read them - and I expect them to be even better (the books usually are)!
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: "Aubrey, may I trouble you for the salt?"
Review_body: From start to finish, this movie had me feeling every emotion, except hate. I found the brotherhood outstanding, the witty dialog at times near on side splitting, for e.g. When Aubrey suckered Maturin into the Weevil analysis. Maturin's response was equally as funny, but then Bettany has the ability to rise to the occasion in practically every role I have seen him in. Crowie, once again, Brings a fictional Character to life, and if you didn't know any better, you would think the story was based off a real life account. Killick, he kills me, " Killick" yells Aubrey for the Albermarle, " I'm already ere in-nit I " I have watched this flick now about 10 times, and I just don't tire of it, because each time something else catches my eye. I wish I could just climb aboard that vessel and experience the sea-dog life, as I am a sailor from way back. All the Actors in this movie, collaborate to make it a memorable epic. Weir When are you doing another? If you do, get Crowie and Bettany back, and Killick please. Loved it.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: Lack of handling and to much talking in the movie. Looks like an cheap movie in action.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: And the point of this movie was ????
Review_body: Ok, so the scenery was spectacular, and the sailing ships were a beauty to behold, and there were some moments of good acting.  But over two hours of watching Russell Crowe and his band of merry men chase down another sailing ship on the high seas was a bit much.  The plot was pretty thin, and after a while, it felt like I was watching the same movie a second time.  Unless you're *really* into watching a few beautiful sailing scenes, save your $8+ and rent the movie when it's released to DVD in a few months.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: This movie is a masterpiece, plain and simple.  A poetic time machine that transport us to the world of the beginning of the 19th Century.  The story, characters, pace, music, photography, etc. are just perfect.  Peter Weir is one Master Director that has not been seduced by the MTV-video-fast-paced-no story- no characters-movies and still respects his audience, giving us a truly masterpiece that probably won't be at the reach of the common viewer. With this work of art, Peter Weir deserves the Oscar as Best Director, the one that he should've gotten long time ago.. Gallipoli.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: Nothing special about this movie.  There is no real story in the script and it is long and draggy.  The final (actually the only battle not counting some cannon shots here and there had to wait the whole length of the movie for it) battle was confusing I could not figure out who are the Brits and who are the French.  Besides the main characters in action, you only people in plain clothes fighting each other and got blown away.  In contrast, The Last Samurai is so much better movie and the battles sequences were much better!
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: A perfect distillation of the Aubrey/Maturin Novels
Review_body: As a fan of the books, this movie perfectly distils the essence of the O'Brians works. The life aboard a man o'war during the Napoleonic Wars was hard and often brutal, and the battle scenes are violent and life often short.However it is in the relationships aboard the ship - where women are a vague, lusted for concept - where this movie shines. The very different characters in Aubrey (Crowe) and Maturin (Bettany) are the best of friends, and it is their relationship that provides the balance in the books and movie. The friendships and yes, passion that the men have for each other in the face of war and weather is so well teased out without being overt of maudlin. The acting is perfect and the cast well suited to their various roles.Soundtrack and cinematography are sublime and create the world that seems so similar to ours, but worked on very different ideas.One my favourite movies of all time. Long may the HMS Surprise sail.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body:
There is just not much of interest happening here. Yet another in a series of recent movies that goes over the 2 hour mark for no appreciable reason- the business of the plot could have been taken care of in 40 minutes. The rest is filled in with observing beetles and a flogging scene which doesn't serve much purpose except maybe they felt the movie was running low on homoeroticism (besides repeated use of the word "seaman" of course)Don't be fooled- this is absolutely nothing like "Gladiator." They both contain combat and R. Crowe- that's about it. The script is episodic, lazily put together- maybe this worked as a book but little effort has been made to structure this into something the audience can care about.
Kind of typical of adaptations of novels- they jump through so many hoops, like changing the villains from American in the book to French for the benefit of the historically uninformed in the audience (that'll teach 'em to help us achieve independance and give us the Statue of Liberty!)- but at the end of the day they would've been better off writing a story from scratch that works on the big screen. "Gladiator" is a great original screenplay, this is a half-hearted, half-assed adaptation that goes way too many directions at once and never builds any tension whatsoever.I was fidgeting in my seat throughout. I kept hoping it would break into unintentional comedy but that never quite happens either- it just sort of meanders along, there's a big battle, and it ends.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: Not an action movie, really a humanistic movie
Review_body: The trailers for this movie were deceiving, but so are most. Its sad trailers have to put in almost every action scene they have just to get people's attention, but in this case action played very little in Master and Commander.There are some very well done action scenes, but this was really a movie about life on a navy battleship in the early 1800's. It was interesting seeing, for what maybe was the first time, all the children who lived on the boat with the men (scary thought), and brought home the origin of the term, son-of-a-gun. (Look up the origin, it's interesting.) Even some of the officers were just teenagers.But even as a human drama and a "this is how they used to live back then", the movie still came up short at time. This movie had greatly done cinematography, but the story itself was poorly told and dragged many times. (The excuse that that was how life was on ships sometimes is no excuse; you don't have to show 15 minutes of nothing happening to give people an idea that nothing is happening.) Another shortcoming was that the director wasn't able to convey a sense of time lapse. One scene would cut to the next, and then they casually mention 3 weeks have gone by, but you never get a sense of that. But the arguments between the captain and the ship's doctor were good, most of the actors did a great job, and again there was very good camera work and the action sequences were done well.I'd rate it a 7/10, but again, don't think this is an action movie.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: Not only good action, but good history; plus outstanding novel adaptation
Review_body: Master and Commander is one of my favorite action movies set in real history. The characters and plot of the movie borrow from Patrick O'Brian's famous series with a real attention to the spirit of his writing. O'Brian is well known for his attention to detail and his ease in creating a fictional world so believable and real, it is almost like stepping into a time machine. I believe Master and Commander is one of the few movies in which I can honestly say IS as good as the book, and I am an avid fan of Patrick O'Brian.Aubrey and Maturin are presented in all there literary appeal (although a small chunk of Maturin's character is missing in the person of his espionage capabilities). Aubrey is the practical, patriotic British leader, who relies on discipline, smarts, and tenacity to win his battles. And Maturin is his counterpart, the intellectual idealist who understands the costs of war from the vantage point of a surgeon below the decks. The two's differences often lead to clashes, but are easily reconciled by the two's friendship and love of music.It is also refreshing to see a movie which doesn't rely on the spectacular for its dramatic moments, but instead the subtle yet important shifts in the plot - which is closer to real life. The movie doesn't have any dominant female roles, nor does it need it. The British Man of war is a male paradigm, a ship run by men with really no place for women until it nears shore. Indeed, it seems HMS Surprise seems to be the only real female role in the movie; a character as enduring to Aubrey as his own wife. But a character with her own personality quirks, faults, and strengths.The only complaint I have of the movie is purely as an O'Brian fan: the Barrett Bonden character isn't quite right. I probably wouldn't mention it except that all the other minor characters flawlessly match their character descriptions in the books - Pullings, Mowett, Killick (Man I love that guy), Allen,Howard, Calamy are all instantly recognizable to the point that those who've read the books need not even be told their names to recognize them. But Bonden's wrong, I'm sorry but he just is...its just a little distracting to me, so I thought I'd mention it. It really doesn't affect the quality of the movie in the least.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: Surprise, of course, is the name of the British ship and I had been forewarned this was a marine version of Gladiator.  I was pleasantly surpised that this was not so.  The plot was a pretty straight forward telling of an epic naval sea chase and battle in the early 19th century with exceptional attention to detail of life on a three masted warship of the time. (I swear I felt a little seasick during the storm scenes).  There were a couple of holes in the story:  medical miracles from on-deck brain surgery, all-to-quick-healing gunshot and sword wounds, and the seemingly instantaneous shipboard repairs after the battles.  A realistic timeline was probably 6 months or more but it seemed more like six weeks in the movie.All-in-all, excellent entertainment value for the price of admission and most will not be disappointed.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: Boring, pointless movie. Not realistic. Don't waste your time with it! You wait for something to happen but nothing happens. I don't understand why it is so overrated on this site.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: One of the best movies I've ever seen. If you love period drama you'll love this one. It gave a lot of insight into the often cruel world at sea that shaped our history. Breathtaking scenery. Beautiful score and a few well placed surprises I didn't see coming. There was a depth to the characters that shone through. Russell Crow, Paul Bettany and all the crew were so into their parts. The weevil joke was so unexpected and funny! One profoundly moving film. The 2 disc DVD has so much intriguing and exciting features it made the whole experience even better. If you missed this at the cinema shame on you, you missed a real treat. Well worth buying on DVD for the extras alone. I sure hope they make another one as its based on a long series of books and begs for a sequel.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: I saw master and commander, the far side of the world yesterday. Well I didn't like it that much. The movie depicts the fight between a French ship, Acheron and an English ship, HMS Surprise in the period of Napoleon Bonaparte's quest to conquer England. The English ship under the command of Jack Aubrey (Russell Crowe), fight back hard against the powerful and big French ship. The movie depicts the journey of ship through the sea, the hardship faced by him and his crew and the victory achieved at last over Acheron.Let me be honest while writing this review. There are some sequences which I liked about the movie. The first sequence of escape from the more powerful French ship, Acheron, was witty. The last sequence was also nicely shown. However, the movie passes through a phase of dullness where nothing really happens and it can lead you to boredom. The movie offers a lot about the history where battles were fought in sea and with ships. The cruel lives of the seamen were also nicely depicted but the movie itself failed to keep the momentum going throughout its run time.I wouldn't say its a bad movie, but the storytelling was weak and loose in some parts of the movie, while it was spectacular in others.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: Around 50 minutes into the movie, the ship is fighting desperately against the terrible winds and enormous seas as it rounds the treacherous Cape Horn.A young seaman is thrown overboard on a broken mast. The sailors can't save him and must watch helplessly as he drowns.The background music does not, as one might expect, attempt to match the crashing waves and tearing winds of the storm.Instead it's Vaughan Williams 'Fantasia on a Theme by Thomas Tallis' - arguably the most heart-wrenchingly beautiful piece of music ever written. It perfectly matches the sadness and agony each man feels at that moment.Simply wonderful!
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: Interestingly, Russell Crowe helps rather than hinders the picture. It's hard to believe that he's such a jerk when out of character, because his acting as the captain is totally believable. His character is great because he's smart, very stern, but very caring of his crew. While they fear him, they look up to and idolize him too.The presumably accurate historical details really piqued my interest, from the little 12 and 13-year-old kids on the crew (and taking part in battle--viciously!), to the intricate chain of command, to the sheer power of the battle scenes. Splintering wood shrapnel, how often have we seen that in movies? Some of my favorite scenes are when Crowe is playing his cello in his quarters. His roomI never would have guessed a ship like that would have such a nice and fancy décor hidden within it. I mean the captain's room resembled a room out of "Clue" (The Study? The Library? I cannot say) Anyway, the visual details are great. Lots of money was spent on this movie and it was spent on things that really mattered, like recreating interiors and antiques. The guns and cannons look like artifacts to the modern viewer, but they're also well-kept and shiny.The dialog is fantastic, tooI can't remember exact quotes, but when Crowe gave some of his powerful, rallying speeches to the crew, I was ready to climb the mast myself.This movie is an incredible addition to the action/adventure/historical genre. It's also very much a man's movie. I'm not sure there's a chick in the whole thing.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: Crowe owns the role in this masterful period Navy film.
Review_body: From the first scene we are taken aboard a period British Navy ship with all the trimmings and into an ocean going game of cat and mouse with the French (Acheron ship). The realism and detail(s) of the vessel(s) is spectacular and noteworthy. Crowe owns the role as Captain and is well served by several supporting cast members (crew) Bettany (doctor) and youthful mid shipmen who are mature beyond their years, competent and likable. The hard life of the sailor during the period is portrayed as well as the glory of battle. Set design and costuming are damn near flawless. The story unfolds with enough twists, turns and suspense to keep things interesting. Violin quartet scenes are tastefully memorable (spoiler). This is some of Crowes finest acting (that I am aware of). Excellent film that I thoroughly enjoyed.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: Next time I'd prefer to just rent the National Geographic "Secrets of the Galapogos."The gun battles and chase scenes were great - but this movie had so much filler that it was nearly unbearable - the "wounded sailor" scene reminded me of the deleted scene on the "Gladiator" DVD.  Well perhaps it should have been cut out of this one.  That, along with the lizards swimming off the island and a ridiculous request for the "brisk walk" only stopping "for the really key parts of the island."  I especially liked the awful drinking songs, only to have them followed up by some lovely string duets?How many ridiculous ways can you make a 90 minute movie 120 minutes - watch this for some good ideas if you don't have your own.  This is one movie where I would not look for the director's cut.  I wonder if the DVD will have any deleted scenes because every inch of film has to be in this movie.I spent the dough - if I could do it again it would be HBO......and a good pillow.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: How can a movie so loud and violent be so boring? The story is not the least bit engaging and even the slightest reason to care about the life and death of the characters is never established. And we're supposed to believe that someone who was shot in the stomach just days earlier can walk for several miles and take part in a battle and remain alive and unscathed. To top it all off, Russell Crowe is just not convincing as a naval captain. The effects were very well done and the "look" of the film is nearly flawless, but it wasn't the least bit interesting.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: I have never had so much fun watching a film as 'Master and Commander'.  It is authentic, thrilling, full of life and adventure, and filled with wonderful performances by all of the cast members.  Russell Crowe proves once again he is one of our best male actors, and Paul Bettany deserves a supporting Oscar for his crisp portrayal of the intellectual ship surgeon Maturin.  As a bonus, the musical score and soundtrack to this film is astounding.It may not win Best Picture at this year's academy awards, but director Peter Weir deserves another Oscar nomination--only this time, he must win. It is the only fitting reward for crafting such a magnificent film.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: This has to rank as one of my all time favourite films,it is flawless, from the period detail to the uniformly good acting,an intelligent and well paced story is played out by characters who are all totally believable,Russell Crowe is excellent as Capt Jack Aubrey,resolute and stern but with flashes of humour and self doubt that make him all the more interesting and he is superbly supported by Paul Bettany"s Dr Maturin,something of a libertarian and more tolerant of the men"s grumbles than the Capt, he is the Capt"s conscience,the friendship between the two is nicely played,the scene where Capt Aubrey looks mutely at the Doctors cello after the Doctor has been shot speaks volumes about the depth of friendship between the two men,as does the scenes of the Capt and his officers getting drunk at dinner,you can totally believe that this is a crew that has been bonded together by many hardships.The everyday aspects of life on board a man of war are also well shown,the crowded conditions and hard work of keeping a ship running,not to mention the risk of death,the scene where they are forced to cut the ropes of a storm broken mast that is about to capsize the ship but in doing so must abandon one of the crew who went overboard when the mast broke is very affecting,you can feel Capt Aubreys sadness and sense of responsibility as the doomed man is left to his fate.The battle scenes are very good and well convey the frantic and fierce action that must have been characteristic of this type of warfare,the noise and smoke of the cannon fire,the lethal shrapnel of flying wooden splinters and musket balls,followed by the bloody mayhem of hand to hand fighting. Master and Commander is a truly excellent film for anybody interested in that period in history but even if you are not you wont be sorry you watched it.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: An unimpressive and long winded tale.
Review_body: Too many scenes of the officers drinking it up at the captain's table, too much dialog, too little battle.  As far as the cinematography goes, the director should have rented Wind before starting to shoot, this would have given him a good idea how to give the audience the feeling they are truly on the deck of a sailship.  A disappointing effort.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: I am giving this film a rating of 1 (awful) in an attempt to save viewers from wasting their time but I fear, having read the reams of tosh from other reviewers, that it will not make much of a dent. The director and actors are praised to the skies, yet there is not a moment of real drama or tension, of surprise, indeed of anything other than a reworking of visual and verbal clichés old as the hills. Nor was the realism so praised by other reviewers there at all except for a few moments. For yes, there were a few, but few and far between. The film is a clever contrivance. No doubt someone with inside knowledge will tell me they spent a fortune and a great deal of time on photographing these scenes. Maybe they did, but the editing is such that one would never know, so much must have been thrown away it looks as though it was done on a shoe-string; from the point of view of film-making it was unenthralling in the extreme, with clips of scenes that never once pulled back to show the wider scene or zoomed in, or panned to give the drama of reality. It is as awful as the film of Mamma Mia and for many of the same reasons. There is a total lack of visual atmosphere and place for which an endless attempt to substitute by background sound does not not succeed. If David Lean or Stanley Kubrick or Alfred Hitchcock or Fred Zinneman or any of the great directors had ever turned out a product like this their career would have ended on the spot. Where it is not awful, it is pretentious. Of course it does not help being shot in the wide-screen aspect ratio which diminishes every film now made when it attempts to work with both large (cinema, for which it was designed) and smaller screens. Now that we are in the digital age and the cost of film is not an issue, could we not return to nearer the 3x4 ratio which is the one that makes dramatic, visual sense in every circumstance? I suggest the director studies My Cousin Vinny if he wants to learn how to make a movie.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: Just thinking about it sends shivers down my spine.
Review_body: I will only make this brief, because my vocabulary is too small to fully give this film the justice it deserves.  The battle scenes are sweeping, moving and haunting, the performances are beyond Oscar worthy.  Crowe and Bettany are so obsorbed into these rolls that I completly forgot I was even watching a film.  The performances by the supporting actors are equally brilliant and nuanced.  All I can say is you must see this film.  Just thinking about it sends shivers down my spine.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: This movie was a complete let down for me. I don't know why critics can honestly call this movie entertaining.It was not exciting enough to be an entertaining action movie, and not with enough drama to make it a memorable movie. The cinemagraphy could have been better considering the ship's been to one of the most beautiful islands in the world, the music score was not complimenting, and Russell Crowe didn't stretch in terms of acting. He just acted himself. The conversation was loaded with nautical terms and neither intelligent nor humorous. The Matrix dialog had more intelligent and Pirates of the Caribbean dialog was more witty.It's full of cliche and predictable, some scenes seem stolen from "Pirates of the Caribbean".I was greatly disappointed, should have gone to see Matrix revolution again. At least it's more exciting.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: Waste of time: Scattered & confusing action, boring at times, but Good acting
Review_body: PROS: Life at sea for that time period seemed accurate, and the acting was good. CONS: The action scenes were scattered & confusing because there was a LOT of cameras swinging around quickly giving only glimpses of many of the action scenes.  At times, you could not be sure who was being blown up or shot at. Seems like poor directing for this movie. No real emotional involvement or connection with any of the characters except the doctor.  It could have been much better.We walked out with a feeling that we wasted our time.  We would not even rent this one when it comes out on DVD.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: Well-crafted, but lengthy and way overrated
Review_body: Master and Commander starts off very well. Leaving away any unnecessary and lengthy introduction, the plot is immediately introduced by putting you amidst a gripping sea battle. All battle scenes are very well-done, exciting, realistic, and they lack any artificial flavour (the very limited use of CGI effects does pay off).BUT, battle scenes alone don't make up a good movie, and it seems the producers had the same opinion here. However, instead of coming up with one single and thorough storyline, they decided to beef up the movie's very thin core story (one ship chasing another, battling each other from time to time) with a number of completely pointless side-tracks. Like: an otherwise unimportant officer driven into suicide by his weak leadership capabilities. Like: endless discussions as to whether the ship's doctor may investigate wildlife on the Galapagos islands or not. Like: numerous endless surgical scenes. And. So. On.There are so many side-tracks that the movie runs over two hours, even though there's only a very weak core story. In other words: it is boring. The end is foreseeable, and the film ends in exactly the same way it starts.Summary: 5/10 points. Only watch if you're willing to trade 90 minutes of boredom for 30 minutes of (excellent) sea battles.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: I love Russell Crowe...he is a great actor but not in this film. It just does not really work because it's all too old fashioned. The values in the film are so out of date. The film looks good and some of the scenes of the ships at war are oustoundin but not a very special film.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: This movie took me by surprise. By the commercials for it, it seems like the movie would just be battle after battle. But Peter Weir is too good a director for that. The movie is based upon the best historical fiction books ever written, by author Patrick O' Brien. The cast was amazing. This is Russell Crowe's best performance since the Gladiator. Also has performances from Russell Crowe's, "A Beautiful Mind" costar Paul Bettany, "The Lord of the Rings" star Billy Boyd, British actor James D'Arcy, and new, but talented young actors. It teaches you a lot about what happened in the 19th century, between the British and the French. I recommend this movie to anyone interested in historical fiction movies.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: Director: Peter Weir; Screenplay: Peter Weir; Cast: Russel Crowe, Paul Bettany, James D'Arcy, Edward Woodall, Chris Larkin, Max PirkisPlot Synopsis: Audacious Captain Jack Aubrey (Russel Crowe) and his crew of Brits aboard the HMS 'Surprise' obsessively pursues a French privateer across the high seas.In this noteworthy naval epic set during the Napoleonic Wars of the early 19th century, we see director Peter Weir deliver some of the most impressive special effects in recent memory. In fact, I would go as far as saying the proliferation of home-theatre is down to films like Master and Commander. The art direction and the cinematography are also spot on, capturing the feel of what it would be like sailing the high seas in 1805 (I have even heard reports of patrons coming out of theaters suffering from sea-sickness!)Russel Crowe once again delivers an impressive performance, rightly justifying his place as one of the premier actors of our time. As the brash Captain Jack Aubrey, Crowe exudes bravado and charisma and creates a well-rounded protagonist that is very convincing as the obsessed Brit hunting for French blood. Generally, the cast as a whole delivers a strong team performance, especially Max Pirkis as the young midshipman, however even mighty Captain Jack must play second fiddle (pardon the pun) to Weir's set designs and explosions.Perhaps the only gripe I have with the film is the inconsistency in the pacing, in that there are a few slow points that interrupt the overall flow of the picture. However, at 133 minutes, the running time is more than acceptable for a film of this type.Overall, Master and Commander is a very satisfying experience that successfully captures the look and feel of naval warfare and should appeal to anyone who enjoys a good cat and mouse chase across the high seas.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: Best historical drama about small unit leadership since ZULU
Review_body: 2 major battle scenes, brilliant acting, historical realism on a scale seldom seen. An intelligent script which requires that the audience actually remember things said over an hour ago. This may qualify as a spoiler, maybe not: One critic missed the point completely, when he thought--what a wonderfully convenient thing that the enemy the captain (Crowe) was supposed to be searching for, just happened to show up while he dawdled allowing his best-friend and ship's doctor (Betany), to recover from serious injury on an island. Had the critic paid just a little attention to the fact that the island Captain Aubrey had chosen for the surgery and recovery also happened to have the only source for drinking water in god knows how many miles, he might have put two and two together and realized Aubrey was making the best of two problems : his ships need for a doctor (along with his personal need to keep his friend alive) and choosing the only spot where his French opponent sooner or later would need to drop anchor for water. Consequently his waiting there while Steven recovers could not reasonably be criticized as dilatory. As for boring-- that is in the brain of the beholder. I first saw it at a Sunday matinée in Phoenix with an audience largely male but primarily 10-twenty something and NOBODY got raucous or seemed restless, laughed when they should have and heard generally favorable comments walking out. I think a large number of the unbelievably low scores of one star out of ten it gets when when you search lowest scores to highest here at IMDb result from expectations of a swash-buckler a la Pirates of the Caribbean. It is a high- adventure movie AND a serious drama about duty and friendship which makes it a rare bird these days. Not really a date move, but a surprising number of women I know have enjoyed it. Not as many as loved Gladiator enough to see it twice in its theatrical run, but quite a few; none I have talked to thought of it as a typical male-bonding flick. Well worth more than one look if you are looking for entertainment that doesn't insult your intelligence.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: Okay I wasn't around in 1805 and never served on a man'o'war so it would be fallacious of me to say that this is an accurate depiction of what it must have been like on an warship in that period. However, Patrick O'Brian's novels have been based on actual events and records from the period and Peter Weir has transferred this to the screen with an obvious love of the novels and with great attention to detail. I'm an avid reader of history from this era and it comes pretty damn close to how I imagined it must have been. Weir conjures up the claustrophobic feeling of life on board ship but also the great camaraderie that must have existed for crews to function effectively and after living together for month on end. Some people might complain about the lack of action - but life at sea would have consisted of long periods of routine with brief elements of extreme violence from either the elements or the enemy. It also creates the space to build up the characters so that we care for them. Rather than the gung-ho approach of many other films. When we do get the action it's sudden and jaw droppingly explosive. The cinematography is stunning with some of the battle scenes looking like period paintings. Again, it's good to see a film depicting naval warfare in the age of sail where the ships look "right". All of the actors play their roles really well with standout performances from Paul Bettany and a young Max Pirkis. If I have couple of minor gripes (which certainly didn't detract from an excellent film) firstly, the not so graphic depiction of how violent boarding another ship must have been - with people literally butchering each other with cutlasses, spikes and hooks etc (in the historic battle between the Shannon and the Chesapeake, the Shannon's boatswain had his arm hacked off with repeated strokes of a cutlass whilst attempting to grapple the enemy ship) but I suppose that would have affected the classification of the film. Less forgivable is the changing of the enemy in the source novel from American to French. It seems that it's not acceptable to depict Americans being defeated - even in fiction. Anyway, these are tiny gripes and if you like your historical films to be accurate with characters you can identify with and stunning action or you have the least interest in this period then I cannot recommend this film highly enough.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: Wow I have watched a lot a lot of movies and yet I have chosen to watch this movie no less than three times - enjoy
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: I give this an 8.5 which rounds down to an 8 because i'm American, I gave 'The Patriot' an 8. There should be some sort of intelligence filter on this board. I particularly loved 'BabyGenius' who thought Russel played a cello in the film, which is a hard instrument to play like a violin (his actual instrument in the movie).Peter Weir feels a bit out of his element in this one, being more accustomed to soul-searching drama, (the classic 'Dead Poet's Society') than courageous naval warfare. This is however a rare film, and Russel's Crowe's best, but he's more convincing as a gladiator. 'theTeague' from the UK alikened him to Richard Burton, although Russel does not have the polished presence of Burton or the flair of Erol Flynn. Much praise for correctly portraying the Cromwellian nature of the time period, with all it's puritan 'taboos' and Christian ethic.So the question ' How did the English take over the world ?' is mostly answered here. Magnificent cast, plot, cinematography, and attention to historical detail. Bettany is a fresh breathe of acting air, brilliant and flattering, however Darwin didn't plop out until 1809 and the biology is out of place and turns into a Herman Melville novel. Also The almost monotone color palettes, bleck, this was the height of warfare for the last 2000 years and the next 600 to come ! ! ! ! liven it up ! ! ! Overall ranks up with 'Bridge over the River Kwai' in war films genre. A keeper.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: This is a fantastic movie about the HMS Surprise, commanded by Captain Jack Aubrey, stalking the French vessel Acheron to the "far side of the world" during the Napoleanic era. The film is intricately detailed, and while I am no sailor, most of the details strike true. I do know that the British Navy by the time of this story absolutely revered Lord Nelson, and that reverence is played out in this movie when several younger officers ask the Captain for impressions of Nelson during one of his two meeting with the Admiral. The cannons have names, the bells number the hours of the shipboard day. A knotted rope line is played out to measure the ship's speed in knots. A sounding is taken to read the depth of the sea, and sextant lessons are given to measure true noon. In fact the level of detail is overwhelming, but the story is just as good.The Acheron is the superior ship, and at first it seems the Captain is also superior. He surprises the Surprise twice, once coming out of the fog at the beginning of the movie and once by hiding in an inlet and letting the Surprise chase on by. Captain Aubry only barely manages to escape into the fog the first time, and into the night the second.Russell Crowe's performance as Captain Jack Aubry is spectacular. I was also immensely impressed with Mix Ppirkis's portrayal of young Mr. Blakeny. The photography and camera work were absolutely first rate, as well as the tremendous attention to detail.This is a really great movie on so many levels. I highly recommend it.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: You can hear every creak and groan but nary a word
Review_body: Why spend all this money to make this film and then allow almost all the lines to be inaudible? How annoying to hear every bit of the wind, rain, and all the FX sounds of the ship at sea and yet have to strain to hear (and still miss) just about every word. The battles are a confused mess. Might as well have subtitled this one. A well-hyped but poorly executed offering.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: Some films, like Chinese cuisine, pass through you so quickly you hardly remember they were there.  Others linger in your mind, sometimes even subconsciously, growing, so that by the time you see the film again it's something more than it was the first time.  Master and Commander is deceptively simple.  You could sum the story up in a single sentence.  But the levels of nuance and texture go beyond almost anything seen on American screens in years.  It manages to be exciting, bloody, adventurous stuff without ever becoming inhumane.  And it's subtle, human, and beautiful without ever stagnating.  Not a single performance bears a false note. The world of the film is so rigorously invented that one can't help but fall into it; it's completely absorbing.  But on reflection, it's an amazing high-wire act.  It stands as single, overpowering proof that a film with the best visual effects of the year can also be the most clever and intelligent. Maybe it will be even better the third time.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: I was so anticipating attending another Russell Crowe film.  The man seems to always pick the best parts and he can even make a good film a really great film.  Perhaps my mistake was expecting another "Gladiator" type movie will Russell delivering a brillant performance with lots of action.Well, there was some action and Russell was good, but it's no "Gladiator". The character development is so weak.  I kept sitting there asking myself why I cared what happened to these characters and to be honest, I didn't really care.  Shame.Some scenes are really spectacular, but if you're looking for the full package, this isn't it.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: This nautical adventure full of historical detail keeps you well engrossed and wanting more when the movie abruptly comes to an end.  If any criticism, the lack of denouement and the deliberate setup for the next movie gave the film a TV miniseries feel not warranted for a production of its caliber. Russell Crowe and Paul Bettany are outstanding as the lead characters.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: After seeing this film I realized 2 things:1) With the exception of a couple of Brazilian natives, there are NO women in this film.2) Russell Crowe is so riveting on screen that I would probably buy a ticket to watch him do laundry.Though the overwhelming action sequences are sometimes so loud that I couldn't understand a word being said on screen, I still found it to be an enjoyable and watchable flick. That I couldn't hear what was being said was sometimes of no moment. This is not a film that spends a lot of time explaining itself. There was enough inexplicable nautical terminology tossed about that eventually gave up trying to understand what the hell they were talking about and went on faith that I would be able to figure out the pertinent details of the story.The story was not a particularly strong one, but the movie was well executed. Both Crowe and Paul Bettany did excellent jobs, although there were a few moments when I wanted to smack Bettany's rather effete doctor around and tell him to catch a clue...We're at war and you want to stop to check out the scenery? Still, he makes a good on screen "conscience" for Crowe and his behavior sets the stage for the moments when we get to see a more human side of Crowe's character.When I left the theatre I didn't feel as though I'd wasted my $8.00...and that's something in this day and age.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: Sorry, just seen this movie in the theater and I found it mostly disappointing. Only the doctor saved me from falling asleep. Even its not nicely shot, so boring story, no beautiful pictures, hmm nothing which really makes a good movie, I knew from the beginning how it would end hmm Ok one of the why waste money on this movies .... IMHO .... 5/10
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: This is an intelligent film, not packed with clichés to make a point we have already assumed. It credits its audience with intelligence, as it does it characters. It gives them depth and lightness, learning and introspection. No two dimensional characters here, and for my mind an adventure movie far better than the Indianna Jones series.Russell Crowe shows himself to be an actor who is willing to take real risks with his career, a man who could have made a comfortable living playing tough guys, but has succeeded in playing as diverse a range of characters as Sean Penn, and probably has made better career choices than Mr Penn. The results have not always been happy, a 'Brilliant Mind' although well acted was let down by the sentimentality of the movie, he looked at odds with the result, I think his performance had more truth than the film. Here he is in full command, a confident performance, as was Paul Bettany's performance as the surgeon, both difficult parts calling on a wide range of emotions.The screenplay was a delight, witty and crackling stuff, it avoided the obvious trap of creating a pastiche of the period, just well written English.An underrated movie on the IMDb in my opinion
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: **** Mild Spoilers Maybe *****Usually, I don't like Peter Weir movies that much. But this time I was pleasantly surprised. I hope many people either don't watch the trailer for this movie or don't let themselves be influenced by it. The trailer doesn't give any spoilers but it gives a different impression of the movie. This movie is a great epic with heroic, yet very human (and humane) and attractive men of all ages. There is no cheesy, distracting love story, but there's a lot of display of emotion. I'd recommend this movie to men who silently dream of sailing away and exploring things, and to women who want more substance in dialog and more interesting male characters than the usual "chick" movies have. 9/10
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: Richly detailed, genuinely interesting historical fun
Review_body: I saw "Master and Commander" last night with a friend, his cousin, and his cousin's friend. I thought M&C was very good, my friend thought it was the worst movie ever (oh, come on now...) and the other two guys thought it was "pretty good". That being said, it really is a genuinely good film, definitely one of the best mainstream flicks of 2003.M&C is based on the Patrick O'Brien novels of the British Navy during the Napoleanic War. I'm told the novels focus more on the ship's doctor than Captain Aubrey, but I don't think that should disuade anyone from seeing the film. Lovingly crafted with lots of great details of the state of shipbuilding, sailing, and naval life in 1805. Think guys with bad teeth who are sorely in need of a bath. The officers of the ship seem to live pretty good though.It was good to see Russell Crowe portraying a character with an accent somewhat similar to his native New Zealander. My only previous encounter with him is in the very good "L.A. Confidential" in which he plays an LA cop. His American accent in that film is pretty much limited to "rmrmrrrmm mrrmrgrm mrgmlm" the entire movie.Anyways, although M&C did stretch a bit too long (Weir could have shaved 20 or 30 minutes off) it's one of the more intellegent, better made movies of recent years. Highly recommended. 8/10
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: And positive one indeed! The film was even better that I expected. Great acting (especially everyone!), beautiful landscapes and touching music, just to mention a few qualities of this Oscar-vehicle. And not even a bit of a romance in sight!
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: *SPOILERS*The visual FX are nice, the acting is good, the recreation is fine... there's some nice scenes but nothing more, the story is quite boring; confusing specially on the fight scenes... who are the british?, who are the french? (who knows?) and predictable, come on, when the doc climb that hill EVERYONE at the theater knew he was gonna see the french ship :P.If you're into naval stuff and/or if you really enjoy non-sense war movies, go for it, otherwise stay away.Yet Another Pop Corn Movie.5/10
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: Sails away from the majority of mediocre films in 2003
Review_body: Master and Commander: The Far Side of the World has a very rich look on the screen.  The reported $135 million budget shows as you watch the 138 minute Peter Weir feature, which makes the price of admission worth it alone. However, not only does this film have a very artistic aura surrounding it from beginning to end, it also incorporates other fine aspects of technical film-making.  The editing, the original musical score, the cinematography, the visual effects, and the sound effects all coupled professionally together by director Peter Weir and the strong, memorable acting performances by Russell Crowe and Paul Bettany.  I have never read the novels written by author Patrick O' Brain, so I cannot make an assessment on the screenplay adaptation from novel to film, but I can make the judgment that the novel must of have been a very engaging one, as this film itself was exciting and gripping at the same time. Therefore, I can only make the positive assumption that both screen writers Peter Weir and John Collee followed the original source faithfully, because both writers believed that what they had read was destined to be brought to the silver screen in its original form. 	The opening action sequence and the final battle sequence reminded me of the classic opening and ending of Saving Private Ryan. Master and Commander resonated a very gritty and realistic feel of the life on a ship and the battles that these sailors had to endure upon in the heat of an attack. There are some slow points in the film, however they are essential nonetheless (The Galapagos Island scenes felt out of place but when they ended, they made sense and it just took some time to get there). This film is not simply about one small ship chasing another bigger ship across the globe, but rather about discovering the mysteries of the new world that was awaiting to be discovered and about friendship that was to be trusted  and leadership that was to be earned during a desperate era of war between two powerful nations. So it was necessary to spend time within the film to explore these themes.  By learning the trial and tribulations that these men had to bare through, we start to care more about their hunt for the French ship. 	I enjoyed this picture a lot as it sails away from the majority of the mediocre movies that plagued the sea of theaters in 2003. 8/10
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: A superb movie about Navy vessels and their crewmen in 1805
Review_body: After seeing Master and Commander I was totally blown away. The way daily life on these ships were depicted was spot on. How the different characters and their tasks were clearly demonstrated. The locations such as Brazil and the Galapagos Islands were a nice touch. Ship to ship battles were top notch as were the close combat scenes.Anyone interested in Navy life in the 1800's need to see this movie. This is also one of those movies where you will want to buy the video for your collection.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: Outside of the very good BBC production of "Horatio Hornblower", I have not seen a film that shows the day to day life of the English seamen as well as this film. I found the cast to be perfect and the soundtrack makes you seem as if you're there. Congrats to Peter Weir!
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: I vote 10. At first, movie is technical brilliant. I had an impression of personal presence in almost all the scenes, which means that the cameras positions, light, sound, the other effects and the rest of the technical tools are well composed, coherent to each other, "catching" the right moments to be as close to the reality, as possible (or necessary). Furthermore, Peter Weir`s choice of actors is excellent. O`Brien`s novel needs such an actors, who can realized their roles with the faces, movements and characteristics, they already have by their own. Relationships, between captain (Russell Crowe), his doctor friend (Paul Bettany), than the young boys and their elder colleagues, finally the sailors back to their captain - all the circle is description of possible human community, which can be comparable with any other human union, even the state. Russell Crowe as Jack Aubrey represents classic leader, an archetype of "strict, but righteous king" (captain), so his role justify the title of the movie. On the other side, Paul Bettany`s character is a typical one who represents other human spheres, such as mind, sense, hunger for knowledge and scientific researches. This polarity, between human lack (Dr. Stephen Maturin) and captain`s (Jack Aubrey) personal wishes, covered with "hold on tight" of state (British Empire) priorities, P. Weir alleviates in the scenes where the fear of loss of a close person waking up a hidden love and care (R. Crowe character). That point makes this movie more lyrical, than the epic male war drama. No matter the scenes of battles are enough rude, as they have to be, the lyrical sense is the clew trough the entire movie. Except the parts at the Galapagos islands, everything is on the ship, but the feeling of claustrophobic, introvert atmosphere is absolutely absent. Also, the end without end (final issue) makes the movie and protagonists a bit like a shadow, which can emerge any time, somewhere at the oceans. Very good end. I saw many of characters Russell Crowe acting, but as Jack Aubrey, I found him the best (for now). Knowing well Australian and New Zealand film production, directors and actors, Crowe is so Australian in this role (no matter Aubrey is British) - a specific and recognizable acting (like people can always recognize the Hollywood or European actors and acting styles, which are specific in their own way). Conclusion: Congratulations to Peter Weir, Russell Crowe, Paul Bettany, all the other actors and the rest of the Master and Commander movie crew.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: A masterful movie from top to bottom.
Review_body: Master and Commander is a good film and the cinematography is amazing for a movie of its scoop. I thought Russell Crowe does such a great job and the rest of the cast follows him like well-trained soldiers. The movie needed to pick up some speed during the first half, but the movie does deliver towards the second, and what a fine second half it is. I know that this is based on the first book of a series, and I would not mind a bit that this movie has a sequel or two in the future.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: And surprised I was. After hearing a friend rant endlessly about it, and having nothing to do one Friday night, I rented Master and Commander. The marketing staff should be cackling in glee, that a female in her 20's, would love this movie. It's an amazing movie. Russell Crowe is a force of nature, and all the other actors from Paul Bettany to Billy Boyd give wonderful performances. I especially enjoyed the details of life at sea, though most would call them boring. The day after my 5-day rental, I had to run to the nearest shop and buy the DVD, and have since re-watched it endlessly. I've never seen a more beautifully adapted, filmed and acted movie. Five stars out of five.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: So confusing, and boring, not worth anyone's time
