Review_body: This movie was so confusing. You would only understand it if you were a sailor in that century, which no one is. There were too many characters for you to know their names, the director expected you to catch their names when they said them, they didn't have anyone say "Sir this is Cpt.Jack Aubrey" or anything like that. You had to give everyone nicknames, like the little boy with one arm or his friend or Pippin! When the guy on top of the sail thing died, I thought they killed off Billy Boyd because I didn't know his name. The worst performance in this movie would have to be Russel Crowe's. His voice is too deep and soft for you to understand. Plus, what makes a good movie is if it has at least one joke. The funniest part in this movie was the "lesser of two weavles" and that wasn't even all that funny. I just don't see how people compared this terrible movie to the great "Pirates of the Caribbean: The Curse of the Black Pearl". "Pirates" was great, this was just plain pathetic. Pirates had a great introduction of characters with the whole "What's your name?/Will Turner" also "Well, well, well, Jack Sparrow isn't it?/Actually, it's Captain Jack Sparrow" and it actually had a plot! I never want to hear Master and Commander again! Another terrible thing about the movie was, gore. I know they didn't have good medicine back then, but did they really have to show the pain on the poor boys face when he got his arm cut off?! There was too much implied gore for a PG-13 movie. Again, Pirates was great with that, they only showed the people's feet, this showed people getting stabbed and shot. Plus, it was so unbelievable when the doctor operated on HIMSELF! Thank god, I saw Shrek 2 the same day I saw this piece of garbage. THERE WERE ONLY A FEW GIRLS WHO HAD NO LINES!!! I give this crap a 0/1,000
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: Nearly all of the film takes place aboard the HMS Surprise, under the command of Captain "Lucky" Jack Aubrey (Russell Crowe). The captain's orders: to intercept and disable the French privateer Acheron, which is troubling British vessels off the coast of South America. The two ships clash early on, and the Surprise is thoroughly routed--the Acheron is larger, faster, and more modern. But Aubrey, with a determination that might not entirely be due to his sense of duty, is not one to give up, and the Surprise chases the Acheron--and/or vice versa--down the Brazilian coast, around Cape Horn, and to the Gallapagos Islands.That's the action part. The intimate part involves Aubrey's relationship with the ship's surgeon, Stephan Marutin (Paul Bettany). Stephan is a quiet intellectual and devout naturallist, whose train of thought is foraying into the territory that would make Darwin a household name later in the century. He's also the only one among the crew who's either willing or able to call Aubrey's decisions into question. He provides a grounding force for the captain, and the friendship between these two dissimilar men is the emotional heart of the story.I've yet to read any of the Patrick O'Brian series upon which "Master and Commander" is based, but the movie shows every evidence of being derived from a painstakingly and meticulously detailed work, one which has gone to great lengths to re-create the world and environment of these men. The details on screen are wonderful, depicting the sort of harsh conditions that make the contestants on those "reality" series look like the overglorified wimps they are. The crew of the Surprise (many of them not older than twenty) lives in claustrophobic and none-too-clean quarters--at times it seems as if every inch of the screen is crammed full--and sleep in hammocks that may very well end up serving as their shrouds. Battles are chaotic, with cannon fire ripping huge holes in the ship and sending shrapnel in every direction. The weather seems to exist only in extremes: still heat, raging tempests, even snow as they drift down near the Antarctic circle. Good service is rewarded with extra rations of grog and brandy, insubordination is punished by the whip. It's a place where both close friendships and deep resentments can grow, and the tension in the air at times feels like a living presence.Crowe dominates the production, once again proving himself one of the best leading men working in movies. In his hands, Jack Aubrey is a natural leader of men: clever, courageous, determined, and capable of what nowadays is called "thinking outside the box." He is frequently confronted with difficult choices, but takes his responsibilities and the consequences of his actions unflinchingly. Bettany turns in an equally good performance as Aubrey's emotional and ideological opposite; the two men play wonderfully off of each other. Most of the rest of the crew tends to blur together (the exceptions include a young officer who's right arm gets amputated early on, and later takes command of the ship), but "Lord of the Rings" fans will be amused to notice Billy Boyd among the ranks.The combination of action and introspection in "Master and Commander" at times seems like an odd mix, but the film succeeds on both levels. Definitely a voyage worth taking.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: An unvarnished snapshot of daily life aboard a British wooden naval ship during the Napoleonic wars, when many rank-and-file men and boys were drafted by impressment. For those interested in English history/naval history, Patrick O'Brian novels, or just beautiful cinematography, music, and fine acting, this film never disappoints. The star, Russell Crowe, is wonderful as Captain "Lucky Jack" Aubrey, though there are truly fine performances all round. Max Pirkin shines as the sweet-tempered midshipman, Lord Blakeney, and David Threlfall is fun as the grumpy but attentive Steward, "Preserved" Killick. The beautiful close shot of young Max Benitz (2nd Lt. Peter Calamy) at (the "weevil") dinner, bathed in candlelight, was reminiscent of a miniature oil portrait. Complex and layered, it's one of very few movies I can watch again and again; disappointed, as many people were, that no sequels were made. Perhaps the studios were saving money for the fifteenth version of Spider-Man. Note: Will bore mallrats to tears.Favorite quote: "Name a shrub after me. Something prickly and hard to eradicate."
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: Very watchable realistic action sea drama
Review_body: I really enjoyed this film. That same evening I had seen a very tired "swashbuckler with Errol Flynn and Maureen O'Hsra and Tony Quinn. It was low budget and melodramatic and they all looked very tired. By contrast, this film had everything; drama, humour, pathos, action, scenery, and a passable story-line. Thoroughly watchable escapist entertainment--with no syrupy "lurv"interest. The Doctor/naturalist character was, I felt , a little out of time and seemed a touch too modern in outlook. I thought the portrayal of the life of the assorted midshipmen, learning their trade at sea, was very realistic. Would they really have been fooled, however by all those dead Frenchies on the enemy ship as they boarded it?
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: Having not read an O'Brian in a couple of years, I hadn't anticipated the lovely buzz of recognition watching MASTER AND COMMANDER afforded.  The theater was mostly empty, so I presume this will be the only Aubrey/Maturin episode we will see onscreen.  But this one is a fitting bookend to the majestic series-- a stand-in for the final-episode I have presumed O'Brian left his executors to publish posthumously (presumably, one in which Aubrey and probably Maturin go down with one ship or another).  Weir and company didn't get in the humor of the books (film-goers won't know how fitting was one O'Brian fan's online confession that his dream-Aubrey was Bill Clinton). They couldn't shoehorn-in Maturin's espionage or the other sides of his fascinating, impossible book-being.  And those watching the film won't know the aesthetic of O'Brian's relegating battle-scenes to secondary importance (he even vaults-over a few, stunningly).  They will see his archival relish, his fascination with hierarchy and order maintained under claustrophobic conditions, and his curator's interest in absolutely every aspect of naval subsistence.  In a couple of respects, the film even improves on the books: the line of streamlined eloquence Weir affords Jack may conventionalize his appeal to his men, but it stood-in for the charisma of Aubrey's reputation, amassed over so many volumes (Crowe understates artfully); the film manifests tangy mortal presences for the ensemble of sailors who, in the books, flicker by as names-only.  In fact, Weir's only error seemed to me the inflation of Hallam's collapse into a set-piece of cued poignancy, a narrative stutter. Spectacular film-making-- I am sure Spielberg, Scorsese and P. Jackson appreciate the ingenuity and clarity of what Weir managed.  Jack Aubrey would know what to do with the churls who have recorded indifferent comments in this register.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: There's no wonder it's underrated movie.
Review_body:
Boring ,nothing special...too Long for nothing...and when you think about "Russell Crowe" this movie won't come across your mind...cos it's an okay movie but really there's nothing special about it....
You can skip it easily.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: I absolutely adore this movie. Like the first reviewer, I am a woman in her late 20s. I read all the Horatio Hornblower books, and I love stories of the King's Navy during the Napoleonic Wars. There may be a few inconsistencies here and there, but hey, we're all human. Needless to say, I was quite impressed. The movie is touching, tough, and lyrical. The music is exquisite -- I have purchased the soundtrack, and the casting brilliant. I have now been through two of the Aubrey-Maturin novels, after seeing the movie, and I don't see what people found so disturbing about Russell Crowe's casting as Jack Aubrey. Though Aubrey is younger in the books, Crowe played him magnificently. And I love Paul Bettany; always have, since his Chaucer days. He does the character of Maturin a great service. As I have read these books, I've found that the screenwriters took good care to include some dialog from the books word-for-word. I like that in a movie made from a book -- or more than one, in this case. I can't wait to read the rest of the books and compare them to one of my favorite movies, one I've watched so many times, I can "watch" it with my eyes closed!
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: A huge fan of the books
Review_body: I love this movie. Russell Crowe and Paul Bettany do an amazing job of bringing the characters to life. The story is captivating and the movie has a lot of beautiful visuals.I definitely recommend reading the books if you liked the movie.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: This film is two things:1. A highly superior action movie. It's exciting, emotional, beautiful and honest. The sound design is particularly good and I suggest choosing a cinema with a better than average sound system if you possibly can. They are very successful at creating the life of the warship, this little floating world, travelling around our world, but not in it, with its own independent, isolated life, subject to the awesome power of the weather and the sea. The actions, with cannonballs crashing about your ears, and the seas off Cape Horn, are awe-inspiring. The heat, the cold, the possibility of running out of water, of accidents, disease, the isolation, the responsibilities, being 'stuck' with your shipmates, the resilience and sensation of living only in the present - all this is superbly conveyed, and that's before you even mention the enemy.2. A pretty good Patrick O'Brian pastiche. It's not like the real thing, but it's a very worthy tribute. Crowe and Bettany may not be Aubrey and Maturin, but they're about as good a try as you could possibly hope for. If you have read the books, just relax and don't worry about the plot of either of the books this is based on - there isn't room for that kind of plot in the time. Treat this as a new sea story. You should recognise some dialogue, which is all to the good as O'Brian's brilliant dialogue is one of the best things about the novels. What they've really gone for here is physical historical accuracy and great acting. If you haven't read the books, but seeing the film has made you want to, just start with "Master and Commander".Age range: I think anyone of 10 upwards would be fine, but parents should use their discretion in taking a younger child. Although the violence is not especially graphic, it is realistic. There are some emotional scenes of characters being injured, killed, or buried at sea which might upset an imaginative child. On the other hand, there are also scenes of very young characters showing great courage and responsibility.Some people have found it difficult to follow. I see that one reviewer simply couldn't understand the British accents, which probably does make it tricky, and two seperate people on the message board have mistaken the brief glimpse of a cricket match for baseball. (Both of them enjoyed the film, though.) If you don't need subtitles, why not give it a go? If you do, you might have to wait for the DVD, which is a pity as this is a big-screen flick.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: A thoughtful, masterful evocation of the age of sail, and a quietly gripping story.  Performances are wonderful.  Weir does not resort to audience manipulation through music score or bloodshed - he expects the audience to pay attention and keep up.  It may be too much to ask of American audiences today, but I hope not.  Crowe, Bettany and the rest are wonderful, and this movie fully realizes the spirit, if not the letter, of Patrick O'Brian's novels.  A wonderful movie for the ages - but it's not a video game.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: Many with a short attention span, which seems all too common these days, may feel that this movie drags.  But those with patience for a good thing will recognize that Peter Weir did an excellent job of giving a realistic portrayal of life on a battleship from this time-period.  Those amongst us with A.D.D. would have been happier if the whole two hours were filled with nothing but battle scenes.  Those amongst us with an appreciation for good films are grateful to the filmmakers for this wonderful accomplishment that not only entertains us, but also succeeds in illustrating history for a generation centuries removed from experiencing it for ourselves.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: My husband and I use IMDB to see what real viewers think of films. We never go see anything with lower than a 7 rating. I was not really looking forward to Master and Commander but the majority of those who had seen it liked it so off we went. I am glad I did. I am not a big Russell Crowe fan but sometimes he surprises me. He did an excellent job. He played the role of Lucky Jack with the reserved emotion as needed. I knew nothing about what the film covered. My husband briefed me quickly about the war and I was set. The film was beautifully done. The acting, costuming, and story telling were all great(expect to see Oscar with this one). The attention to detail was amazing. I left feeling that I had been on ship and in the time period. When you see this film take your mind and let it absorb all that is the Master and Commander.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: A high seas ramble with great attention to detail
Review_body: After hearing so much about this being a great movie, I decided to rent it and see for myself. The only good thing I can say is that now I've seen it, but I should have saved the five bucks. I loved how accurate everything was, but Here is the plot: A warship (the H.M.S. "Surprise") captained by "Lucky Jack" Aubrey does battle with the "Acheron" and then chases her around...and around, and around. We see brief glimpses of the men's lives, but not ever enough to care about them or see their struggles. (Yes, Hollom struggles with being an outsider, and other men struggle with losing their friends at sea, but there is never enough of any one person's struggles to make it interesting.) They keep *almost* catching the "Acheron," but never quite do. At the end, they take her, but Jack assumes the "doctor" (actually the disguised French captain) is telling the truth and the "Acheron" and her captain get away. So Jack and Stephen sit down and play a lovely piece by Bocherinni (the best part of the movie, I thought) to pass the time. All of this is accompanied by a strange selection of classical music by Bach, Mozart, Vaughan Williams, and Corelli that does NOT go with the moods portrayed on screen.I was impressed that Russel Crowe learned to play the violin for the movie, but that did not make up for a two-hour ramble on the high seas.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: This film was far better than most of the large-scale action/dramas that come out this time of year.  It was engaging, but it was somewhat inconsistent and its flow was at times diverted and came to a near standstill.  Russell Crowe's performance was excellent, certainly one of his best.  The story was well-executed.  However, something was ultimately lacking in the film, attention to a larger purpose or goal, that made the sailors' sacrifices worthwhile and would have given them greater significance.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: Probably one of the best sea movies of all time
Review_body: Napoleon Bonaparte, on being told the virtues of a new general - the man's heroism, bravery, skill in battle and so on - waved his hand impatiently. "That's all very well," he said, "but is he lucky?"In a world where competency is the rule and deviations from prescribed orders bring instant termination we are transported back to Napoleonic naval wars and the world of Captain Jack Aubry. Aubry is multi-faceted playing the violin, fascinated by natural science, loving women (though only a glimpse is shown of this in this movie), wanting the money from the enemy ships that he seizes but at the same time courageous, patriotic and most of all lucky.I know some may disagree with me but I think this may be one of the best sea movies of all time. The movie captures perfectly life among an English frigate during the Napoleonic wars, yet works as an action movie and also as a buddy picture (the Doctor Maturin and Captain Aubry). Dialog is great, picking up much of the language of the books without feeling the need for endless exposition for the definitions. Performances are excellent throughout and Russel Crowe will certainly be put in Oscar contention for his role as Aubry.I think some may criticize some of the pacing of the movie but I think it captures the fact that life on a ship like this was sometimes boring, fun and very dangerous for short periods of time.If I only have a one criticisms of the movie the are for the lack of exposition on Dr. Maturin. People may seem mystified by Capt. Aubry's soft gloves approach to Dr. Maturin (even though we know they are friends). This is because Aubry knows that while the crew follows Aubry because he is lucky, they know a competent surgeon is a rarity on a frigate the size of theirs. Three major reasons that Maturin is on board are his friendship to Aubry, his desire to see foreign lands as a naturalist and his desire to be as far away from England as possible since he was somewhat involved in a recent Irish rebellion. It probably would have been a good idea for 1st Lt. Pullings or Capt. Howard to ask in an aside why he tolerates comments from Maturin that he wouldn't tolerate from anyone else on board. Aubry could have given a short speech on how a Captain has to balance the needs for discipline, individual motivation and loyalty of the crew in all decisions that he makes.Still in all a great film.10 out of 10.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: Master and Commander: The Far Side of the World is just about one of the finest and most see-worthy films of the year. Russell Crowe is at it again in the clothes of a natural hero, this time a certain "Lucky" Jack Aubrey, and with director Peter Weir we are taken on a journey of revenge that goes to the very far sides of the world.  What is perhaps most to admire of the film is its excellent realism. The very first 15 minutes are perhaps the finest, most exciting and dazzling 15 minutes of the year. Jack Aubrey and his crew of seamen are attacked by French fregate Acheron, and the battle is downright intense. Saving Private Ryan redone in the early 19th century, well, I'm very amazed. Also, Paul Bettanys character, Stephen Maturin, adds an excellent supporting character which helps us take interest on the happenings on the ship, the HMS Surprise.  What came most unexpected (to me, anyway) was the fact that in this movie, we get to delve into our characters in a way not yet seen in huge blockbusters. This risk was worth taking, as this drama keeps the crew alive and believable.  Even if we might drive into some slow parts at times, I can't help to be fascinated by the authentic portrayal of the wars at sea, and even if it is a little slow at times, the beautiful shots, interesting characters, and spectacular battle scenes create one of the best films of the year, which is highly recommended.  9/10
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: I really do not understand why this film is getting such great reviews. I will say the battle scenes are great, but that's about it. Russell Crowe is a great actor but not here. For me this film was almost a joke in the acting department. It was predictable and dull. I really don't believe people would be as calm and cracking jokes while there being blown to bit's. How critics have reacted to this film is exactly what is wrong in Hollywood. It really doesn't take much to make them happy anymore. What was the purpose of this film? The Dr. friend needed to get thrown overboard along with most of the rest of the cast. Sorry this is just another bloated Hollywood waste of time. Oh, and please do not compare this film to Lawrence of Arabia that film IS a classic!
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body:
Fine but way too long epic that is very good in general but a bit over stays it's welcome towards the end. Russell Crowe is great as usual, and he is supported by a fine ensemble of actors that gives him something to work with.  The battles at sea are far and the away the best of its nature, and the period is well represented. If they only could only cut about a half-hour from the film, them it would have been a much better movie.
All and all a great time at the movies.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: This movie is excellent.  One of the few historical fiction movies that can't be criticized for historical inaccuracy.  It shows how sailors of the British navy lived at the time of the Napoleonic Wars.  Russell Crowe and Paul Bettany were perfect in their roles as Jack and Stephen; they both had their characters down great, and they excellently captured the friendship between Jack and Stephen from the books.  I highly recommend seeing this movie, and then reading the books.  Don't watch this movie as an epic, watch it for the characters, or else you'll miss what makes this movie so great! If you haven't seen it make sure you see it when it comes out on DVD!
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: One of my favorite movies if not my very favorite movie ever. Extremely engaging and exciting plot with the right amount of action-packed violent battle scenes at the right times. Perfect movie for military warfare and history buffs like me and for men and boys. I love period war films. ^^ Also what made this film a most enjoyable experience for me, as an avid classical music listener and violinist, is the use of classical music in the soundtrack. I especially loved that very poignant scene - with Corelli's Adagio from his Concerto Grosso in G Minor playing - of the injured Maturin being carried into the scenic Galapagos Islands and also that scene when they reached the Islands themselves with Bach's Cello Suite Number 1 Prelude playing. I also liked the fact that Aubrey and Maturin were apparently not just excellent at their respective professions - let alone Maturin's naturalist hobby - they just so also happened to be an excellent violin-cello duo! This film was truly the best of both worlds for me. In reality though, the adeptness of this pair at so many skills would seem most improbable and make me extremely jealous, but in fiction, well - it's just awesome! xD Although I would have preferred Russell Crowe could have at least have not held the violin so clumsily though. He could have done with several more violin lessons! :P Still, amazing how these film technicians can somewhat simulate the actual fingerings for those pieces into the actor's hands. Not exactly a perfect simulation though as any cellist or violinist, or any musician for that matter, can still tell it's being faked, but very cool nonetheless!Gave this a perfect ten. Even after the fourth time or so watching this yesterday, I couldn't help smiling and laughing like a giddy boy at the excellently played-out battle scenes and especially at that "lesser of two weevils" joke. xD Russell Crowe also really played his character like he truly was Captain Jack Aubrey and I could not help but feel extremely moved and inspired by him whenever he rallied his men during his speeches - as if I was right there among his men, listening to him. This film, unlike most, gives its characters the kind of depth you often only find in book characters; you become attached to them. Like how this film explores Aubrey's struggle to compromise his conviction toward his duty and his men, sometimes having to "choose the lesser of two weevils". :P One may think they are one and the same, but the film shows he often had to choose between one or the other - whether to head back to land to save his best friend's life or chase down the Acheron, to save the life of a man overboard or risk the lives of his whole crew and ship during a storm. The film expounds on themes of fellowship, friendship and duty in a time of war when they become tested. Although I haven't yet read the books yet, I feel confident in saying that this film does justice to portraying the books. I've downloaded the whole collection to the book series just because of this movie and I will get to reading them eventually. I have a feeling that the books will prove equally or more exciting. Here's to hoping that they'll make a whole film series eventually! This is much more deserving of its own series than that superficial Pirates of the Caribbean crap. It would be incredibly disappointing if Hollywood would leave this largely untapped cultural treasure to waste.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: Bettany, Crowe, and considerable atmosphere ALMOST keep M&C afloat
Review_body: First of all, you should know where I'm coming from.  My favorite genre is historical epic, and I am in general a great admirer of Crowe and his films. In this case, though, the few redeeming qualities of Master and Commander, in which Crowe's performance is included, simply do not add up to an end result that is worthwhile. The only reasons I can imagine to see this movie would be if you were researching for an essay about Russell Crowe, find visual effects to be paramount in a film's overall value, or are unqualified in your interest in all things related to British naval history. Aside from these purposes, I can not imagine how a viewer could leave this film satisfied.  While there may actually be a plot, it is certainly hard to discern.  At best, it is disjointed and decentralized. All that being said, this film is still a credit to the acting talents of Crowe and Bettany, and to the abilities of those responsible for its technical merits, of which there are many. Sadly, though, these efforts are wasted on a film that is truly worthless otherwise.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: I must say that if you missed this motion picture in the theaters, you truly missed out. It was an amazing special that left you realizing WHY they invented movie theaters in the first place. If you've read the series of books, Master and Commander, you were left frustrated that they left out so much. Again, its a two-plus hour movie, so I understand. I went with some friends that did not read the books and they were very confused about a lot of things. All in all, it was great to see it as a film and considering how many films-from-books get slammed about the differences, this was no John Grisham, The Firm - type let down.  Russell Crowe did an amazing job and it's unfortunate he was overlooked by the Academy this year, but I guess Sean Penn has been due for some time now - I'm just glad he was there to get his Oscar.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: Authentic, intriguing, a British "well done"!Experience life in the 1800's and on a tall ship, in all its glories and drawbacks. Be transported in time and to the element of the sea, as you enter the mind of a daring man of destiny, brave young lads, hearty British yeoman, and what made tiny England a great empire carrying Christian values to the "far side of the world.""Be British," was their cry wherever they went. No wonder! Modern times are a pale copy of living life to its fullest from a platform of civility and discipline.Now I'll have to see everything else Peter Weir has written or directed.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: A sublime combination of wonders- realistic portrayal of the conditions, pecking order, and priorities of shipboard life in that era. Fabulously cast and portrayed.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: Peter Weir is the director of this film but 20 years prior he directed a film called 'Gallipoli' which was staunchly Anglo-phobic. The film portrays an Englishman ordering the suicidal attacks on the Turkish machine guns when in fact history shows the man ordering the charges was an Australian. Weir was a nationalist in Australia, a proper left winger yet we see him here in M&C praising England/Britain for their fine seamanship and esprit De corps...I wonder why he would do this; the ageing process made him see sense perhaps? :P9 9 99 9 99 9
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: Not just a historical movie--The Historical Movie
Review_body: This is a beautiful movie, an intellectual movie, and an action movie. Flashing fog shoots cannonballs; the moon paints shadows of ropes and climbing crewmen upon the sails; lizards, birds, and insects flee from a pile of opened traps. Military strategy, history, evolution, superstition, friendship, and leadership are all philosophical subjects discussed in the picture. The movie is really about two warships--and their captains--trying to destroy one another, with several minor adventures mixed into the story. The realism is such that never for a moment do you doubt that these people are from the turn of the 19th century, that they are on a ship fighting during the height of the British Empire. This movie is the Das Boot of the 1800s. Although I'd recommend this movie to anyone, if you're really into films with a lot of fast CG cars, CG tentacles, idiotic teenagers, or idiotic teenagers falling in love, you probably won't enjoy Master and Commander as much as I did. If, on the other hand, you're tired of boring historical movies or vacuous blockbusters like The Patriot, this is a film that will restore your faith in the belief that good movies can be made once in awhile, even in this day and age.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: I have never witnessed such camaraderie in a film. The cohesion between the actors and director is visible, it makes you want to drop what your doing and go to Her Majesty's Royal Navy fantasy camp. The story is so fluid it is almost impossible to predict what could happen, yet there's a sense of security knowing that no matter what happens it will undoubtedly pay dividends to the plot. Russell Crowe and Paul Bettany's partnership is truly existential but they make it feel so obtainable. The film relates "strength, respect, and discipline" and truly that is what the film personifies. From the leading role to main antagonist, there's a feeling of respect as well as ingenuity that the story magnifies. It's truly a shame that this franchise did not get to take off, because this storyline has endless potential. This film is a gem and should be immortalized as one of the greats.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: A good adventure yarn. Plenty of action, but linked with some of the (movized) reality of what life on an extended sea voyage in a crowded man-o-war must have been like.Russell Crowe is pretty obnoxious and arrogant in real life and a lot of times that comes across in his movies in my opinion, but not this one. Besides, a number of scenes are stolen by his supporting cast especially the young boys and Paul Bettany who I thought was marvelous as Geoffrey Chaucer in 'A Knights Tale'I particularly enjoyed the string instruments and Russel Crowe's violin technique. In an interview he noted the hardest part of his role was to learn to look convincing playing the violin. He did a reasonable job of it (save his lack of vibrato action to match the music over - but it takes a while to get that far with a fiddle!).An entertaining flick.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: A phenomenal period piece. The Napoleonic War is in full swing and we follow the crew from Patrick O'Brien novels. Master and Commander is a masterfully crafted film from top to bottom. The casting decisions were inspired without a weak link in the cast. Brilliantly built ship sets with excellent effects. All following an entertaining story that oozes an authenticity you rarely see in period films. Highly recommended for anyone who even has a passing interesting in the era or naval warfare.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: Maximus with Guns? Master and Commander
Review_body: Read More: http://basementbanter.com/530-2/Have you ever wondered what would happen if you gave Maximus from Gladiator a gun, a cannon and a frigate? Master and Commander: The Far Side of the World answers that question in glorious, bloody fashion. Master and Commander is an epic naval Napoleonic war movie where Britain and France fought for control of the seas. With maybe the most badass character ever put to screen in Russel Crowe's Captain 'Lucky' Jack Aubrey, and more epic shots than any movie out there, I cannot praise this movie enough. Showcasing more charisma, machismo, and intelligence than any other of his roles; other than maybe Maximus, Crowe becomes the bold and cunning naval captain of the HMS Surprise. Captain Aubrey goes on a daring mission to the far side of the world, chasing a French Ship.Featuring a fantastic cast with several people you sort of recognize like Vision, from the Avengers movies, either Mary or Pippin I can never tell them apart, and some bloke from Agent Carter. Crowe and Paul Bettany (Vision) have excellent chemistry together as they play best friends and trusted confidants. Bettany shines as Dr. Maturin, the surgeon and head doctor on the ship. Dr. Maturin has little nautical experience, so most of the many laughs of the film come from him. His dead pan delivery expressing his confusion about what is going on with the ship creates much needed comedic relief. The rest of the cast are mostly unprofessional actors who have experience on the sea, making the movie feel all the more authentic as you travel back in history to a time of adventure.After his ship is nearly destroyed Captain Jack Aubrey pursues the French ship, The Acheron. It is a new breed of ship that the British have not seen before. The crew of the Surprise go south, around South America and back north towards the Galapagos Islands. The journey pushes Jack Aubrey, and his crew, to their physical and mental limits, testing his leadership and skills as a Captain. From the beginning to the end there is action a plenty, cannons blowing peoples arms off, excellent sword fights, clever problem solving, a man doing surgery on himself (fucking insane), and the best ship to ship combat ever put to film.As will soon become evident, many, many of the movies I love came from my Father making me watch them, this was one of the first ones he made me watch. I watched this when I was 12, and I immediately fell in love with the ocean, and the time period. This movie perfectly blends the swashbuckling adventures of an Indiana Jones or Pirates of the Caribbean movie with the somber and serious take on war and its hardships from Saving Private Ryan or The Hurt Locker.The movie flows between awesome badassery, somber slow moments, and back to action. You will care about all the characters and wince every time someone gets hurt. Every shot that Crowe is in, he improves through his amazing, and complicated performance. All in one he is a bad ass soldier, loving father figure, caring best friend, trying musician, and stern leader. I cannot heap enough praise on him. This is one of my top 20 favorite movies of all time, and I could watch it again and again. I highly recommend this movie, and encourage you to check out other movies by the great Peter Weir. This movie does not get enough attention and while it did get many Oscar nominations, not enough people saw it. I implore you to go see it, all things considered I can almost guarantee you will enjoy it.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: A beautiful, intelligent and touching film
Review_body: As a teenage girl, I did not really expect to like this film, because I usually don't enjoy movies set in wartime. I wasn't prepared for this one, you see! I very rarely respond emotionally to the characters in a movie but this is one exception! I don't know what it was -- maybe the restraint present in each role, particularly that of the anguished midshipman Hollom. When painful things happened to the characters, I couldn't dismiss the characters as overacted or unrealistic -- they are real people and you care about them.I was surprised to read some comments on the film suggesting that the film lacks humour -- I really have to question these critics' definition of humour! Although the film does not contain many deliberately "comic" moments (save the lovely weevil joke!), a gentle sense of humour is present throughout -- you couldn't put this variety of different characters together on one ship and not get humorous situations! Another very strong point of M&C is the music, which combines classical music with modern compositions and complements the settings perfectly.This is a truly beautiful, wonderfully acted film. It can't really be classed as an action movie, which will put some people off, but if you're in a thoughtful mood, I can't think of any more rewarding film.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: Rarely does a film rate a 10 by any reviewer, but "Master and Commander: The Far Side of the World" is one of them. The audience lives life on the HMS Surprise with Jack Aubrey and his crew for a short two hours of this historical epic. It is a believable adventure at sea in 1805. Peter Weir is a master of detail.The characters are real, from Lucky Jack to Cousin Joe. Their dialects are authentic early 1800's, lower class Britain. The cinematography is spectacular, the ship is beautiful in its woodwork and rigging detail and the sounds of creaking masts against the wind are ubiquitous. The roar of the cannons and the chain and bar shot as it rips through the audience is electrifying.The only sense that could not be stimulated by this movie was that of smell. One can only imagine how repulsive that must have been with two hundred men living in close quarters amongst the cattle, goats, chickens and rotting food for months on end. The daily grog would have been the least of two weevils.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: I hated it the first time I watched Master and Commander!! Why and why did people not like it? Why did i change my mind? Let me explain, project and second guess! Well, let me tell you: It was the Marketing. The film with its trailer on TV and Internet marketed the movie as the New Pirates of the Caribbean. Big Ships, Big Battles, sword-fights and all. This raised especially after the success of Pirates, the expectation for Master and Commander to be alike. Yet, what the film really showed, was human relationships at sea, drama, with suspense elements some action and a battle here and there aboard an 18th century ship.That's why people's expectations were disappointed and in terms of Box Office revenue it dropped of so quickly from week 1 to week 2 but not to week 3. That is interesting.The Marketing promised and did not deliver! Would like to know who else had this experience, cheers, R
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body:
This film has prompted me to put some comments here at IMDB, which is a rarity. A movie that takes you by the neck and never looses its grip for the entire journey. For me the thing that made it was its believability. I was there on the ship in the first few moments in the calmness of the fog, then, a distant flash, and all hell breaks loose as the HMS Surprise is pulverised by enemy cannons. Never has an action scene appeared as forcefully and emotional as the first ten minutes of this film.Over the past few years I have failed to `get into' hardly any new action-adventure movies. The Star Wars prequels, Matrix sequels, have all disappointed because of the low believability factor for me. But here is a movie that makes you believe again in the `movies' and there ability to take you to another time and place and feel for the people involved.
Not once did I think I was looking at any computer generated scenes or looking at a ship in a `big tank', so the effects were perfect, that is, they didn't look like effects, they were seamless.So here we have action, drama, adventure on a grand scale. And no BS love connection to annoy the hell out us and the progress of the HMS Surprise.This is a 10 out 10 movie for me.Here is some of my other favourites in no order or significanceTerminator 1, Terminator 3, Titanic, Minority ReportSome movies I didn't likePearl Harbour, Attack of the Clones, Fast and Furious
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: An Evocation of the True Life on Board a British Warship 1805
Review_body: Don't miss the "Making Of" for this film if you have or rent the two-disk DVD set. They bought one ship and made a second one from scratch to make this movie! Weir the director stated his intent to make the movie achieve the above Summarized goal. For my money he succeeded. Ten out of Ten for this one. The use of early music played by the Captain and the Doctor to bring in the civilized nature of both men was brilliant, and Mr Crowe studied the violin enough to be able to accurately act the playing, and the above clips include some of his actual playing. He had never touched the instrument before, likewise his co-star on the cello. There are only a few movies in this category, perhaps A MAN FOR ALL SEASONS is comparable, and I viewed it twice on successive nights. It has so much truly authentic detail and depth of action that it could be profitably viewed monthly for a year. UNMISSABLE. And I had never heard of it before late 2009.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: Greatest naval war film ever made and that's saying something
Review_body: Master and Comander The far side of the world is without doubt one of the most spectacular and riveting movies on naval war ever made. The film starts in the south Atlantic ocean where a battle begins between the British HMS Surprise and the French Acheron. Jack Aubrey (Crowe) commander of the surprise is both himself and his crew surprised and out gunned by the larger Acheron. After he narrowly escapes defeat he goes on the hunt in a cat and mouse game with the french Acheron it 's witty captain who Jack Aubrey knows nearly nothing about. This film is bound to leave even the most anti English fan howling for more. Both the story and the action make this film a masterpiece that will certainly command any screen.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: Such a great movie. Timeless lessons, great storyline, and solid character development. No excessive drama or over the top action like too many new movies today. One of the best films ever in my opinion.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: There weren't too many plot turns or twists, and character surprises or turns, definitely played it safe. A great movie to watch with your great-grandmother. Could have done a lot more with it. None of the characters are exceptionally memorable.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: Not Bad, for a Sea Yarn
Review_body: I admit that I've never read the Patrick O'Brian books. I went and saw this purely for the enjoyment factor. This also means that nothing other than my enjoyment was at stake.The movie itself moves quickly and truly gives you a feeling for the life that these people led at sea. Russel Crowe and the rest of the supporting cast are wonderfully convincing, making one forget at times that you are watching a movie. Invested in all the characters I really felt for them as they lived their daily lives in a small wooden ship, at the whim of whatever Nature and Napolean could throw at them.*Caution* This May Spoil It for some people.The plot for the movie is deceptively simple compared to what you see on film. Jack Aubrey has orders to defend the Brazilian cost. When the H.M.S Surprise is attacked he takes these orders into his own hands and chases the attacking ship for all it's worth. But that isn't what the Director seems to be interested in. Peter Wier gives us the chase, but he shows so much more as well.If you're not into realistic battle scenes and the hard, rather dirty, and very cramped life of the professional sailor this movie is not for you. If you are, and you want to see as close as a filmmaker can get to the real thing, the film is definitely a must see.7 out of 10.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: Seriously, if not for Paul Bettany, this movie would be right up there with Glitter and Gigli. I'm still trying to figure out how I was supposed to care about anyone else in this movie. I wanted Crowe to lose a limb or at least fall overboard or something.Plus, even though Paul Bettany saved the film from total failure, he was playing a thinly disguised Charles Darwin, who is reality a) made his voyage on the HMS Beagle in the 1840s (way later than the movie) and b) did his studies on ecological adaptations of the beaks of finches, not flightless cormorants.The big flaws are too many story lines, too much Crowe, not enough Bettany, lots of actors that can't enunciate, and lack of character development for Crowe's character or the secondary surgeon (Higgins?) or the "Jonah" of the ship. Maybe if the writers/director/actors had made me care, i wouldn't have spent the last hour and a half of the movie hoping for Moby Dick, Jaws, or a combination.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: Too long. Could have been 1 hour shorter.
Review_body: I just got out of the movie.  The movie started out with a bang, but then dragged.  I thought the characters weren't deep enough and there was just too much seemlingly meaningless dialogue.  I think the movie could have been 45 minutes shorter and just as effective.  The movie's trailers lead you to believe it's more of an action film, but that is certainly not the case at all.  Expect to spend 45 minutes after the first 15 minutes watching slow and tedious dialogue.Still, the good parts were pretty good.  The premise of the film is good, the acting is pretty good, but it still only gets a 6/10 from me.  The movie could have been much, much better.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: Historical Fiction is Alive and Well
Review_body: At last we have an "Action/Adventure" film that respects the audience. No skeleton swordfights.  No CGI cast of thousands.  No video game here. This is the real thing. It is P.W.'s best film yet and Russell Crowe IS Lucky Jack Aubrey.  I can only "hold fast" and wait for his next attack on the French or the fiddle.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: I implore you to give this film a fair chance if you are smart.  I went into the theater with high hopes, being a Russell Crowe faithful follower. This is a big different from what I have seen of director- Peter Weir.  Of his filmography, I have seen early Mel Gibson in Gallipoli, early Harrison Ford in Witness, the always go-to Dead Poets' Society, the though provoking and Oscar begging Truman Show, and now Master and Commander. From what I have seen, this is a very different feel from Mr. Weir. The film was not as epic as I expected, but the storyline was well written and easily held my interest.  I've heard talk of Russell Crowe and best actor, which would be an amazing three nominations under his belt.  It was nice to see another performance from Russell Crowe's buddy, Paul Bettany, non-existent roommate to a beautiful mind.   His performance grips you at quite painful times, in which you really feel his character's pain.Filmed on the same waters as Titanic, I must say that this film is much more deserving of academy recognition.  I don't know if I can quite say best picture, but I hope to see a not to Mr.  Crowe, soon-to-be-new-father.  I would love to see a best picture nomination, but it seems my vote will probably be going to Return of the King. By the way, to any LOTR fans, Billy Boyd's performance was quite enjoyable.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: I hate those movies that you watch for an hour and still have no clue what's going on. Such was the case with this movie. The dialogue was so soft that it was little over mumbling much of the time. The plot twisted and turned so much that I couldn't make heads or tails of what was going on. After an hour, I turned the movie off in frustration. Other than them being a British ship fighting the French, I never understood anything more of the movie. Perhaps more narration would have helped. As it was, I was too frustrated to watch the movie further. The movie "Dune" is still my #1 worst movie I've ever watched, but "Master and Commander" is a very close #2.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: Dull would be a little harsh but not far off the truth
Review_body: There are some nice points...The Attention to detail and the sense of place... The film however is without soul, feeling or any emotive drive whatsoever. RC plays yet again his stock New Zealand actors role (what happened to the guy we saw could act in A Beautiful Mind).. The film is messy you simply dont care one iota for any of the characters.. At one point rounding the Horn A sailor has to be sacrificed, the scene is so lacking in any power or feeling .. You would be hard pressed to even know which character has been lost.. The Galley scenes are pathetic with no narrative or plot drive and come over like some weak soap opera. The Surgeon is well potrayed but only works when hes on his own, when hes with RC even the blocking of the scene is embarrasing to watch as they fumble with there musical instruments..(NOTE to directors things that work in books dont always work on film)...One puzzling aspect to the film is why there is a lack of cohesive thematic scoring..this would at least give you some clues as to where the drive of the film is because you would be hard pressed to catch it in the performances.. Instead we have to put up with inserted excerpts of Classical Music which are all totally inaproppiate (what the hell is Vaughen Williams fantasy on Thomas Tallis doing in there)..Absolute waste of time...It resembles a film where so much time was spent on second unit work that the director failed to realise he didnt have enough coverage to actually put a story together before it was to late...
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: I have been reading this series for years.  I think that the movie captures the essence of what it must have been like on these ships in the early 1800's.  Russell Crowe is Jack Aubrey.The naval battles were brilliant, and frighteningly real.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: Love to Hate, Hate to Love
Review_body: A movie that moves equally too slow and yet too fast; too many action sequences and yet too many scenes where nothing happens. A movie that will make you cry and laugh with joy is what Weir has brought to the screen.Crowe who plays the infamous 'Lucky Jack' in another role that bloody well suits him makes you want to hate him. He has to much pride in him that could kill his whole crew and his best friend Steve tells him that. But still he goes with what his head says not his heart until his friend gets shot.But you got to love a guy, who plays a violin so well and can make a crew smile even in a middle of a crisis. The crew themselves work together like glue to paper. The child actors act more older than the adult actors in some instances and they prove themselves.Master and Commander: The Far Side of The World, with a nine word title does drag and it cannot be helped when a peep of the watch is done. It is no excellent film, but it is a very good film nonetheless.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: I thought that this was a very good historical insight into seafaring life of the time, but couldn't decide if the periods of the film that were dragging were intentional to demonstrate that much of the time life would have been so or that it was just a slow plot. Russell Crowe was very good in the role in demonstrating true leadership. Supporting performances were adequate but what this film lacked was any love interest or background of any of the crew including Aubry the commander.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: On leaving the cinema last night, two women in front of me complained that the film was boring, and that they should have stayed in and watched Eastenders. How foolish. This is a fantastic film on a number of levels. Firstly for those of you who are proud of your heritage and have had enough of Hollywood constantly denigrating the British, then fear not, because this portrays us in a positive light. Secondly what a wonderful picture is painted of life in the early 19th century Royal Navy- the songs, the food, even sleeping, or how the decks were converted before action occurring. It shows the grim realities of war at sea, and just how difficult it was to sail these magnificant looking ships.The game of cat and mouse between the French privateer and HMS Surprise is broken up by these interesting sequences. The doctor is well placed, because he can play devils advocate without incurring the penalties of mutiny etc. The climatic fight scene is as good as anything I've seen in a cinema. Russell Crowe is as ever on imperious form, as is Paul Bettany. However the young midshipmen- unlike their ship- are not wooden, with some fine performances, certainly talent is there for the future. James D'Arcy comes of age with a well crafted performance showing an array of emotions.Splendid effort all round. Bravo. What a way to return to the naval genre!
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: This was such a great movie, I'm in total shock.  I had expected to fall asleep half way through since this isn't really my kind of movie.  Do not expect a boring battleship war movie with lots of talking.  The  fighting scenes captivated me right from the beginning and pulled me into the ocean with the rest of the crew.  The story was fun, the cast were personable, and the directing was great.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: I was quite eager to see this film, being a fan of historical films/books, and I wasn't disappointed. A nice mix of action, humour, music and the occasional poignant moment made this one of my favourite films of the year. I'd recommend it strongly to anyone.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: Epic scale onboard a single ship
Review_body: This movie simply left me astounded because of how different it is from any other movie being made today.  It doesn't follow the traditional progression of movies with typical villians and heros, typical plot twists and typical pacing.  This is simply the time in the life of British sailors.Bad things happen, and some good arises from it.  It all progresses as a real adventure.  This movie is almost a documentary.  A documentary that is incredibly entertaining and spellbinding.Russell Crowe gives a wonderfully subdued performance.  Whereas other actors may have gone over the top with cliche sailor acting, he has a subtlety that speaks bounds more than any cliche dialogue.Everyone else aboard the ship gave their part just as they should have. Nobody was out of place.Definitely a contender for Best Picture.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: This could have been a great film.
Review_body: This film is very interesting if you like looking for what went wrong. It has a great cast, director, a beautiful enviroment, and awesome special FX... But there is something missing. I am not sure what it is, but something is not right about this film. I have some ideas, though. first: the characters.. there is no sense of depth in any of the characters. they don´t tell anything about then, like where did they came from, and what they want. This fact can explain my other thought on this film: it looks like a chapter of a much longer story, like it started from the middle and did not come to an end. That may be why this film looks so long, without any strong characters and goals, its never clear where the story might end. this could be a good thing, but not in this case.. it just makes the film a somewhat unpredictable, but also uninteresting. To sum up, I would say that this film is not worth it, I would rate it as a 5/10, just because of Russel Crowe and his great performance (as usual) and some of the action sequences.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: Just not my kind of film
Review_body: Although the acting was phenomenal, I found the story to be a bit drawn out and uneventful for my liking.  I'm sure that the historical accuracy was most likely right on the money, I just wanted more.  I felt that this film lacked enough conflict, internally or externally.  One word about the plot, there was none.  The film makers spent so much time trying to get so much in the film, the story itself was lost.  You'd do better to watch the Pirates of the Carribean, or even the ride at Disney Land would be more enjoyable than this film.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: amazing recreation, makes understand way old sailing was
Review_body: The film is a notable recreation about the old time sea adventures, that not only included battles or storms, also the daily and ordinary problems they had. Perfect setting and as usual in Peter Weir's films, explores every detail to illustrate his heroes main problem: how to face and solve their existence in a difficult and adverse circumstances (places and people included)
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: Having seen this film touted as Oscar material, and being something of a fan of Russell Crowe and Peter Weir, I bought this DVD on spec. Sorry to say, I was disappointed.Although supposedly based on a true story (it was written in the early 70s as part of a series, and loosely based on a real captain in the Napolenic Wars.) In short then, it is not supposed to accurately reflect a historical event.Which left me wondering why not simply tell the story of Nelson at Trafalgar, since we're asked to believe Captain Aubrey was a friend of his anyway? Instead of being a strong naval figure who can inspire his men like Captain Bligh or Hornblower, in M&C he comes across as a rather bland older brother. We find out he is intent on pursuing a french warship whatever the cost, but why, is never explained? At no point is he particularly wronged, and at no point did I ever really feel the HMS Surprise was in any danger.Likewise the relationship with the ship's doctor is supposedly full of humour, and double-act of sorts (according to the publisher of the books.) However on the screen the relationship came across as bizarre - a slanging match between the captain and the doctor over whether to go and collect animal specimens or fight the French??? Who exactly IS in command here?And as before, since the doctor is essentially a fictionalised Charles Darwin, why not make "The Voyage of the Beagle" - the movie - instead of this pulpy serial?In short I found it wholly lacking in character development, I didn't really believe many of the characters, and those that I did I still couldn't care whether they lived or died.A shame.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: A beautiful film that rewards repeat viewings.
Review_body: I must have watched this movie a dozen times, without tiring of it. The performances are excellent, and having read all of the Aubrey-Maturin canon as a result of seeing the film I can testify to the sheer faithfulness to character and period detail. Very unlucky not to win the Best Picture Oscar, this is such an immersive experience you can practically smell the sea air and feel the canvas.Plotwise, this is very much a composite of the books as no doubt many viewers have pointed out. For me the only drawback about this is that it rules out the possibility of a sequel. Probably Paul Bettany's finest performance to date, and he's a year younger than me, the talented so-and-so.Just watch it; this is the closest any of us will get to the Napoleonic War and 19th Century medicine. Unless we get treatment on the UK National Health Service of course.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: When I first saw this movie in the theaters, I was only moderately impressed. I'm not a big fan of Russel Crowe, but he is certainly one of the best actors of our time. After seeing this movie a few more times on TV since, I've now come to really enjoy it. It's just so well done. It's a credit to the masterful Peter Weir who kicked butt on the Truman Show as well. He is an intelligent director who doesn't have to have a neatly wrapped Hollywood happy ending with his films. Master and Commander is strangely satisfying, exciting, touching, and suspenseful all at the same time. Russell Crowe really wears this role well. Paul Bettany is a fantastic actor as well, and takes on the doctor role here with skill I thought. It's definitely worth the price of admission.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: It's amazing for me to think of warfare conducted at the whim of the wind, yet these sailors would almost drift alongside on another and fire at point blank range. I enjoyed the first battle were cannon balls from Acheron can seen flying through the air towards HMS Surprise - considering the low velocity of those guns - you possibly could have see a shot coming and ducked for cover! I found Russel Crowe thoroughly engaging - even more so in M&C than in Beautiful Mind. The scene in which he helps the doctor in surgery on the island is fascinating. One gets a wonderful feeling of the cramped spaces with men moving about in crouching positions due to the low decks. Having visited some of these ancient fighting ships in maritime museums, I realized that they were quite small and flimsy by modern warship standards. Continuity: I agree with comments about the ship making 5 kts with her sails limp. Is it my error or does Lord Blackney's arm grow back? He seems to have two hands on his sextant when their second encounter with Acheron gets underway.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: Master and Commander: The Far Side of the World is an engrossing and deeply fascinating film that offers a detailed look into naval warfare in the early 1800s. It faithfully adapts the works of Patrick O'Brian by telling the story of the British warship, the HMS Surprise, and her crew's mission to seek and destroy a French privateer during the early phases of the Napoleonic Wars. The story highlights the hardships and brutality of the conflict, exemplifying the myriad dangers and perils that sailors faced before, during, and after battle.The story is centered around the film's protagonist, Captain Aubrey (played by Russel Crow), and much of the plot revolves around the cat and mouse hunt between the two ships that are set upon each other's destruction. Several intense naval battle scenes punctuate long stretches of tension and subsequent character development as this time is used to demonstrate the juxtaposition of both the fierce camaraderie and the growing resentment and unease between sailors at war. While the pacing could be seen as slow and perhaps plodding at times, the strong performances and painstaking attention to detail make for a thoroughly enjoyable viewing experience. How much the viewer enjoys him or herself however, is really dependent on how he or she enjoys either history or maritime adventures, so take my fervent recommendation of the movie with a grain of salt. The score of the film is also worth mentioning as it is one of the best examples of atmospheric ambiance in a manner that is simultaneously accurate to the period portrayed and effective at establishing tone in various types of scenes throughout the film.All in all, Master and Commander: The Far Side of the World is one of the foremost examples of a movie about naval warfare and is an absolute must see for enthusiasts of the genre or anyone with even a passing interest in the subject of maritime history.Score: 9 out of 10
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: Not a movie for the stupid.........
Review_body: How nice it is to watch a movie that concentrates on the relationships between the characters rather than relying solely on cheap thrills from explosions and gunfire. It's true that the action is transferred from the Angl-American war of 1812-1815 to the Napoleonic Wars in order to appease American sensibilities but it's still a fascinating insight into how the Royal Navy of the day operated. I won't bother mentioning the main points of the plot seeing as plenty of reviewers have done so already but I will offer a word of advice - if you're unlikely to appreciate this movie's finer points then stick to watching Rambo I, II, XXVII etc. Those are the movies you're more likely to respond to - you redneck morons :0) .
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: Russell Crowe mumbles his way to the far side of the world
Review_body: I appreciate that a great deal of research and effort went into the production of this movie, and that if you are a genuine navy buff then you will find such an astonishing level of detail a delight (as other people have commented here). If like me however you are not such a glutton for authentic early 19th century naval warfare then you may find this movie a tad dull. Yes the production values are excellent, yes the movie is well shot but as for the quality of the script I have no idea. Not because I wasn't paying attention, but because I basically couldn't hear a word of dialogue. Russell Crowe is a great actor (should have beaten Denzel to the best actor Oscar for a Beautiful Mind) but for some reason his acting in this film consists entirely of talking gruffly under his breath. Jack Aubrey may have been the most inspirational character to grace the screen in the past 50 years, but all I could think was 'speak up you mumbling idiot!' Not for the hard of hearing.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body:
Certainly one of the best movies of the year. Rare is it that you find a Hollywood release so true to the novels from which it was developed.
Although it is a fictional account, it is very accurate in its portrayal of the time, as well as life on board a British ship of war.
From what I've read of other comments, those who had cause for disent based it on relatively minor points, whether inconsequential or in keeping with a particular historical detail.If the battle scenes seemed loud and confusing, that's an accurate portrayal of how they were (and are).If there were times when the movie moved along sluggishly, that's because life onboard a ship in those days was even slower and largely more mundane, punctuated by brief moments of brutal fighting.Most of the negative comments I've read seem to reflect a lack of understanding of both the novels and historiocity behind them. On the other hand, those familiar with both, even if they haven't read the books, will immediately appreciate the attention to detail down to the smallest levels.
As another commentor said, and I agree, I think those who walk away disappointed do so because they were expecting a modern car chase at sea with lots of bright flashing explosions, all moving at a rapid pace they're more accustomed towards.Without a doubt, this movie is destined to become a classic not only in its particular genre, but on its own merits, as well.Once in a while, Hollywood surprises me and gets it right. This is one of those times.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: Boring, slow and lacking in plot.
Review_body: This movie was pretty blah in my opinion. I waited the entire movie for it to pick up, and it just never did. Disappointing. My husband, however, liked it, so maybe this is just a man's movie. The acting was overall pretty good, but the plotline was not very developed and there was no real build-up or excitement in what was marketed as an exciting adventure film.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: For 2+ hours, I was one of the guys...
Review_body: You know you're watching a good movie when you forget that you're not IN the situation, going through the actions and -- in this case -- being (or being close to) a total badass.  I'm about as wimpy as they come, yet in different spots throughout the film, I had such the urge to get up and scream my enthusiasm like a wild animal foaming at the mouth.  This film has everything:  flawless casting (Crowe will be up for an Oscar again), incredible cinematography totally done on location and bone-tickling sound. As a lover of "chick flicks", yet a hater of that term, I will say that this is a testosterone-soaked film that anyone (male or female) with a hunger for a good story will leave having only been appetized...to see it again!
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: My comments are brief.  I thought this was an excellent movie with wonderful performances from the entire cast.  The ships, sets, costumes and cinematography were amazing.  The story kept me interested from start to end and overall it was very satisfying.  However, possibly my most favorite aspect of the experience was that this movie tended to only attract s. There wasn't a single teenager or child in the theater.  It was a refreshingly mature audience that made the movie-going experience thoroughly enjoyable.  I am the parent of four children and enjoy watching movies with them, however, sometimes it's nice to leave the kids at home and not join everyone else's at the theater.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: Almost perfect realization of the novels
Review_body: Peter Weir & Russell Crowe at their best, beautiful seascapes, exciting chases and battles -- what more could you want?  The relationship between Aubrey and Maturin.  This relationship is central to the novels, but almost background to the film.  Furthermore, the film is ABOUT Aubrey, not the two of them, and Aubrey is shown to be a man without apparent weakness (far from the case in the books).  Perhaps this was intentional -- it certainly streamlines the film, and removes some pesky complexities which one could argue are easier to sustain in a literary form.  Nevertheless, I felt something was lost.  But go see it anyway, even if you're a fan, it's still a dynamite film on its own.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: I found this movie to be very slow and way too long.  I must have checked my watch 6 or 7 times while sitting through it.  The final battle scene was engaging, but it was very difficult to figure out who was who during the fight.  I think you have to be a fan of the books or a fan of this type of seafaring story to enjoy this film.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: Totally disappointing. The sound editing was particularly weak and certainly contributed heavily to this film's downfall. Bring a magazine and a flashlight. However, if your not a reader, bring your pajamas.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: See this one in the theater while you can.
Review_body: This movie is visually stunning, and the plot is not bad at all either. The 2 hours plus running time goes by in a flash.This is the type of move that you must see in the theater. If you wait until the DVD is released and watch it on your home system you will be saying to yourself "I wish I would have seen that in the theater!" The large cannons blasting and all the action is fully appreciated with a large cinema sound system. At the theater I saw it at I could feel each cannon blast reverberate through my entire body.Very enjoyable, highly recommended. 9 out of 10!
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: It is a very poor movie. I expected much more than I got. The story was not enough to fill a two-hour movie. The characters were not arranged well. There is no challenge among captain and others who oppose going further after the first battle. I have to add that there was no sympathy toward the characters. In fact, its normal to feel that invaders deserve to be defeated. So you don't feel compassion toward the English guys who attack the French ship and ultimately were killed. I was really disappointed from this movie. The only good part of it is character of Doctor and nothing more.He has some points to make, but the captain is too stubborn to change his mind. On the whole, no challenging characters, no surprise and no new idea in this movie. I would score 3 out of 10 to this movie.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: This is a movie for the boys who always imagined what it would be like on a sailing ship back in the days of sailing. For over two hours you are literally on that ship with the crew scrubbing and fighting; in the end I was very glad to get off that ship.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: A Masterpiece, no matter what you folks say!
Review_body: I can understand people not liking this movie.  They have just seen Pirates of the Caribbean and The Return of the King.  They were expecting blood, and thrilling action from the beginning to the end.  And what did Mr. Weir gave them?  A long, detailed tale of how life was on a war ship, those who look so beautiful from the outside, but were nothing like a vacation to live in for months and even years.  And that is awfully hard to do!  It merely proves how great a director Mr. Weir is, and how good actors Russell Crowe and Paul Bettany are.  This is a movie for those who can go a little deeper into every situation that's shown to them, and this is a movie for those who can understand how hard it is to move cameras in such little space.  I think this is a magnificent movie, that from now on will be considered the reference for all age of sail movies.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: Real and well performed, a must see.
Review_body: Even if the plot is not so dense of facts, to tell the truth everything starts from and goes on - from the beginning up to the closing titles - with the seek for the Acheron to the point that, at first sight, the spectator will come to think that every other scene has been added in order to make the movie a little bit longer, this is one of the movies that won't delude you. It's superbly shot (probably the director will receive a nomination to the Oscars, in case he won't we will know that critics are blind) and well balanced. Although the plot is centered on a battle, in fact, we have more by this movie: we can enjoy the true meaning of friendship, a relationship that endures despite opinion divergences and that eventually overcomes even navy orders, we will be light up by our commander firm authority just as his crew and finally we will win the fight against Acheron.Involving and real as never seen in movies of this genre, this is not a film everyone can look at: scenes like the surgeon's self operation are not tolerated by someone, so if your neighbour puts his hands on his own eyes you'll now why he acts like that!About the cast there's nothing to say except congratulations. Everyone has played his character in the finest way. Russel Crowe could really have been a frigate commander, even if sometimes he smiles too much for an authoritative Jack the Lucky. Anyway he should gain another Oscar nomination for his skill in playing such characters. We've yet seen him in "The Gladiator" and here he's not changed too much, impressive. Paul Bettany is the perfect companion for Crowe and as he did in "A Beautiful Mind" even here he is perfect. The surgeon isn't of easy interpretation since it's a double faced character.
