He cannot understand why his captain can be so wayward in following his orders so that he cannot forgive his friend to have broken his promise, but he is able to recognize the true friendship that links them when he finds himself on the Caymans shot and near to death. He cannot share the same views of his friend but he doesn't hesitate to set aside his interests when needed. These opposites find an unique harmony in his performance and this makes the surgeon so fascinating.Photography is enchanting and gloomy as needed in such a realistic sailing movie. Every shot is orchestrated so that the spectator feels part of the crew, struggling with them to obtain another victory for their commander and master of life Jack the Lucky.No one can say, after Master and Commander, it was easy to be on a frigate but everyone would love to have been on it, at least one time, at least as a spectator.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: Master and Commander was just wonderful. It shows that you do not need a love story at all for a terrific film. I was very surprised that there was only 1 woman..and Russel Crowe looked at her for about 1 minute, and that was it. The plot is very interesting, sad, but joyful and fills you with excitement. I would recommend this movie to anyone. Some of the jokes lean toward adults, but the action and advneture of the film would be appreciated by all ages. Hip Hip Huzzah for M and C!
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: Great movie, needs to be seen!
Review_body: This movie is one of the greater naval action movies out there. Crowe does a great job as Aubrey, this role was made for him. Although it's a little confusing in the beginning, it pulls you in. You never leave the area of in and around the boat, so its a little hard to get a grasp on world events and the motivations of the captain/crew, but overall this was great! Not too much gore, the filmmakers used camera shake very well during the battle scenes to help stay with the PG-13 rating, so this is a Crowe movie (unlike Gladiator) that the younger ones might be able to watch also.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: Russell Crowe delivers a stunning performance yet again in what is definitely an Oscar worthy role. Crowe stars as Captain Jack Aubrey, a British ship captain in 1805 who is given orders to disable a French ship and help stop the dominance of Napoleon.The film starts with a near miss as the two ships do battle, then follows Aubrey and his crew in their quest to outdo the bigger and better equipped Acheron. It gives an interesting viewpoint of what life at sea was like during this period.Master & Commander also marks the return of director Peter Weir (The Truman Show, Dead Poets Society, Witness). He is also equally as worthy of an Oscar for his work, provided they haven't already etched Peter Jackson's name on the statuette.Visually stunning and masterfully acted, I believe this is one of the best movies of the year.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: I will review this movie on three levels. First, regarding the writing: Very good. the plot touches on the expected themes of duty, honor, and loyalty with some interesting asides, although I found Crowe's Aubrey to come uncomfortably close to the stock "commander" figure: wise, modest, dutiful, firm but compassionate. Having said that, however, we see Aubrey's sense of duty really tested against personal loyalty. We also see, no matter how elevated the rank and "enlightened" the personality, superstition still is part of the fabric of the day to day life aboard a ship of the nineteenth century. There is also an intriguing attempt to "pace" the film by repeatedly cutting to shots of the ship's hour glass being turned over and the ship's bell being rung to mark the watches. We also see the conflict between the two ships as something of a very drawn out duel: the antagonist, though unseen, takes on a personality. In the quieter moments we see the French captain given his due by Aubrey without fanfare.On a technical level, I regarded this film as being almost flawless. I don't think I've ever seen a better rendition of "Wooden Ships and Iron Men on a Bounding Mane"...the miniatures are flawless, the water effects first-rate, motion control superb. I've noted that in other movies of ships at sea CG has a very hard time rendering the boundary between a hull and the water, as well as the wake. From what I could see this movie neatly sidestepped most of this problem by using low angles that obscured the waterline by hiding it behind a swell. It isn't pronounced and felt quite natural. The last level I want to mention is historical authenticity. Clearly this movie was well researched and comes pretty close to accurately portraying ship-board life at the time. When I saw how well the film transported me to 1805 I found my expectations raised to the point that I felt a few elements got short shrift. Firstly, we see no effort to impress sailors, a common practice at the time. Also, I felt we didn't see an accurate portrayal of shipboard discipline: whippings and beatings were a lot more common, even aboard ships with so called "benevolent" captains. Also, it was a common practice to spread sawdust on the decks prior to battle so that the crew could keep their feet when the decks became slippery with blood. This was barely touched on. Can you imagine the sense of foreboding this element would have added, especially in the second battle scene after, say, we had been treated to a view of decks literally running with blood? I believe including those two elements would have helped enormously. Also, in one scene we see an attempt to disable a ship using solid shot against masts rather than other ordnance that targeted the rigging. These are however, minor quibbles from a maritime enthusiast looking for a flawless time machine. My only real annoyance with the movie are the scenes where we see the captain and his surgeon "jamming" on violin and cello. It is the most inept mismatch I've ever seen between what we are seeing and what we are hearing. Crowe is totally unconvincing in his depiction of a musician. We might as well be seeing him playing "air violin". We hear at one point a trio and there are only two instruments. We see a cello playing but hear a viola. After all the fidelity given to other elements in the story the effect was quite jarring. That said, however, I'm certain for the majority of the movie-going public it'll be quite adequate. I believe this'll have a long run in the theaters. Huzzahs for Peter Weir, Universal, Miramax, 20th Century Fox, and Samuel Goldwyn Films. I give this film a nine out of ten.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: Kind of a slow movie. Hard to get into at first. Got better toward end. Good actor's both older and young.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: Sorry to say, but truly I can not think of the other 9. Best Costumes, a sure winner, but even in that department LotRIII would give it a run for its money. Furthermore, I just found it plain boring. In the end it got exciting for a brief moment, but when they discovered the subterfuge, the movie was over, and that could have been the cherry on top of a rather dull cake.The acting was not even what I hoped for, the humor was nice, but when you expect to see action, and only hear a few jokes during the first 1,5 hours, they sound rather out of place.A mere 6 on a scale of 10.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: It will make your heart glow.
Review_body: I would say this is my favourite sea story and I wish for a sequel like no other. First of all the acting is top class, Russell Crowe, Paul Bettany, boy it is a joy to watch them and the rest of the artists. I am not gonna spoil the story for you, easily my top 100 favourite movies of all time.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: This movie is so packed with characters, details, humor, subtexts and action that I had to see it again right away. I loved it the first time, but the second was even better. I can't wait for my third viewing.If you felt so-so about it after the first viewing, *go back.* You'll be richly rewarded.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: Beautiful Portrayal of life in a navy vessel in 1805
Review_body: I would like to start by saying Bravo! I liked the story, the execution of the story by the actors and the director. Russel Crowe really depicted the Captain well and I thought that the supporting cast were superb. The photography really enhanced the scope of the story, and I must take my hat off to the photographic skills of the photographic director.One tends to forget that this story is not a high speed chase film with lots of blood and gore however it does have its share, although, the speed of the story is greatly paralleled by the speed at which a sea chase would have happened 200 years ago.It is great to watch a movie that really gets to the heart of the emotions of the crew of a Man-Of-War vessel, not just making the crew look like the hardest SOB's around.And to that I take my hat off to the Cast and Crew, as well as the writers and the director and producers of this production.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: Superb combination of direction and performance with stunning effects
Review_body: Peter Weir's genius for creating enclosed universes is breathtakingly displayed in this powerful expansion of his talents into the epic. On every level,from that of popular entertainment to those of thoughtful historical and psychological investigation,this is a gripping piece of work. Russell Crowe uses his genuine charm and humour to create a character who is not simply heroic but complex. The remaining cast are perfect in every nuance of authentic shipboard life in 1805. The spectator becomes so immersed in the action that the state of the art special effects never intrude simply for their own sake. One of this year's best movies.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: This film was overwrought from stem to stern.  When all was said and done, the only interesting character is Paul Bettany's.  When the credits rolled, it really didn't matter what had happened to anyone, I couldn't get invested enough in the lives of these characters.  If you want to see a great movie, look elsewhere.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: Well acted, well written, well directed
Review_body: Everything about this film was enjoyable.  The acting was top notch, with some "unknowns" in it was a joy to see.  Max Pirkis as the young midshipman had a lot of focus paid him; what a fine young actor who portrayed the role perfectly.  Many films with the "young" sailor portray them with almost sappy or cute style; M&C did not.  The writing of the script left no bad feelings on my part; a great story told effectively.  The directing was perfect; it would easily had botched this movie if a different director had been chosen.The music was one of my favorite parts; some "period" music mixed with more contemporary British music helped me accept the characters into their roles with ease.I plan on getting a DVD as soon as it's out!
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: the joy of imagination, the age of discovery, and advice for those handicapped by short attention spans.
Review_body:
having never read any of the novels in the series of the same name, i can make no comment as to the accuracy or quality of this film in respect to its adaptation from book.  what drew me to view this film, something which i was very excited to do as soon as i learned of its debut, was not its cast nor its director, but the interest i have in anything related to the sea, sailing and the lost age of great sailing ships.  i went with the hope that this film could get that right.  while there are many minor details which i can easily take objection to, i walked away very satisfied with the recreation of life aboard sea which this film portrays.
this film accurately portrays the life that would be confronted at sea in so many details.  the great dichotomy between the lives of officers and the lives of deckhands, rightfully portrayed by differing foods served to the crew and officers, their respective living quarters, even the quality and quantity of conversation which these two, often adversarial sectors of the ship would enjoy is seemingly true to form.  the long, post-dinner conversations amongst the officers over glasses of port punctuated with humor and marked by a literate and skillful ability to speak, share stories and entertain in a manner which predates television and our hurried society is starkly contrast by the "old salt", a cinematic cliche perhaps, below-decks as he warns of the bad luck experienced by all crew each time an unpopular and inept officer holds watch on deck.  these crew would most certainly have been illiterate, uneducated and from the poor classes of england and would have been very susceptible to the superstitions and paranoia that long periods at sea could induce.moments of intense experience are strikingly contrast with long periods of little event: a man lost overboard and the effects of broken rigging trailing in the sea abaft are successfully portrayed (even though one must acknowledge that any verbal hailing to the overboard crew would have been inaudible and that his honest chances of getting back on board were nil in those sea conditions), as are the long, tiring and dismally hot days (sometimes experienced for weeks) that would most definitely have been encountered in the doldrums near the equator.  the immediate elation experienced by crew during the strong  rains which followed such a sweltering and monotonous episode is well done; one feels good for those on film as they dance happily on deck.while there are so many other great and subtle moments in this film, and admittedly some aspects to the plot and character development which fall short (one must "suspend their disbelief" during a few occasions), the film is excellent overall.ultimately, and i have read many other's reviews of this film, what any viewer needs is realistic expectations.  this film is not set in our cell-phone frenzied, sound-byte age but unfolds in a time when time itself was experienced very differently.  when new worlds (such as the galapagos) were first seen in the flesh and not on television or on-line while booking a flight.  can we imagine what this experience would have been like?  are you interested?  if yes, then please see this film: you will greatly enjoy it while overlooking the minor shortcomings which it does possess. however, if you've never engaged your imagination upon what has come before and how it may have been, if you have no curiosity about life at sea during the great age of sail, no passion for exploring new worlds and can sense no mystery beyond the horizon as you lay upon a summer beach, headphones concealing the sound of the breaking waves, then i do have strong advice for you: stay at home and watch football, i guarantee you will enjoy those three hours so much more.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: Old time sea adventure updated (a few spoilers)
Review_body:
Every 20 years, Hollywood remembers a genre that needs a good update, and this year's genre's been sea adventures. First, one of the best movies of the summer, "Pirates of the Caribbean" (congratulations to Johnny Depp for his nomination) and then, now, one of the year's best movies (with permission of "The Return of the King", probably the best).
"Master and Commander, The Far Side of the World" Is more than a "ships movie". A wonderful story, full of the details that give depth and feeling to a movie. Script, Characters, Landscapes, Music and Stages are first quality, as all the cast. You know when cast & crew believe in what they are doing, and this time it's obvious. Peter Weir, First-class director and writer, builds a majestic movie around a majestic story, where every FX serves to the scene, without overloading it. His sense of narration is great, and a long and not-full-of-action movie elapses in an eyeblink, leaving you crying for more.One of the things I liked most was the relation between Capt. Aubrey (Russel Crowe) and Dr. Maturin (Paul Bettany). Both, strong and experienced men, share an educated, artistic mind that comes in conflict when Aubrey, a Soldier, must choose between carrying out his orders, or make Maturin's dream of become the first scientist in the galapagos come true.To sum up, a deep and intense movie, very real and realistic, that deserves the 10 nominations that has received.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: I found the movie to be rather disappointing. It was boring, not enough action and there wasnt one moment in the entire movie that made me sit at the tip of my seat. When it was over i felt like i wasted 2 hours of my time.Rating: ** (out of 5 *)
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: A wonderful tale worthy of legend.
Review_body:
Master and Commander is one of the best movies I have ever seen. It portrays life at sea during the era of the wooden warship wonderfully. There are those that have commented that the characters are not explored emotionally. Of course they weren't! Those where the days of wooden ships and iron men. On top of that they were serving in the Royal Navy, the English Royal Navy that is. Emotion was not a thing one indulged in during that time period on His Majesty's ships! I thought the movie portrayed very well the "life", it did not show the downtime, fair enough, but who wants to watch a movie about a bunch of sailors doing nothing for weeks on end? The downtime was implied, you had to look for it...Now for the things Master and Commander brought to the screen (and the public awareness about that era).The ship: beautiful! A wonderful recreation of the beautiful sailing and fighting vessels of the time. What a time that must have been when men sailed the world and every new port was a discovery mission of a kind, when they had to rely on their wits and skills to get through every day.
Lucky Jack: I have only one question about Lucky Jack. Who did he p*** off to end up with a 28 gunner? In 1805 the British ships of the line (the wooden walls of England) where a little more capable than the 28 gun probably a "6 rater" that Jack commanded. At the time Vice Admiral Lord Nelson was sailing the Victory, she was a 104 gun "1st rater" and there weren't too many ships in service that were too much smaller than her.Other than that I loved Russell's character, who couldn't? Tough but fair, a man of Honor, a born leader of men, and a good Friend to his best Friend (the doctor). Someone mentioned earlier that he was the Captain Kirk of the high seas. Well did anyone else notice that Jack's best Friend was the doctor? Kinda like Kirk and McCoy... Is it any wonder that Star Trek turned out that way given the source? Gene Roddenberry was a WWII B-17 pilot. He knew a little about the relationships that men build during "trying" times. I think that the writers of Master and Commander understood this too. That is why Jack is who he is and he chooses his close Friends wisely and he holds that friendship above all else. Captain Jack is a wise, interesting, multifaceted character. Maybe a little too perfect, but there must have been men like him somewhere in the service in those days, so why weave a yarn about a lesser man? I still wonder who he p***ed off to only command a 28 gunner! ;-)The Life: Well done! The hardships of a life at sea are well documented in this movie. The grisly account of medicine 100 (or so) years before another Englishman discovered Penicillin. The bug infested food (the lesser of two weevils). The food in the sailors quarters. The mess becoming the sick bay in times of battle. The Captains cabin being assembled and disassembled depending on the situation and time of day. The age of the young Officers and the powder monkeys. All brutally but honestly truisms of the time not portrayed well in most other period pieces that have been committed to film.The Directing/Writing: Better than par... I loved the fact that you did not get to "see" the battles from the perspective of the French. That was masterfully done. You only got the perspective of the English crew and because of that you lived their lives. You had the feeling of being one of them, you felt the way that men in that situation would have felt. If they filmed both sides of the battles it would have been as if you were an observer from the "10,000 foot view" and not a member of the crew. Besides, you didn't know what was going to happen in the end. If Quentin Tarantino had written and directed this movie both ships would have gone down with all hands... ;-)As a "fan" of the era of the Royal Navy's fighting wooden ships (which covers about 400 years) I was greatly impressed with Master and Commander. It was a triumph of modern cinema to bring to life a time we can only dream and wonder about. Sure Jack was a little too perfect and some of the crew were a little too brave but that is the stuff of tall tales. Tall tales of the sea, after that film I wish I had the oppotunity to join Jack and his crew on every voyage. That is what movies are all about.
Well done!Martin
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: It starts out very slow but it seemed to be a good movie. It picked up pace and slowed down again at points, but i expected as much of a sea movie. I was surprised by some of the actors abilities in the movies, such as Crow and the good doctor. So different roles from their previous movies. Its a fairly long movie but well worth the rental. It was a movie that kept both mine and my husbands attention and that sometimes is very hard to do, as we have different tastes in movies for the most part. There are a few sad points in the film that just about brought tears to my eyes as well as a few funny points that almost had me laughing. According to my husband the movie was very badass, in a good way so to speak.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: A great worth seeing movie! *minor spoilers*
Review_body: Master and commander is definitely one of my favorite movies, perfect performances by the cast, Russell Crowe and Paul Bettany make wonderful performances as Jack Aubrey and Stephen Maturian. Lot's of new faces such as James D'Arcy, Edward Woodall, Robert Pugh, Chris Larkin and so on. The Midshipman in the movie are very promising young actors, Max Pirkis, Max Benitz, Jack Randall, Richard Pates are very good young actors, Lee Ingleby also plays a Midshipman. The story is well set, Russell Crowe plays Jack Aubrey, the captain of the Surprise, Paul Bettany plays the ship's doctor. Hunting the French ship the Acheron in the pacific, makes a good movie. 95% of the movie takes place on the Surprise, a stop is made on the Galapgos islands is very beautiful. The acting is superb, beware, this movie does contain some very sad deaths, one of a young kid. Very exciting, wonderful music, great cast, including Billy Boyd, Pippin from Lord of the Rings. Contains some language, nothing to bad,a lot of Lord of the rings type violence, a boy's arm gets amputated early in the film(the camera is focused on the boys face.), the doctor has to do surgery on himself(a bit graphic might want to cover the little ones eyes or have them and weak stomachs out of the room), there are dead bodies seen at the end, this might be very sad for all of us, especially young children. i recommend that 11 years and up for kids. A must see!!! 11 out of 10 stars!!!
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: It gets 10 out of 10 for cinematography and 4 out of 4 for story
Review_body: If you have never read the books I would imagine this is quite a sweeping adventure and Russell Crowe has the charisma to carry it along. Peter Weir was painstaking (but not quite enough) in his recreation of the British Royal Navy at sea during the Napoleonic era. Paul Bettany did a creditable job as Steven Maturin. Lee Ingleby stole the movie as Hollom - that is one self-possessed kid and a damn good actor.Now, for those who have read the books (which I have) this movie stank. It is a beautifully filmed Discovery Channel special that had me squirming in my theater seat wondering what it would end. Peter Weir and John Collee rewrote The Far Side of the World into an unrecognizable mess with one plot and no subplots. Get the French ship. (That's your plan? Get her?). What he did, essentially, was rewrite the plot into Desolation Island, stripped of a) the intrigue, b) the espionage, c) the Dutch, d) the on-board epidemic... I could go on. I like my movies a little more meaty, please, especially when they're based on some very fine novels.There is no depth to the characters or the plot. By the time the action of this entry in the series takes place, Maturin and Aubrey have been friends for years but you get no sense of that from the actors. During the action sequences you are never given any reason to care about what happens to the characters (except for Hollom and that was solely Mr. Ingleby's efforts) never, ever made to hang on the edge of your seat. Mr. Weir is notoriously bad at creating nail biting moments for all that he's made several films that included tense action moments - he simply has no sense for creating them.Overall, this was quite disappointing for the amount of talent and money that were combined for this movie. In the hands of a director like Ridley Scott this would have been a masterpiece of both acting and action.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: The Best sea tale I have seen to date
Review_body: Me being a seaman in the US Navy for four years and spent a few years in the merchants serving on board cruise and cargo ships in both oceans Atlantic and Pacific. I honestly think director Weir has put together his best Maritine sea saga yet. The crew looked like a crew on an 18th century sailing vessel. the costumes were authentic looking. There was a scene near the end where Crowe was up on the poop deck standing on the starboard side , the cameras was panning away from him, To me that was a classic pose.Everything about that picture was done well. Since the first time i saw this film i must of watched it about a dozen times more . My hat goes off to all who were involved in the making of this fine motion picture.I also understand that originally the french ship was to be an American one , but was changed for the American audience.One other post script There was a scene of a few crew members on there hands and knees scrubbing the wooden deck with a cobble stone what they were doing for the land lubbers out there is called holy stoning the deck. Its like sanding the old wood off the deck surface bringing up the new wood this is a practice that is still done today .
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: Just to be fair a couple of factors are going to influence my review:I was a devoted fan of the P O'Brian Aubrey / Maturin novels before seeing the film. Of lesser importance but still relevant, I served in the RN for 6 years (enjoyed it but don't regret leaving either..).In summary, I had more than a passing interest in (and affection for) the subject matter before seeing the film.It's difficult for me to judge the movie as a stand alone entity: for me it'll always be a companion piece to the books. Like many other viewers, I sat down to watch it with a sense of curiosity and some apprehension: will it do the books justice? Which characters will they include? etc. etc.To quote Emily Wilson in the Guardian: "People love the books for different reasons. Sailing buffs adore O'Brian's remarkable attention to accuracy and detail when it comes to life on board a ship of war in the early 1800s. (By about book six, one feels one could confidently captain a ship-of-the -line to India and back, or perhaps throw together a jury rudder, without too much loss of face.) Naturalists adore the bugs, birds and wombats dear Maturin lugs aboard at every port - he's a keen collector, as well as an excellent and adventurous ship's surgeon. Spy buffs adore his secret life as a top intelligence officer - when he's not sawing someone's skull off in a force nine gale, or filling the captain's cabin with bees, he is generally to be found ashore on some perilous mission against the evil French/Spanish/Americans."Other reasons are the deftly handled comedy running throughout the books - more of which later - and the visceral, heart pounding sea battles, often the crescendos to expertly ramped up passages of tension. You can almost smell the slow match burning, feel the anticipation as the ship finally clears for action and the gun crews run 'em out.I'm glad to say I wasn't disappointed. I was completely immersed from the opening minutes of the film, when the Acheron's broadside came thundering out of the fog and swept the Surprise's deck. I thought the pacing and structure of the film was perfect: the temptation or potential studio pressure to 'over Hollywood' the thing, to cram in battle after artificial battle sequence, was resisted. The result is much more authentic for me.The attention to detail was spot on but, to be honest, it should be with the amount and quality of source material: anything less would have been criminal from the producers. It's more a tribute to Patrick O'Brian's research on the subject than anything.One observation rather than criticism concerns the two main protagonists: Aubrey's character came across to me as less flawed, less comical than in the books: his often hilarious ineptitude in most areas of life other than fighting his ship was missing, but then there wasn't much opportunity to show his being 'all at sea on land'. I also thought this coloured the on screen relationship between him and Maturin and that the balance wasn't quite right: Maturin's character sometimes comes across as slightly weak in comparison overall. Then there's the near complete lack of plot relating to Maturin being an eminent intelligence agent, bar one brief hint. But then there wasn't really the opportunity to show this true depth either.This perhaps curtailed (did you smoke it...) on-screen portrayal of the two principal characters (versus the wonderful depth in the novels) is potentially the main issue for some viewers, particularly in Maturin's case. I can understand it but ultimately it didn't bother me too much. I accepted it as part of an inevitable loss in adapting such detailed source material into a 2 hour screen play.Special mention goes to David Threlfall's Twice Preserved Killick, a real joy to watch. I agree Billy Boyd was slightly miscast as Bonden but in the grand scheme it wasn't a problem for me.I think the movie's greatest achievement is that its simultaneously a great screen adaption of the novels and a great stand alone movie in it's own right (though as I said the latter is harder for me to judge).I'm not sure about a sequel: it'll be hard to improve on this. Perhaps in hindsight the ideal scenario would have been to make a trilogy, with each movie roughly drawing from the corresponding third of books, so that the first film would have been set before this one. Maybe they should make a prequel - Cacafuego anyone?
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: There was a lot of attention to detail in the production of this film, but the use of tree-dwelling green (common) iguanas from South or Central America to represent Galapagos iguanas was a major error that impacted the credibility of the film. Related animal shots as seen through the telescope from the ship were also hokey, and one shot of a swimming marine iguana actually appeared twice in this film (same footage!).Many people have noticed the fact that the relationship between the ship's commander and the ship's doctor could not carry the film. In fact, this relationship goes nowhere. The commander behaves inconsistently, letting a man die to continue his pursuit but then suddenly going back to the Galapagos when the ship's doctor is injured. It just didn't make sense.The best things about this film are related to the realism of many of the action scenes at sea, which happen quickly. Key areas that should have been improved substantially to make this a great film are: 1) Total lack of development of the character of the French adversary (huge lost opportunity here), 2) Lack of developed or adequate sense of time and place during a very long ocean journey (quick transition between tropical latitudes and the southern ocean), 3) Lack of clear explanation to the audience (or to sailors in the audience) of positioning relative to the prevailing winds during each combat sequence, and 4) Lack of depth in the main character. It was also hard to understand how the French could miss the gun ports and overall structure of the vessel when it pretended to be a whaler. Would British officers really be this young, or is this based on an adventure story for young boys?Some of these weaknesses may have been due to limitations in the works of fiction from which it was based (I have not read these). The shooting the albatross scene and the becalmed at sea scenes were right out of the Ryme of the Ancient Mariner. The Galapagos material was reminiscent of the Voyage of the Beagle by Charles Darwin, including Darwin's interest in beetles. Nonetheless, as a whole, it was a very good action film, just not a great one.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: Great story with powerful performances. Sweeps you away to 1805.
Review_body: A very complete tale, interwoven with beautiful cinematography, powerful performances (Russel Crowe, especially), masterful score (Bach, Motzart...to name two),and a truly believable storyline with many twists. At the heart of which is the conflict inside Capt. "Lucky" Jack Aubry (Russel Crowe) who balances his duty to the British Empire and his personal relationships with friends and crew members on board the HMS Surprise. All this while playing cat and mouse with a french enemy vessel that is twice his ship's size and double her strength. The conclusion is a great blending of commonality of human cause and duty. All in all, this is one of the most well rounded stories I've ever seen on the motion picture screen.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: This is my first review ever. I've seen this movie twice. First, a few years after release and I rated it a 7. Decent movie, not a lot of action but overall fine. Now, a decade and a bit older, I've seen it again and rated it a 9. It's - in my humble opinion - one of the best historic movies ever made. It really depics how crude life on a warship could be (not that I've been on one, but I've read some books about it). I love the themes this movie covers: Choosing the lesser of two (we)evils, leadership and patriotism. I just love this movie and I recomment you to watch it too.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: At first I didn't think it would be up to much but I was mistaken. My mate persuaded me to watch it and i thought it was brilliant. Russel Crowe did the part credit and Paul Bettany supported him superbly. The story line was also a BIG plus for the film. I enjoy films and programmes based in that period so maybe thats why i enjoyed it as much as i did. But people who aren't big fans of these types of films still enjoy it. People may claim 'how could Crowe do what he did when the French had a superior ship and superior man power ?'...well he did and they could've ruined it concerning this fact but they didn't. They made this film brilliantly and considered all details. If that wasn't enough what a good ending to keep you guessing and improve it that little bit more!
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: This is an extremely good movie, successfully recreating the atmosphere of the era. The special effects depicting battle scenes and adverse weather conditions are especially good. So, too, are the costumes and make-up.I have, however, one criticism to make. Captain Jack Aubrey (Crowe) is shown on more than one occasion aloft in the rigging while the ship is sailing along. I am pretty confident that no Royal Navy captain would adopt this pose. The concept of sailing along in the rigging is more reminiscent of Kevin Costner in "Waterworld"! Apart from this one small breach of etiquette, a thoroughly enjoyable film.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: This film at first seemed like it was going to be drawn out. It does start off with a pretty good action scene, then it slows down a bit. I also thought the film would primarily be only based on the ship (which it does for most of the time except towards the end when the crew decide to land on the Galapagos islands for a bit). However the down time in the movie became really fun to watch. The film displayed the crews individuality and tells the story about them and how they lived on the ship for weeks of not seeing family back home. Also it is interesting to watch how rank is treated on the ship. Russel Crowe does an amazing job in the film and so does Paul Bettany in his role as well. I enjoyed how the two actors characters developed over time in the film and how they both seemed to care for each other. Overall the film is fun to watch, it does have a rocky start and seems to start off slowly, but it makes up for it with a good story and some great action scenes.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: OK I just saw Master and Commander for the first time and loved it! But as I have not seen this mentioned anywhere else, could someone please explain why that guy was sitting bare butted in the snow on the side of the ship when they were sailing low around the Horn? Punishment or Piles perhaps. I am not a big fan of Crowe because of his off stage antics, but you can not deny that he is a great actor and this is by far his best yet. I was wondering why a French ship of this period would have been built in Boston, but I see from this site that it was an American vessel in the novel. I wonder how our take on this film would have been altered it they had left it as a War of 1812 battle instead of the Napoleonic Wars?
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: This past weekend, I toured the HMS Surprise, the ship that was used in M & C and I was reminded of how much I adore this movie. That this film was not awarded Oscars for Best Picture and Director has to be one of the hugest errors ever made by the "esteemed" Academy. M & C is something of an anomaly. Here's a movie about the glory of Old England that was financed by Hollywood studios, filmed primarily in Mexico, directed by and starring Aussies! The villains are the French, which struck me as sort of funny. And this movie is a celebration of values that seem so alien to us today; in M & C, patriotism is a virtue. It almost makes you want to shout "Hurrah for British Imperialism!" Almost. Now I'm no historian, so I can't comment on the authenticity of the battle scenes, but the important thing is that this movie is gripping and feels realistic. There's a nice balance between the battle scenes and the portrayal of daily life on board the frigate. It's all so beautifully done, with my favorite part being the crew's first glimpses of the Galapagos islands. I'm a big Russell Crowe fan (is there any actor who is more likable on screen?), and this is my favorite movie of his. My favorite character, though, is the brilliant doctor, brilliantly played by the underrated Paul Bettany. The doctor is a fascinating character, a sort of proto-Darwin, and makes a nice counterpoint to the captain. If you haven't seen this movie because you were put off by the trailer, know that the trailer did not do the movie justice. The brilliance of this movie is that even if you don't care about the Napoleonic War or British naval history, you will still be entertained and even touched by M & C.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: This is a brilliant movie for those who appreciate how tough it was before steam powered ships. Also just a brilliant movie about discovery and well acted by all.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: I my opinion the director makes a great movie out of a mediocre story. Shows the horrors of a naval battle and the daily life of sailors in an hostile environment. Great play by Crowe and the rest of the supporting actors
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: The action scenes were pretty gripping and the whole feel of the life on board with the old salty dogs came across pretty well, but the film suffered from a distinct lack of plot. There were times in the movie where absolutely nothing was happening, there were no unresolved issues and no reason to be watching. I got bored and I saw Russell just acting too hard.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: Master and Commander succeeds not so much in the fact that it has an exceptional plot, but in the fact that it carries the viewer along on its voyage exceptionally. It follows the voyage of Captain "Lucky Jack" Aubrey sailing for the English empire while being chased by a French vessel during the Napoleonic Wars. It's not an entirely innovative or original plot, but it's the experience rather than the plot that drives this movie. The chemistry between the characters and strong performances by all is what make it an exceptional movie. Rather than casting good-looking Hollywood types as crew members, Peter Weir went after people who look like believable seamen who are also great actors in their own right. The cast even had a sort of boot camp training so that everyone knew how to make the ship function. It is this attention to detail that make the movie so believable and enjoyable. Rather than indulging itself in melodrama and Hollywood type moral-based clichés, this film pulls no punches about how it perceives the workings of a British Naval ship to function in the early 19th century. It simply bleeds authenticity at every corner. Excellent performances by Crowe and his doctor right-hand-man played by Paul Bettany only add to the thrill.The film also has a great original and non-original score which makes it flow perfectly. The interaction between the ship members is what makes it a success. Though 2+hours may seem like a long time to spend with an all-male cast inside a ship, I was never once bored. Instead, you truly feel like you are in the ship with them and at the end you feel like you would want to follow Russel Crowe's "Captain Jack" virtually anywhere he would lead.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: Finally an action movie that doesn't use or need the common parlour tricks to try and get us to care about the characters and the action.  You got to experiance the whole adventure without any overdone foreshadowing or music to tell you to "care about this because it will be important later" or "Lets make sure you know just how well these guys get along or don't get along with a couple of unnecessary shots of overdone emotion".  This movie assumes you can think and will watch and pay attention.  For paying into that, you don't get let down.  The action sequences are incredible and the story is handled in a way that is so rare in Hollywood today that I'd almost forgoten what it was like to enjoy a movie from the ground up.  It's ending is wonderful in that it doesn't fall into a forced package that Hollywood feels every big movie must have.  This movie is a classic for a genre that has been forgoten.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: Set a course for L.A. Oscars here we come!
Review_body: Master and Commander is a visually impressive movie that takes you on a journey into the lives of a Napoleonic-era war ship.  Crowe is the captain, and you, as the viewer, become a member of his crew.  The battle scenes were really cool, and the symbolism runs deep.I certainly could not help thinking that the movie was dripping with Oscar politics.  You could almost hear Crowe yelling out in the movie, "I WANT ANOTHER OSCAR!"  As a matter of fact, you could tell which clip they will show if he is nominated as it appears in the film. It was very clear that this was an Oscar vehicle for both Fox and Peter Wier.  That, however, didnt stop me from liking it.  I dont know if they can actually bring home the gold in March or not, but I think they deserve the nominations that they get.Overall, it was a good "ship movie." Many critics called it boring and dull. They obviously were not sitting where I was, because I went in unsure and came out pleased. Go see it, as it will lose some of its value in your living room.7/10
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: I finally got a chance to see this movie and I was not disappointed! I was unfamiliar with the source material (Patrick O'Brian's novels) but it didn't matter much. This is a movie that takes you back to the days of Captain Blood or the Sea Hawk. Finely made in every way (10 Oscar nominations), Russel Crowe is terrific in the part of Capt. Jack Aubrey and Paul Bettany is great as his friend and alter ego Dr. Stephen Maturin. Kudos especially go to Max Pirkis in the role of the very young midshipman Blakeney. This is not a movie with a message but one made for entertainment's sake and it does that on a grand level. Highly recommended!!
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: Good but not great enough to make another
Review_body: I saw and enjoyed this film when it was released before I had read any of the Aubrey/Maturin novels. I've just watched it again on DVD after having read and (even better) listened to Simon Vance or Patrick Tull give the characters human voice in the audiobooks and I like the film far less now.They are called Aubrey/Maturin novels for a reason...Stephen Maturin is a complex and mentally (and sometimes physically) tortured character that either Mr. Bettany could not portray -- I doubt that, he seems like a good enough actor, mad monks withstanding -- or the character's heart was removed in editing the final release. I also think it was a mistake not to have included more romance. We have to do more than toast 'wives and sweethearts' to feel the risks of sudden death are above contrivance. My wife taught me that the best way to think of Aubrey/Maturin stories is as complements to the novels of Jane Austen. Jack and Stephen are the men that those heroines are waiting to come home. I venture to say that the movie would have had a better box office if it had found time to portray Sophie and Diana in the flesh.Ultimately, the movie makers try to stuff too much of a twenty book series into the first of what was obviously meant to be a multi-picture franchise. Does anyone remember getting the DVD preview of M&C:TFSOTW in their Sunday paper before it was released? Felt to me like the film had tested badly and the producers were doing anything they could to find an audience. Peter Weir is too competent a director to have crafted this whole thing with no central story -- so I blame the mishmash that ends up on the screen on studio meddling.Too bad...Mr. O'Brian's books deserved better handling than this. That said, I would probably have spent money to see the next film. Especially, once I had heard that Heath Ledger was to replace Mr. Crowe in a prequel. Now whom could they cast as Maturin to give that character more fire? Shorter in stature - Stephen is supposed to be half Jack's size - less of a pacifist and deadly when required - a Napoleonic Dr. James Bond. Tim Roth would suit if he were younger.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: Apart from some good art direction and a very good storm scene in the first act, this was a major snorer. Silly little morality tales. Manipulative and simplistic.  The final battle was a mess.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: The movie has its high points, but they are far and few between.  I found much of the movie to be boring and have no bearing on the plot, such as the endless minutes they spend showing the ship sailing through a storm.  In addition the movie focuses so much on the side of the British that you don't really understand the plot, or the perspective of the French in the movie. The battle scene between the two was terrible as far as cinematography, with the battle lines being impossible to discern.  Rental at best in my opinion.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: I love this film; it's simply amazing. Superb acting and the great chemistry from Crowe and Bettany that we saw in A Beautiful Mind, also one of my favourite films. It has the perfect blend of action and dialogue, moving from battle scenes and action to some very witty lines and also the tense and powerful scenes between Crowe and Bettany when conflict arises.The music score is brilliant in this film, including things like Bach, plenty of cello and violin music as both these instruments are what Aubry (CRowe) and Stephen (Bettany) ply in the film and wonderful directing from the amazing director who brought us 'The Truman Show'. The atmosphere in this film is great, realistically true to what it would've been like at the time and the plot is simplistic yet clever. I highly recommend this film!
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: If you enjoy gripping historical dramas this film will blow your socks off. Master and Commander is definitely a success because is achieves excellency in many of the different facets of filmmaking. In this film the HMS Surprise pursues and eventually after many hardships captures the French privateer the Acheron. One of the many facets successfully mastered in this film is photography or cinematography. The way that this film is shot makes the viewer feel that he or she is on the ship. The use of different angles such as looking out of the gun ports at a battle or through a telescope are very impressive and immersive. I think that the cinematography was very effective and that it blended well with the other components. Cinematography feeds into editing and this film was also very well edited. The editing did help me discover and understand the theme as well as other components of the film, however the film felt a little jumpy at times. This makes sense because it is difficult to portray even a full day on a warship of this time period without getting boring. The setting, costumes and makeup were totally authentic, period appropriate, and accurate. They created the perfect atmosphere for the film and helped the viewer understand and even empathize with the characters better. They did this by vividly showing the effects of battle, hardships, and daily life aboard the HMS Surprise which allowed the viewer to momentarily step into the shoes of one of the sailors and experience naval life first hand. The setting the HMS Surprise was built as a replica for the film and was very well done. The actual ship replica was used during the filming and they fired with real gunpowder (obviously not with cannonballs) and the ship replica actually sailed. The costumes were also quite accurate the typical sailor cloths and big wool jackets during storms as well as the uniforms. There was a distinct difference between the officers blue uniforms and the marines red uniforms. The makeup was great as well. It showed slightly graphic wounds, blood on the skin and stains. One negative aspect of the makeup is the flogging scene. When a sailor named Joseph Nagel was flogged 12 times for disobedience the wounds did not resemble those of actual flogging, the skin was barely ripped off. This lacking depiction of accurate flogging is most likely due to the pg-13 rating that restricts the amount of explicit gore in a film. Another aspect of filmmaking which was mastered was sound. I am a colonial and naval history nut, but through all of the documentaries and videos I have watched, I have never heard a more realistic interpretation of an18 pound lead cannonball flying through the air. The sound in this film was totally effective and completely immersive. The sound not only accurately captured the terror of battle but the other sounds only found on a ship on the open ocean. Such as the crashing of the waves against the ships hull, or the swaying and creaking of the men in the bunks as they sleep, and the sound of the sails unfurling and filling with wind. This film does a better job of capturing the naval environment that does 20,000 Leagues Under The Sea. In that film the ship felt like it only became important when it was destroyed by the Nautilus smashing into its hull. And the battle scenes were much more accurate in Master and Commander than they were in 20,000 Leagues Under The Sea. In conclusion Master and Commander was a very successful film in the aspects of sound, setting, cinematography and editing with a few minor criticisms. It was the best most accurate depiction of naval life and warfare in that time period of any other movies out there in my opinion.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: The acting of Russel Crowe is boring! He is unable to show more than two different faces. All the time he's smiling smart even if he lost a crewman or got shot down. I wanted to see a dramatic sea-movie like "The Bounty" with Anthony Hopkins and Mel Gibson but there was nothing like this. It was just a modern action movie. Russel Crowe is unable to act any emotions. He got the chance to act as a captain between hate and desperation, but he doesn't. I tried to find something special about this movie but only the Special FX an the design of the ship rescued this movie. Sorry, but I've only seen a few movies that were less boring than this.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: I first saw this film about three years after it came to theatres. As always, im late in popular culture.All too often, the British Empire has been portrayed in a very negative light. There's some understanding to be had with that issue. Change is painful. Expansion is painful. Exploration is painful. But with those initial pains, comes healing. And when that healing comes, its sometimes the scars that bear the greatest fruit.To say such a thing from the seat of what might be called "White Privilege" could be construed as highly insulting.But: with the British Empire came Medicine. Technology. Systems. Order.At a time when the world was all too often in chaos, order, good or bad, was brought to bear.To me, nothing embodies this more than the Royal Navy from this period.To have people embark on leaking wooden ships, fed from spoiled and salted food, and fueled by ever present cane rum, and succeed? This is proof of miracles.Russel Crowe's portrayal of leadership in adversity, and his adept handling of a tenuous balancing act was absolutely brilliant to me.This film, to me, was THE example of the British Spirit in its "good".Strength, courage and honour under adversity.Always.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: It´s 2020 and I just saw this movie for the 10th time. 17 years have passed and there are a just a few films of this caliber. The staging is remarkable, it makes you feel like been there. The film takes some licenses about realism, but it's very accurate to be an entertaining movie. The script is great and even if some people may find the ending a bit disappointing, I find it great. Its a movie that tells a story at the needed rate. It don't have only action, but it has enough.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: Loving the movie made me read the 20 books
Review_body: The movie Master and Commander is a masterpiece in sharing the feeling from the 20 books in the Aubrey - Maturin series. I re-visit this movie from time to time and I am always entertained. You get to follow captain Jack Aubrey and Dr. Stephen Maturin as well as all the crew of the corvette surprise in a way that few other movies manage. The fact that it won 2 out of 11 academy nominations is humbling considering the competition being "LotR: The return of the king". I wish there will be sequels but seeing that 17 years have passed since this movie makes that implausible with the same actors. Luckily there are 20 books to draw great content from.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: Truly AWESOME movie, captures the Era perfectly. Paul Bettany and Russell Crow are just perfectly casted, in my opinion they're best work. Everyone is casted perfectly, man what a vastly different time period. Watching this EPIC film never gets old. BRAVO!!!
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: Brings the novels vividly to life
Review_body: Having read all 6,510 pages of O'Brian's beloved Aubrey /Maturin seafaring epic (several times over) I was overjoyed to see Weir's painstakingly crafted homage to this masterpiece of naval literature. This film, like its source novels, was grossly underappreciated upon initial commercial release yet both have proved over time to be enduring , finely tuned works of art.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: This is a great movie, just about nothing to complain about. I'd just question how well it's an adaption to the books. I think Russell Crowe and Paul Bettany are great actors and made a great film... I just was expecting something rather different when I read O'Brien's novels. If you wanted to make films with actors more consistent with the characters in the books, you'd probably want to cast John Goodman as Capt Aubrey, and Steve Buscemi as Dr. Maturin. THAT would be a film to see!
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: AWESOME!!! It made you laugh, cry and sit on the edge of your seat.  Any movie that can accomplish all three of those things is WELL worth seeing.This movie is a MUST see event and one of those movies that you have to see on the big screen to appreciate it.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: Overall an excellent try to stay true to Mr O'Brian's vision.  The use of several tricks from different books kept the pace of the movie fast and with little time for boredom.  However I don't think the characters of Jack and Stephen had much of a chance to show the true bond and affection for each other. Also there was no mention of Dr. Maturin's other career with British intelligence.  Possibly these can be corrected if a second movie is made.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: The absolute best of it's genre, bar none.
Review_body: If you enjoy some reality in your swashbucklers you will be somewhat astounded. They have never made one any better. If what you want is a cartoon and a good laugh try Pirates of the Caribbean. While it has nothing at all to do with reality 'Pirates' is still plenty of fun.This one is a movie best suited to those who understand something of sailing and/or naval tradition but it is also of interest to those who want more from a character than just blood and more from a movie than just an endless and mindless series of fight scenes. While there is brutality in the movie, much of it is implied, with very little of the explicit gore that is used to draw in the mindless masses. Most of the sickening reality is kept just off screen. You get the idea, and that's what's really important, with just enough 'blood and guts' so you are aware of it.There are no real weak spots in this film. There are plenty of strengths. Sound is amazing. Acting is superb, although it's not a movie that lends itself to an acting Oscar. Like a ship that requires all the crew to 'pull together as one' the movie takes an almost ensemble approach with a host of character actors each contributing to the complete picture.It's very realistic in it's portrayal of life at sea and the interaction between crew members, including the need for discipline and mutual respect, the necessary pecking orders that must be maintained, and the brutal realities. Each of these people, regardless of rank, cannot survive without the knowledge and teamwork of their fellow crew members, from the lowliest on up. If you've ever been aboard 'HMS Rose' or USS Constitution, as I have, you have basically been aboard HMS Surprise and the French privateer Acheron. Acheron is based on the USS Constitution class of 'super frigates' and HMS Surprise, while somewhat based on the historical HMS Surprise, is actually "HMS" Rose; a replica British Frigate you will find at most tall ship events throughout the world.My only complaint with this picture is the ending. A sequel is implied, which would justify the ending as it is. Without a sequel it just doesn't have the necessary finish.One more thing...and this is very important at this time. You can view this movie many, many times with nearly the same level of enjoyment. In a time when people are trying to build libraries of movies and getting stuck with too many movies that just don't have any legs beyond the first viewing this is one for the library. If you like it once you will like it again and again. That can't be said of most movies.See this movie.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: An extraordinary performance by a performer of extraordinary talents.
Review_body: I have seen two Russell Crowe films; Gladiator and Master and Commander, The Far Side of The World. I was hesitant to see Master and Commander for fear that Mr. Crowe's performance in Gladiator might have been a fluke. Master and Commander proves, beyond question that Mr. Crowe's talents are exceptional, his capability limitless, and his films of a remarkable caliber, and quality rarely witnessed by this movie viewer. And these qualities are consistent in both performances.I have found Mr. Crowe's films to be much like a good novel; difficult to stop before they end, and much enjoyed with repeated viewings.I have discovered one negative quality about Mr. Crowe's films: when I've finished watching all I have, there is little else that proves sufficiently, or equally as entertaining to watch.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: A worthy tribute to the author, Patrick O'Brian.
Review_body: As a Patrick O'Brian fan (and an avid C. S. Forrester fan - Hornblower Series - before that), I awaited this production with mixed emotions.  I am pleased to report that given the marketing-driven changes of years of the action and the adversary, the Producer, Director, Actors, and Production Company (all) did a remarkable job of capturing my visions of O'Brian's oh-so-precisely written words, 'just so,' and 'with not a moment to lose.' To an O'Brian purist, they faced a very difficult challenge and achieved a most satisfying result.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: Same character names, completely different intent.
Review_body: As a long-term, die-hard fan of Peter Weir's films I find it hard toimagine how he could possibly have written this screenplay. Afterfinishing the final book (number 20) of the acclaimed Patrick O'Brian"seafaring tales" starring the honorable, bold and eminently sea- capable Captain Jack Aubrey and his lifelong friend and companion thesecretive, brilliant Stephen Maturin, and having watched the filmtwice, I can't help but wonder how such a miscalculation could haveoccurred. Weir's use of political commentary (such as has appeared inthe past with his films Gallipoli and The Year of Living Dangerously)is plain. In this case, he decided to make his primary focus theBritish Empire's naval ambitions in the 19th century. Unfortunately, neither Weir nor his lead actor Russell Crowe seemed tohave comprehended the greater intent of the series in the slightest.The Aubrey of this film seems to be a domineering, ignorant captain,painted with a thin veneer of civilization. The character of Maturin issomewhat more believable, though radically one-sided; his status as anagent for Britain completely overlooked in lieu of his hobby -naturalist - which ends up making much less sense in terms of theoverall story. Further, Weir's decision to use elements from a numberof the novels (from the first, Master and Commander to at least the10th, The Far Side Of The World) ends up diluting a consistentstoryline in order, seemingly, to provide more more sea battles.I challenge anyone who has read the series to enjoy this film, and anyfan of the film to not cry "foul!" upon reading the series. While it israrely if ever fair to compare a book to its filmic counterpart, thisinjustice to Patrick O'Brian, who the Chicago Tribune proclaimed to be"the best author in the world" cannot be overstated. The true magic ofthe series lies in its detailed treatment of its characters and thereality of life during the Napoleonic War, its subtle but pervasivehumor and its dedication to higher values such as honor and duty. Whatwe're left with after distillation of so much material is a domineeringcaptain who appears mostly annoyed at his surgeon, a surgeon whoconstantly complains about the Naval service and a plot which seems torevolve mostly around ship battles. Whatever the movie is, it bearslittle substantive resemblance to the stories and characters portrayedin the novels.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: I just finished watching this flick.The story, in and of itself, was solid - however, at times it was needlessly slow paced, a bit like wading through old pudding. I know the movie was based on two books (which I admittedly have not read), and I have gathered that it sticks quite close to these books - but, as far as pacing goes, there are things that work in literature, that just don't work in movies - unless you have the characters and the acting and the dialogue to back it up. And even then...Now, about the characters...I'll get the positive stuff out of the way first. Max Pirkis, as the Blond Boy Who Looses His Arm, was the most accessible, sympathetic, and memorable character in the entire movie. The ship's doctor comes in a solid second - I think his bland lines/ direction had more to do with it than his acting/ screen presence, which were pretty solid. Then comes Russel Crowe's character, which was suitably boring, predictable, and bland (the same character has been seen in countless movies/ stories since...ever). The ship's crotchety cook was quite entertaining - actually, I found him more entertaining than Crowe's character, so we'll just bump the cook up to slot 3. After them...nope, no one. The rest of the characters may as well have been cardboard boxes with English accents and bad teeth. The movie attempted to make you care about the entire swollen roster of characters...or, at least, I think it did. Rather lame attempt, in actuality. Before the Jonas subplot played out (which I'll mention in a moment), I found them all to be quite boring and indiscernible - which was fine, and to be expected, given the movie they were inhabiting. Then came one of the (pointless) subplots, in which the entire crew, hit with many runs of bad luck, blames a young man for it. They then drive him to kill himself through psychological torment and social ostracization. All this because of irrational superstition and the ramblings of an old man with a head injury. Now, I know that this is perfectly believable, as is the fact that the captain seems to feel the same as the crew. But then the movie tries to make me agree with the jerks. It did not have the intended effect...I found that to be just as disgusting as the act portrayed. From that point on, I was kind of hoping that 40% of the crew would meet a violent end. When the final battle with the French vessel finally rolled around, the only thing I cared about was seeing a couple choice s.o.b's die. And they did. Aside from Max Pirkis's acting, that was the only tangible entertainment I got from the entire movie. Oh yeah, other characters died as well, but pfft. However you cut it, the viewer should care about the characters he/she is following, should care whether they live or die. In this flick, whenever they showed a character's death, or the other characters crying over it, I was checking my watch. What, another cardboard box got stepped on? Whooptie-tit, recycle.Now, the movie had some good scenes. The battle scenes (all two of them) were suitably exciting, the two main surgery scenes (kid - arm, doc-on-self) were excellent, in both acting and direction...can't remember any of the others... It had some great shots, and some great costume design. It was pretty. But even then - being a sailor in the Royal Navy back then was far from pretty. The whole movie was too clean. Too shallow.All in all, I found this movie to be 35% enjoyable, 85% predictable, 90% visually appealing, and 100% "meh."
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: Master and Commander is one of the most perfect films I have ever watched. I don't think there was an extra scene, not a useless line, everything about the film is perfect. The end though, no spoilers really, was ... well I sprang up out of my seat and hollered at the screen, slapped my leg and wish the movie would never end. The more I thought about the film, the more I read into it, the better it became. It is more than a war film or a sea film, it portrays the old world, and the new together. Yada yada, won't go on but you all must see it.Weir was robbed, he should have been given the Oscar instead of Peter Jackson. I've never watched the Oscars since.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: Not one of the better pictures of the year.
Review_body: Much of the audible language was garbled & the Fight Scenes too confusing. The ships action never seemed real. The acting was great but somewhat boring. I enjoyed the music more than the action.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: Great Movie that's chock full of hotties!
Review_body: Master and Commander was definitely one of the best movies I've ever seen. Great for fans of O'Brian's novels. Great cast of wonderful actors that nobody's ever heard of, which is probably a good thing. The love between Aubrey and Maturin was very strong. Watch out for the hot faces of Nagle and Hollom.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review title: One of my all time favorites
Review_body: This is one of my favorite films, and in my opinion, one of the most well crafted movies I have ever seen. I love movies that really put you into the time and place that they depict, particularly with historical films, and this will leave you feeling as if you were there for every second of it. If you ever wondered what it may have been like to sail with the British Navy during the Napoleonic Wars...well, this is the closest you'll ever get.The performances, particularly by Crowe and Paul Bettany are flawless. The screenplay is brilliantly written, the cinematography is exquisite, and the direction by the masterful Peter Weir is perfect in every way. The film could have taken the easy way out and focused mostly on battle scenes, but those come second to the story and well crafted characters. And trust me, when you actually care about the characters, any battle scenes that happen will be 100 times more intense than any of the bland, underdeveloped action films Hollywood churns out.That being said, the battle scenes are incredible, and will leave you on the edge of your seat. The film really leaves me with no doubt that this is what naval battles of this type, during this time period, would have been like. There is also an incredible scene during a storm that has to be seen to be believed. It is so realistic, that I cannot fathom how it was done.So, in a word, BRILLIANT. If you are a film fan who appreciates good writing, directing, acting, and cinematography, see this immediately. You will be utterly captivated from first frame to last. I would love to see more books in this series turned into films, with Peter Weir at the helm.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: Although filled with amazing sets and remarkable maritime atmosphere, one word comes through my mind when I think about this movie: propaganda. I won't elaborate here about the stylistic aspects of Master and Commander, but try to underline its strong and shameful political allusions: with M & C, Hollywood has offered the American audience a movie filled with good old Francophobe stereotypes. Tasty clichés in the political context of the movie's release: American's Francophobia (and boycott campaigning) reaches its peak with the French refusal to enter the Iraq War in 2003. What? The coward frogs won't go to war? Then let's eat "freedom fries", tax their wine and kick their bottoms on the big screen! The replacement of O'Brian's American villains by French ones was not done only to avoid American anger. This was also convenient. Let's study a bit our frog pirates.As I was watching the movie, I kept wondering "why the hell those French villains appear so few times?" Other viewers were also obviously frustrated by this absence of two-side perspective. Actually, the answer is clear: the American "war on terrorism" is just transposed on 1800's sea battlefields, with the French as Taliban. Look at the first battle scene (a great one by the way): an invisible enemy hiding in some demoniac smoke, striking cowardly with a stab-in-the-back technique and disappearing again as magic. What does this remind you of? Fundamentalist human bomb Muslims of course! And their bloody bombing attacks. It expresses the American frustration for a new type of war which they are not accustomed to. Namely, having to fight invisible terrorists, instead of well clearly organized adversaries (like the soviets were). The French privateer's aggressive cowardly tricks are just countless: hiding in a creek then falling upon a poor unarmed British boat, hiding in a destroyed piano to ambush Capt. Aubrey (final battle scene). Without mentioning the French captain's final trick,pretending to be the vessel's surgeon, to avoid martial punishment. Really those French privateers are incapable of any face-to-face confrontation! (Interesting detail: Aubrey's trick to have the French privateer chasing a fake ship was an idea of Surcouf, an 18th-19th century's French privateer) After 138 minutes of this kind of brainwashing, the hidden meaning appear as clear as light for the average American viewer: the French don't want war, consequently they are accomplices of S. Hussein's regime and the Taliban. Adding to this their cowardly military history, which seems quite similar to Taliban's terrorist methods, here is the point to get: French are like Taliban, in a sense they ARE Taliban.Bush's biblical superstition is there as well, personified by the old crazy seaman: "I tell you, this vessel is driven by the Devil". Reminiscence of Melville's Moby Dick no doubt. The French vessel is named "Acheron", a complete fictional name referring to Hades's river, the river of hell in Greek Mythology. Interesting subtle hidden message. The poor lad Hollom is a modern Jonas who did well to jump off the boat after all. Clear message printed again on the viewers' brain: "America has to wipe out this weakest link; otherwise it may put the whole organic community in danger". It also reflects the American biggest fear in the context of national hyper security: the psychosis of the terrorist threat hiding amongst the population, the Islamist fifth column. Who knows, maybe this Hollom was a discrete French sympathizer. Good riddance!Let's talk a bit of the protagonists' aesthetics. The very short time you'll be really able to see the French in the final battle is just astonishing. A bunch of pirates you could imagine in a tale for children: toothless mammals, scars, dirty bristly hairs, rags. What a contrast with those British play-boy seamen with their perfect teeth and blond-tinged hair: a bit more of those nonsenses and you would almost see them in a Baywatch's episode. The racial gap is hugely and boorishly stressed by Weir in order to dehumanize the evil enemy. A little homage is even paid to the great British scientist, Darwin, from whom so many racial mad ideologies and pseudo-scientific theories have emerged (loads of in particular in 19th century's Great-Britain, namely a feeling of superiority towards all non-islander populations, considered as threatening aliens. Just take a look at John Knox's works or Herbert Spencer's, an avalanche of scientific and historical nonsenses). God is on British's side, and so is Science then, embodied by the surgeon and his isolated humanistic positions. Fortunately, he eventually rallies to Aubrey's militaristic and Manichean ideals. Patriotic romanticism, scientific rationalism: perfect ingredients for the perfect propaganda recipe.Peter Weir's adherence to G. W. Bush holistic Neo-conservative ideology, and to an idealized world Anglo-Saxon imperialism, has really poisoned every minute of this movie, which is nothing but a masterpiece of silliness, a massive indigestible patriotism cake.P.S: I put 5/10 because the sets are incredible despite the story's disgraceful political position.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: And surprised I was. After hearing a friend rant endlessly about it, and having nothing to do one Friday night, I rented Master and Commander. The marketing staff should be cackling in glee, that a female in her 20's, would love this movie. It's an amazing movie. Russell Crowe is a force of nature, and all the other actors from Paul Bettany to Billy Boyd give wonderful performances. I especially enjoyed the details of life at sea, though most would call them boring. The day after my 5-day rental, I had to run to the nearest shop and buy the DVD, and have since re-watched it endlessly. I've never seen a more beautifully adapted, filmed and acted movie. Five stars out of five.
Movie_name: Master and Commander - The Far Side of the World

Review_body: Russell Crowe does it again! The savior of Rome, "Gladiator", brings to the screen another commanding performance. I heard women take in "small pursed-lipped gasps" looking at Russell Crowe on the posters, as we entered the theater. They were enjoying the night before the lights were even dimmed.
